PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that the public is overwhelmingly opposed to Telecom's plans to introduce time charges for local calls;
(2) that while Telecom remains a public enterprise, it must be accountable to the public, its owners; and
(3) while Telecom retains a statutory monopoly which shields it from the discipline of competition, it should not be unilaterally allowed to impose extortionate charges upon the public.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon all members of the Senate in Parliament assembled to take action to prevent Telecom introducing time charges for local calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the Senate in Parliament assembled. Your humble petitioners showeth:
(a) The introduction of time charge for local telephone calls would discriminate against ordinary telephone users.
(b) Time charge would be unfair to pensioners, handicapped people and low income earners.
As in duty bound your humble petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. We the undersigned:
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.
That we express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances for the purpose of food irradiation and disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1, 2, 5, 7 and 8 standing in my name for two sitting days hence for disallowance of Navigation Orders, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), Business Franchise (Tobacco and Petroleum) Products (Amendment) Ordinance, National Parks and Wildlife Regulations (Amendment) and Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (Annual General Meeting of the Industry) Regulations. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned about unreviewable discretions, an inappropriate subdelegation of legislative power, strict criminal liability offences and the apparent absence of any sanction to protect the confidentiality of the income of certain payers of a levy. Ministers have agreed either to remove discretions or provide for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review, to remove the subdelegation power and to provide for a statutory defence regarding the strict criminal offences. The Committee has been referred to an Act of Parliament which will adequately protect confidentiality. It was also referred to a number of other places which I will not mention here. In keeping with the usual practice, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of the Committee's scrutiny. The Committee's correspondence is too lengthy to incorporate and I seek leave to table it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
Navigation Orders No. 8 of 1987

In the Navigation Orders the Committee was concerned about how an unreviewable discretion to exempt people from merchant marine examination certificate fees would be exercised. Prior to 1982 fees were paid for examinations. Since 1982 fees are instead paid for a certificate on successful completion of the examinations. The Orders provided that where a candidate had already paid for an examination but did not sit it that fee should be credited to his or her certificate fee. The Orders also provided for the possibility that a candidate may have paid, in advance, fees for a number of examinations. The sum to be credited to any such candidate's certificate fee would vary with the number of examinations completed. This gave rise to the need for a discretion to grant exemptions from certificate fees if sufficient examination fees remained. In the light of the investigation prompted by the Committee's query, the then Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, the Hon. Peter Duncan, M.P., undertook to repeal the provisions as they have served their purpose.

The Committee was also concerned about a provision which inappropriately subdelegated to the Commonwealth Interdepartmental Committee on Fees and Allowances the legislative power to fix fees for medical fitness examinations. The Minister agreed that it might have been more appropriate expressly to specify in the Order the actual fee as fixed by the Committee. The Minister has undertaken to repeal the provision. Private practitioners who charge normal consulting fees are now used instead of Commonwealth Medical Officers.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment)

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson, has agreed to the Committee's request to amend the Regulations expressly to place ``reasonable'' limits on the amount of information which certain prospective users of the Marine Park will be required by the Marine Park Authority to publish in the press. The Minister agreed to amend the regulations to provide some defence of reasonable excuse for individuals like the masters or owners of vessels or aircraft who under the regulations would otherwise be deemed to have committed offences constituted by the acts of employees or other agents. The Minister also agreed to provide for AAT review of refusals to grant permission to take certain fish in the Park for education or research purposes.
Business Franchise (Tobacco and Petroleum) Products (Amendment) Ordinance 1987

Section 36g of the Ordinance gave the Commissioner for Business Franchises a discretion to issue replacement diesel fuel exemption certificate to a person whose first certificate had been lost or destroyed. The Committee considered that if such a discretion were needed a refusal to issue a replacement would reflect badly on the integrity of a certificate holder and therefore an avenue of appeal should exist. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., agreed to overcome this problem by amending the Ordinance to remove the discretion and recast the provision in an objective formulation so that a copy of a certificate would be issued on request.
National Parks and Wildlife Regulations (Amendment)

On 24 November 1987 (Senate Daily Hansard, page 2272) the Committee reported on its attitude to possibly strict criminal liability offences. The Committee takes the view that only exceptional circumstances will justify the imposition of strict liability. The Committee prefers to see in offence provisions express reference to the need for some form of criminal intention or the existence of some reasonable defence.

These particular regulations applied to certain conservation zones the strict liability offences of the Principal Regulations. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson, has informed the Committee that its queries have precipitated a review of the Principal Regulations to identify strict liability offences which will be amended expressly to provide for statutory reasonable defences.
Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (Annual General Meeting of the Industry) Regulations

An eligible winemaker's entitlement to vote at the AGM was determined by reference to the amount of levy paid by that producer. That amount was to be kept confidential as it was indicative of the financial status of the producer. Thus an obligation of confidentiality was imposed on the public servants who would be nominated to act as tellers at the AGM. However, there appeared to be no sanction in the regulations for any breach of such confidentiality. This could have undermined the strength of the protection afforded to producers. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, The Hon. John Kerin, M.P., explained to the Committee that section 70 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act imposed penalties on public servants for disclosure of information and the intention was that this section would operate as the sanction for the purposes of the regulations. This sanction was preferable because it imposed a higher penalty than could have been prescribed by regulations and it avoided the undesirable creation of 2 alternate penalties for essentially the same offence.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, is somewhat complex and I gave him notice of it several hours ago. Since the higher education Green Paper proposes enormous increases in participation in higher education over the next 10 years and seeks and extra number of graduates of about 37,000 per year, I ask the Minister: Where will the extra students come from? Is not the teenage population of Australia dropping? Is it not true that even retention of most students to year 12 in school and the transfer of, say, half of them to higher education could provide only one-third of the proposed increase? So that people can evaluate the Green Paper carefully, will the Minister explain the expected source of the extra numbers of students referred to in the document?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did receive some notice of this question, although in the rush in my office prior to Question Time I had misunderstood its actual source. I thought it was from Senator Michael Baume, instead of Senator Peter Baume, so I will give a slightly modified answer. The question, framed in the way it is, suggests that the questioner has not read the Green Paper. Had it been from Senator Michael Baume, that would not have surprised me at all because one cannot read or think while one is talking and he spends most of his time talking. However, I would have expected a more relevant question from Senator Peter Baume, or at least some indication in the question that he had read the paper carefully. The question, phrased as it is, indicates that he has not.

ANSWER.PARA: I will deal with some of the specifics. To begin with, I remember from my admittedly cursory reading of the paper that the figure of 37,000 graduates is given not as a firm target but as an illustrative figure which would be required should Australia's proportion of graduates move to become comparable with the proportions in the United States, Japan and some, although by no means all, European countries. For example, West Germany has quite a low proportion of graduates to total population compared with the rest of north-western Europe and North America. That sort of scenario-that is, reaching rough comparability with North America and most of north-western Europe-would require a graduate output of around 125,000 instead of the present 88,000, which is, of course, the source of the 37,000 that Senator Baume referred to. It is oversimplistic to look at only the teenage population, which it is true, will decline between now and the turn of the century, except if there are massive changes to immigration intakes. The 17- to 22-year-old population will increase over that same period.

It is also necessary to take account of the substantial increases in retention rates to year 12. To be fair, the question acknowledges that that is a relevant factor. This is a change which flows from the policies of this Government. There are also changes in the rate at which students transfer from school to higher education. Finally, the other important point is that even a relatively small increase in the graduation rate would secure the entire growth rate set out in that scenario, which, I repeat, is a scenario, not necessarily a target. Increased retention to year 12, plus a small increase in the transfer rate, would offset the relative decline in teenage numbers. In this respect it is important to note that the Green Paper emphasises the role to be played by higher education courses in technical and further education. If somebody wants to look at this more carefully or in a more detailed way, I commend especially Chapter 3 and Appendix D to the report, which will expand on the information I have given.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Firstly, are there any overseas suppliers of directories which place in their publications entries which have not been asked for by Australian businesses? Secondly, if so, do any of them send invoices to those businesses asking for payment for the entries? Thirdly, if so, is the Government doing anything about this and, if so, what?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the three parts of the question asked by Senator Cooney is yes, yes and yes, but I need to take this opportunity to elaborate on the problem Senator Cooney raises.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite amazed at the response from the Opposition because this matter has come to the attention of the Government from two sources-firstly, from small business itself and, secondly, from a number of members of parliament who have been billed by this ruse of overseas companies sending telex invoices to them. It is quite apparent from the response we are getting that those on the other side are not astute enough to realise the difference between a legitimate account and one of these accounts they have received and could very well have paid for.

ANSWER.PARA: As I mentioned, the problem confronted by consumers in Australia and confronted by small business people is one whereby a number of overseas organisations bill and send invoices and demands for payment for unsolicited entries in all sorts of indexes. The Government's response is one of concern. We have also embarked upon a course of action in order to try to protect consumers-in particular, as I mentioned, the small business section of the Australian private sector.

I think Senator Cooney would be fully aware of the fact that the Trade Practices Act has provisions to cover this sort of practice. However, the problem we have in this instance is that most of the publishers of these telex directories have their assets overseas and, as a consequence, there is no way of enforcing the provisions of the Trade Practices Act in respect of them because of the inability of Australian courts to have their orders enforced overseas. As a consequence the Government has pursued these operators in a number of ways at a diplomatic level. On the one hand we have proceeded through the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and put our case in that way. On the other hand we have approached individual governments with some success. The Swiss authorities propose to amend their legislation in the near future, and have sought to be given information on the Australian Trade Practices Act in order that they can examine the Act to see whether they can adopt the provisions to suit their particular circumstances. The Government is still pursuing this matter in Liechtenstein and West Germany but not with as much success as it is having in Switzerland.

I thank Senator Cooney for giving me the opportunity to highlight this particular problem and also for giving me another opportunity to warn business and, of course, those members of parliament opposite who have already paid some of these accounts about paying them in the future.

—I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications a question relating to John Pilger's The Last Dream, screened by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) last night. From whence did pressure emanate for the ABC to cut the program, although Central Television had indemnified the ABC against legal action? Was it a case of self-censorship and, if so, why, or was it a case of political censorship applied from outside the ABC? Considering the issue of Australia's sovereignty in this bicentennial year, does the Minister acknowledge that the meaning of the passage suggesting that the Governor-General, Sir John Kerr, `could be trusted to act in the interests of the Western alliance and not necessarily in the interests of Australia' was changed substantially by the omission of the words `and not necessarily in the interests of Australia'? Does the Minister agree that it is in the public interest to have allegations about outside interference in Australia's affairs, not only relating to the events of 1975, openly aired and debated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly the case, as I am advised, that the ABC's assessment of the Pilger programs has been based solely on legal considerations. The ABC has stated publicly and openly that there was no internal pressure applied for changes to be made to the documentaries, and certainly there has been no such pressure externally from me nor, to my knowledge, any other member of the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC has advised me, and I have spoken directly to its senior management just to establish precisely what the situation was, that the minor changes made to the program were made on the advice of its lawyers on the basis that the line in question-only one line was deleted from the program-was both defamatory and indefensible in the courts. I believe it is only responsible for the ABC to make its own legal judgments, rather than simply to rely in any particular case on an indemnity which may or may not be readily enforceable as a matter of practice should the situation arise where it had to be relied upon. Mr Grahame Reynolds, the ABC Director of Television, has said publicly:

Although the ABC was indemnified against loss through any legal action taken against it over the series, this did not mean that the ABC could abrogate its responsibilities and obligations as a responsible national broadcaster.

I think that is a reasonable view and one that should be accepted at face value. As to the final part of the question, of course I do not believe it is in the national interest to suppress allegations about outside interference in Australia's affairs. Such allegations can constitute a useful contribution to an understanding of issues and to free and informed public debate, even though in particular instances such allegations may well prove to be wild and unsubstantiated. I note that allegations about external interference in Australia's affairs in the Pilger documentary did go to air. The matter in issue was not a further allegation of that kind but a defamatory reference to a particular individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister think that the omission of that particular line substantially changed the emphasis of that part of the program-that is, the Pinwell interview-and, secondly, if he believes that the people of Australia have a right to public information of this kind, will the Government be commissioning an open and full inquiry into such allegations, including the ones made by a Mr Christopher Boyce, whose allegations have never been refuted?
—Order! Obviously the first part of the supplementary question is out of order. The Minister can answer the second part if he wants to.
—To the extent that I had an opinion the answer would be no, and to that extent the second part of the question would not arise, even though it is manifestly silly in its own terms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In a statement on 7 February, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Unlike previous retrenchments in the North Queensland Timber Industry, workers will not be thrown on the unemployment scrapheap . . . This will enable all timber workers displaced at the Hancock mill in Cairns to maintain continuity of employment.

Will the Minister tell the Senate how it is possible to create jobs in a situation like this and not at other times and other places when no political issues are involved? Will he see that the formula is provided to the many other areas of Australia where there are high numbers of unemployed at present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting question. I will attempt to do it justice. I believe that an obligation exists between the Government and timber workers in north Queensland because their employment has been directly affected by a decision of the Government. It is not a question of general economic decline as existed, for instance, in the last year of the Fraser Government when thousands of people every week were going out of employment. In this case, because there was a specific decision that prevented logging, a significant number of people were to lose their jobs.
—How many?
—Two thousand.

—Two thousand is a ridiculous figure. According to the industry the figure was around 700. But we all know how you count in Queensland, Senator Boswell. I would have thought that our obligation in that respect was fairly clear. As to why we would not apply that to every other part of Australia, obviously it is an arrangement that can be applied only where people are put out of work directly because of government decision making, rather than because of general economic factors, particularly those we have inherited.

—I ask the Minister for Justice and Acting Attorney-General: In relation to the video Faces of Death, in relation to which there has been some association with recent murders, has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to newspaper reports about the availability of this gruesome video? Is it true that the film has been given an M classification by the Film Censorship Board? What action is the Attorney-General contemplating to have this objectionable video removed from video outlets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The attention of the Attorney-General and me was drawn over the weekend to reports of the availability of the video Faces of Death, which I am advised is a particularly gruesome video. Some of those media reports stated that it had been released with an M classification. It transpires that the film version of Faces of Death was submitted for classification to the Film Censorship Board in 1980. The video version was submitted in 1983. Both versions unanimously were refused classification by the Film Censorship Board under section 13 (1) (a) of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations. This section deals with films that are indecent and obscene. The Board has had inquiries from Victorian police about the film and they have been informed by the Board that both the film and video versions were refused classification. The Film Censorship Board also wrote to the New South Wales Government, in November last year, informing it that there had been reports of the video Faces of Death being available in video outlets in New South Wales. The New South Wales Government wrote back to the Board in November indicating that the matter had been placed in the hands of the police.

ANSWER.PARA: The enforcement of the classifications assigned by the Film Censorship Board in the States is dealt with by State law. Video retailers are required by State law to offer for hire videos which have been classified by the Board. The hire of videos which have been refused classification carries penalties of up to $5,000 for a company or $1,000 or six months gaol for an individual. In conclusion, I thank Senator Jones for his question which raises a matter of great concern in the community, when videos are available of a particularly gruesome character and particularly those which involve an entanglement of sexual exploitation and violence. For that reason, at the meeting of Premiers convened to discuss the whole question of gun control, the much wider issue of the culture of violence that can be exacerbated and nurtured by the availability of these sorts of videos and films was also considered. That Premiers Conference directed the Film Censorship Board to enforce more rigorously the current classifications and gave to the Attorneys-General, who I think are meeting in about the second or third week of March, the task of reviewing those classifications with a view to a much more stringent system of classifications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you take notice of the Senate Select Committee on Video Material?

—Yes, Senator Walters, we are looking forward to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. That will also help the Government. —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of advice from the Under-Treasurer of Queensland to his new Premier and Treasurer advising him to establish an Expenditure Review Committee accompanied by a threat that if he did not do so he would have to face the prospect of having to impose new taxes or raising existing taxes to meet a mounting State Budget deficit in that State? Is the Queensland Government facing major fiscal problems as a consequence of past mismanagement? Will these financial difficulties have any implications for the performance of the national economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of such advice; indeed, I have here a copy of a Queensland Cabinet submission, No. 47914, which is just over 1 1/2 pages long. I understand that the reason that Queensland Cabinet submissions need to be kept that short is that most members of Cabinet cannot read without moving their lips. But there are some attachments to the submission which I do not have with me at present. I am not sure whether they are in the office, but when I get hold of them I might have something to say about them as well. The submission is dated 9 December. It contains the following advice:

ANSWER.PARA: Please note that if the concept of a major expenditure review is abandoned, then in view of the overall budget situation Treasury will need to prepare a range of funding options, including new and/or higher taxation, to lift the resource level more in keeping with expenditure expectations.

That is Treasury-speak for saying, `You are spending more than you can afford'. It is Queensland Treasury-speak, but Treasury-speak of that type tends to be much the same from one Treasury to another. It is a Treasury-speak way of saying, `You are spending more than you can afford, or more than you are levying taxes to sustain'; in other words, in much the same way as Senator Chaney's Government used to do and, in particular, as his Government did during its last year in office, when it brought down that grossly irresponsible 1982 Budget-an assessment with which Senator Stone concurs entirely, by the way.

The letter from the Treasury accompanying the submission points out that Queensland is facing a deficit of about $160m in the next financial year and $215m in the following one. In other words, the problem is getting worse-just as the problem was getting worse with the Federal Budget when John Howard lost control of it, fortunately. Even those calculations are based on some pretty stringent assumptions, such as that there will be no new programs, no tax concessions, no special major projects or works programs-in other words, no more MacKenzie River dams or anything like that, which of course would be a good thing on its own-no natural disasters, no abnormal wage or cost increases, no adverse result of grants commission relativities, and so on.

It is also interesting to note that the Cabinet submission proposed that the Queensland Expenditure Review Committee consist entirely of officials-Under-Treasurer, Co-ordinator-General, a senior Treasury budget officer and the permanent head of whatever department was under review-although under the oversight of a Cabinet Budget committee. As someone who has had some experience in this area, I should like to advise the Queensland Treasurer and some of his Cabinet colleagues that they should get more closely involved in the process, otherwise it will not have the impetus to proceed very far, because they will have to face the fact that years of National Party pork-barrelling and mismanagement have reduced Queensland to a very poor position.

I make two predictions. There are two possible outcomes: one is to cut the Queensland Government's longstanding waste and inefficiency; the other is to increase State taxes. Based on observation of the Government of Queensland over a considerable period, I think that the people of Queensland can look forward to the latter, that is, increased taxes, rather than enhancement of efficiency and elimination of waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that there is no immediate prospect of catching up on the serious backlog of cargo containers on the Sydney waterfront, since the backlog is about 1,000 containers and the present rate of handling is only keeping pace with the normal flow? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

ANSWER.PARA: I will continue to monitor that situation and see what, if anything, might be able to be done by way of further Government involvement or encouragement to the parties. TALK.START.PARA: —You must be joking.

—My question is to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does Australia's current policy of selling uranium to France whilst protesting that country's nuclear testing program in the Pacific leave Australia open to charges of either hypocrisy or double standards, or both? Are the arrogant and contemptuous statements made by Mr Giraud, the French Minister for Defence, that France does not need our uranium and that testing at Mururoa is none of our business a result of Australia's weak-kneed stance on uranium sales and exports to France? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will protest to the French Government over Mr Giraud's remarks and remind the French Government that nuclear testing in the Pacific region is certainly our business? Will the Government resume its ban on the sale of uranium to France as demanded by its Party platform to back up its opposition to nuclear testing in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would only be conceivable grounds for accusing the Government of hypocrisy in supplying uranium to France while at the same time continuing to protest the holding of nuclear testing in the South Pacific were there to be any grounds for believing that Australian uranium was being directed to that particular purpose. We have been at pains to point out on innumerable occasions that Australian uranium in France is covered by Australia's bilateral safeguards agreement with France and EURATOM. These agreements prohibit the use of Australian uranium for nuclear explosives or for any military purpose. Regular accounting of Australian origin nuclear material under these agreements is made to the Australian Safeguards Office to ensure that the nuclear material remains exclusively in peaceful use.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the obligations entered into under bilateral agreements, Australian origin nuclear material in France is subject to independent verification by International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors so that it is not diverted to weapons manufacture. We are confident, as I have said on previous occasions, that France's use of Australian uranium is quite in accordance with our uranium export policy and the obligations of the Australia-France and the Australian-EURATOM nuclear safeguards agreements. Other elements in justification of the decision made last Budget to resume sales to France have been the subject of innumerable statements by Ministers in the period between then and now. Senator Wood can look those statements up for himself without any need for further repetition from me.

As to Monsieur Giraud's statements about France's need for uranium, I would not begin to characterise his statement that France does not need our uranium in the terms that Senator Wood used for the obvious reason that those statements are perfectly and totally accurate. France produces its own uranium from domestic sources sufficient to cover its entire weapons program, both testing and manufacture, as I understand it, and it is amply endowed with rival sources of supply from elsewhere around the world, by and large at cheaper prices-at least this was the case last year in respect of the backlog of uranium that existed pursuant to earlier contracts-than were available from Australia. So it is the case that Australia, in refusing to supply uranium to France, is not in any way inhibiting that country's capacity to get uranium both for weapons purposes from its own sources and for peaceful power generation purposes. Senator Wood will know the extent to which the French economy relies on nuclear energy for power generation. It is very substantial indeed-the highest in the western world. Despite that very large demand, France does not rely on Australian uranium for that purpose.

As to whether or not the testing at Mururoa is Australia's business, I make it perfectly clear in relation to that statement of Monsieur Giraud-I will be making it clear to him when I meet him again this afternoon; I have already met him over lunch-that Australia continues to hold very strong views on that subject and does not resile from them in any way, just as we hold strong views on the general status, applicability and good sense of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that Mr Giraud said that he could not guarantee that Australian uranium was not used in the French military program, on what basis does the Minister have greater confidence that Australian uranium is not being used in the military program than the French Defence Minister?

—I do not know precisely what Monsieur Giraud may have said on that subject. I only know what was reported in the Canberra Times this morning. That very same Canberra Times article also quotes Monsieur Giraud as having noted that France has signed an agreement with Australia that Australian uranium would be used only for peaceful purposes. The Age reported the French Defence Minister as having guaranteed, in quite contrary terms to the Canberra Times report, that Australian uranium in France was not being used for military purposes. Having heard Monsieur Giraud very briefly on this subject over lunch-as I say, I will have the opportunity to pursue this matter further with him later on-I have no doubt whatsoever that he would say, and I have already heard him say, that these things are governed by both bilateral and multilateral agreements and that there can be no question of France either needing to, wanting to, or being likely to breach its guarantees properly and seriously entered into in that respect.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Did the Minister see the claim by his colleague, Mr Holding, that road crashes had cost Australia-I emphasise the word `cost'-$5,700m last year? Is it not true that most of these costs-again I emphasise `costs'-appear as additions to gross national product and gross domestic product (GDP)? What proportion of last year's GDP is $5,700m, and how much did Australia's GDP grow last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I remember correctly the answer to the last two of the four questions is, in both cases, a little over 2 per cent. But the answer to the third question is not particularly relevant, as it involves a figure of $5,700m. I have seen the Press release, although I do not know, and I have not had time to check this out with Mr Holding, what the $5,700m is supposed to represent. I can give Senator Coulter some information about what is and what is not counted in the GDP. Assuming that repair work on vehicles is part of that $5,700m figure, repair work on vehicles and the replacement of vehicles does not appear as an addition to GDP if the repairs are paid for by business enterprises or paid for under an insurance contract in which a business enterprise is an insured party. Those costs would typically appear as intermediate expenditure, and therefore not be added to GDP.

ANSWER.PARA: I think medical treatment is probably included in that figure. The cost of medical treatment provided to injured persons is dependent on whether it is paid out of workers compensation moneys or via a third party insurance contract in which a business enterprise was an insured party. Under those circumstances, as with insurance, the costs do not, I understand, add to GDP but are regarded as a call on the value added already produced by the business enterprise which in the first instance pays the bill. The costs of working time lost and personal suffering, which are not subject to financial compensation, do not appear in GDP. Again it is likely that some imputed cost was included in the $5,700m figure.

This does leave some part of the total costs adding to GDP but I am advised that an attempt to redefine GDP concepts to exclude those elements would be extremely complex. It would be possible to exclude the repair costs of vehicles not in business use from being additions to GDP if household expenditure on motor vehicles were treated as part of investment spending rather than consumption spending, while to exclude medical costs borne by households would require more fundamental changes to the accounts-indeed, to the extent where it could touch off a spiral in which all of the gross domestic product gradually disappeared.

If Senator Coulter has any specific propositions to put on the way in which he believes that the recording of this or other components of GDP could be improved in a technical sense, I would certainly be willing to ask the Treasurer whether he can arrange a meeting between Mr Castles, the Australian Statistician, and Senator Coulter at which they discuss the underlying concepts in national accounts and what improvements could be made to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's reply, which indicates the arbitrariness which determines what goes in and what is left out in the derivation of gross domestic product, will the Minister cease quoting gross domestic product as an indicator of anything useful or relevant to human welfare in this country?

—No, I will not, firstly because I do not accept the assertion that it is arbitrary. Certainly there are judgments made at the margin about what should be included and what should not, but in the preparation of national accounts, statisticians in Australia, and in all comparable countries, tend to follow consistently a set of criteria which do have a rational basis. I know that is probably a mode of behaviour that is hard for the Australian Democrats to understand or even comprehend at all, but that is what is done.
—I ask that further questions be placed on notice. While I am on my feet, Senator Short sent me a note at Question Time. I will be happy to discuss that matter with him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

Understandably, I did not have the Hansard with me, but I have had it sent into the chamber since and have consulted my office. —Last Tuesday, in my baptismal Question Time, Senator Coulter asked me a question about the substance dichlorvos, which is used in Shell pest strips and Baygon. I am now in a position to give a more detailed answer. I will not go to the question, which was in seven parts, but the answer is that yes, I am aware of reports of the results of the United States national toxicological program's recent carcinogenicity bio-assays of dichlorvos. I am also aware that the reported results of these experiments differ from those of previous studies of the carcinogenicity of dichlorvos in rodents, which were fully reviewed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) in June 1987. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a ministerial statement on standards, accreditation and quality and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
INTRODUCTION

In September 1986 the Government established a Committee of Review of Standards, Accreditation and Quality Control and Assurance. This Committee was asked to examine the national systems of standards, accreditation and quality as they apply to the manufacturing and services sectors. The Committee was chaired by Dr Kevin Foley. It included Professor George Bennett, Mr Greg Harrison, Mr John Joyce and Mr Greg Warwick. The Committee's report, presented in June of last year, was tabled in Parliament in October. This statement represents the Government's response to that report.

Undoubtedly, the Committee had a difficult task. It was the first comprehensive review of its type in Australia-never before had Australia sought to determine whether her systems for setting standards, and for accreditation, were helping to develop efficient, competitive and export-oriented industries producing quality goods and services.
The Committee came to a singular conclusion that has far-reaching implications-it concluded quite simply that quality issues are at the very heart of Australia's economic problems.

Quality can be defined simply as meeting customer expectations. Much of the relentless success of Japanese industry in gaining export markets has been achieved through dedication to quality of products that satisfy the customer. The Japanese have pursued quality at all levels of the firm. Japan places great emphasis on its people, on work and process, and on service in order to meet the expectations of its customers.

The Japanese approach to quality is called `total quality management' or `total quality control'. Japan's approach is spreading rapidly through North America and Europe, and through countries such as Korea and Taiwan. It is spreading rapidly because it gives firms practising it an advantage in the international marketplace. Total quality control is many steps ahead of the now obsolete method of `inspecting in' quality at the ends of production lines with its emphasis on fault detection leading to costly reworking and product recall.

Enlightened firms now aim to `build in' quality at all stages of the production cycle-from product development and production planning to marketing and after-sales service. The whole work force strives to achieve quality, with chief executives taking final responsibility for it.

Firms that adopt total quality management do not assume they `have made it'. Rather, using inputs from all sections of the work force, they strive continuously for incremental improvement. In this way improving quality not only provides customers with what they require, but also improves productivity and reduces cost by eliminating waste, error and defective work.

The scope for Australian industry to use total quality management in order to improve its reputation, both in Australia and overseas, as a producer of quality goods and services is tremendous. Studies show that the poor quality of some Australian goods and services is a major concern to consumers. On the other hand, those Australian firms that are delivering quality have found it a powerful aid to marketing at home and abroad.

Designing and building quality into goods and services does not only result in organisations that operate more smoothly, more cost effectively, and with greater market orientation. As a recent survey by the Australian Organisation for Quality Control demonstrates, it also brings a substantially higher return on investment.

The prospect of much greater returns permits the primary responsibility for adopting the new approaches to quality to be placed with industry. The responsibility of governments is to ensure that an appropriate infrastructure is in place. This infrastructure will comprise internationally recognised standards setting and accreditation systems, quality awareness including industry support programs, education and training for quality, and uniform use of standards, accreditation and quality in Federal, State and local government purchasing and regulatory activities.
QUALITY

The Foley Committee made the quality infrastructure in Australia the focus of its recommendations. It believed that the main problem was not one of finding more resources, but of providing the existing infrastructure with effective leadership and guidance.

The Committee proposed that two new organisations-an Australian Quality Authority and a Quality Management Organisation-be established to oversee the quality infrastructure and to promote quality management principles.

In considering these proposals, the Government has kept in mind recent developments such as increased interest in quality by industry, unions and governments. Much of this interest represents a response to conditions created by the economic and industry policies of the Government and by the publication of the Foley Report itself, and is to be encouraged. Other developments, most of which have occurred since the Foley Committee framed its recommendations, include:
(a) the rapid growth of the Total Quality Management Institute of Australia, established by industry in April 1987 to promote the awareness and practice of total quality management;

(b) the effects of industry and government measures for improving quality awareness-for example the quality program in the automotive industry, the new submar- ine construction project, the frigate project and the Vendor Qualification Scheme, within the Information Industries Strategy;

(c) the establishment of a Quality Committee of the National Industry Extension Service, to identify gaps in co-ordinating the development and delivery of quality- related services. This Committee is representative of industry, unions, the Standards Association of Australia, the National Association of Testing Authorities, Australia For Quality, the Total Quality Management Institute of Australia and the Australian Organisation for Quality Control; and
(d) a revamping of standards setting procedures and management arrangements within the Standards Association of Australia.

These developments are already changing the quality infrastructure. The choice before the Government was whether to nurture the changes taking place in the infrastructure or to establish additional bodies with the authority to make the changes they regard as necessary.

As quality is primarily a matter for industry, the Government is keen to ensure that industry-based initiatives are given every opportunity to develop. The Government is encouraging the active involvement of employees and unions at the enterprise level to improve the quality of products and services.

As it views its own intervention as a last resort, the Government has decided to provide more time for the existing and emerging infra- structure to fulfil Australia's requirements. In taking this approach the Government looks to organisations within the infrastructure to provide the leadership the Foley Committee saw as necessary. The Government prefers to use these newly created mechanisms and to improve existing organisations before considering the creation of additional quality related organisations.

The Government's strategy is to encourage the further development and maturity of the existing infrastructure. Should the emerging arrangements not develop as expected or fail to meet Australia's requirements, the Government will again assess whether a new organisation is required.

The remaining gap in the infrastructure is the lack of uniformity in the way governments use standards and accreditation in their purchasing and regulatory activities. I will address this issue later in this statement.

The Foley Committee called for the development of a quality management concept suitable for Australian conditions. The Total Quality Management Institute of Australia and the Standards Association of Australia are developing a joint statement of quality management principles. Also the Standards Association of Australia has now adopted ISO 9000, the international quality systems standards, as an Australian Standard and will be using them in its Supplier Assessment Scheme. The Government believes that these developments, coupled with appropriate quality management principles generally accepted among experts in the area, should develop the ``concept'' suitable for Australian conditions that the Foley Committee recommended. This concept is not static; it needs to develop in line with international experience, and as the body of knowledge on quality management expands.

An important part of the quality infrastructure is the ready availability to firms of guidance on the adoption and implementation of quality management systems and encouragement for them to take on such systems. The private sector and organisations such as the Standards Association of Australia are playing an increasing role in providing services of this kind.

A good example of what can be achieved is the major quality program being introduced by the Federation of Automotive Parts Manufacturers into the automotive industry. The program aims to establish a common approach to quality throughout the industry.

The submarine and frigate construction program also will be important means of accrediting a large number of firms to formal quality management systems standards. Assistance is already available in some States under NIES for this purpose and will shortly become available in the remainder.

It is also important that attention be paid to quality in the service industries, and in particular to those that are export-oriented. The tourist and information sectors both rely on quality of service to obtain and maintain international markets.

In summary, it is clear that attention must be given to providing appropriate advice on quality management principles to many areas of industry, and in particular to small and medium-sized firms. The National Industry Extension Service and its Quality Committee are working to co-ordinate public and private sector services in the quality area.
EDUCATION, TRAINING AND AWARENESS

The Government is keen to provide an industry focus to developments in education. Accordingly, it is essential that the education and research system provides appropriate training and fosters awareness of quality issues. I am keen to see this sector match the role played by institutions overseas in developing quality management techniques and promoting their use in industry. I would like to see links created between industry and tertiary education institutions in this area.

I have drawn to the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training my view that quality management should be a priority area in the education and research system, especially in the context of the Government's Key Centres of Teaching and Research Program. Key Centres provide the necessary concentration of teaching resources for undergraduate training, the opportunity for postgraduate study and research, and should help to develop close links with industry and other sectors. My Department will, in collaboration with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, seek to establish a Key Centre of Teaching and Research on quality matters in a higher education institution. Any such centre would be expected to contribute to the development of education on quality in universities, institutes, CAEs, TAFE colleges and at the secondary level through, for example, the development of curriculum modules.

The ``quality ethic'' is an important part of the productive culture which the Government is seeking to encourage. Despite the commendable activities of specialist organisations such as Australia For Quality, the Total Quality Management Institute of Australia and the Organisation for Quality Control, there is still a lack of awareness in Australian industry of the importance of quality. A broad program of awareness will be undertaken to sharpen Australian attitudes to quality. The Government intends to take every opportunity to raise overall awareness of quality among business and the community.

Australia For Quality is proposing a further campaign involving free radio time contributed by members of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters. It is encouraging to see industry take the lead in this matter. My Department will be supporting this initiative and others to promote awareness through television. Another private sector initiative is the Australia For Quality Award which will be launched later this year. Also, the Minister for Consumer Affairs will be undertaking a major campaign on consumer aspects of quality.
STANDARDS

Standards are reference documents, materials or equipment specifying requirements against which products or processes are defined or assessed. The standards system is one of the elements of the quality infrastructure.
Standards can be effective only if recognised and adhered to by potential users. Furthermore, standards can be effective in promoting exports when they are consistent with international standards.

It is not feasible in Australia to have all standards prepared by a single organisation. A number of organisations in Australia have established roles in standards writing in specialised and discrete areas and are accepted to be impartial and expert.

The Standards Association of Australia is generally accepted as the peak organisation for standards writing in Australia. The Government considers it appropriate, as recommended by the Foley Report, to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding formalising the relationship between the Government and the Standards Association of Australia, and recognising the Association as the peak standards writing body in Australia.

However, there has been criticism of the Association, particularly over the length of time taken to prepare standards. The Association has acknowledged these problems and has begun to take steps to correct them. The Foley Committee made a number of practical suggestions which the Government commends to the Association.

At the same time, the Government has a responsibility to more clearly express its expectations of the Standards Association and to link its financial support of the Association with desired performance goals. These matters will be taken up in the Memorandum of Understanding.

One of the Government's principal aims for the standards system is that Australian standards should conform more closely to international standards, and that departures occur only for compelling reasons. The Foley Committee supported Australia becoming a signatory to the Standards Code of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Code places obligations on signatories to use international standards and provides benefits through access to the markets of other signatory nations. I will be suggesting to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that consideration be given to Australia becoming a signatory to this Code.

Greater alignment between Australian and international standards will go some of the way to resolving a particular problem for our manufacturers. Standards which are mandatory, that is, incorporated in government regulation, are more easily enforced on local producers than on importers. This is because of the extreme difficulty of screening imported goods at the point of entry. This problem is aggravated by different mandatory standards among the States. The end result is often an advantage to the importer.

It would help if Australian regulatory authorities relied more on overseas test results, such as those produced by laboratories accredited by a national agency recognised by Australia's National Association of Testing Authorities.

Responsibility for ensuring that imported goods conform to mandatory standards rests ultimately with the authorities administering those regulations. It will continue to be necessary for local producers to bring evasions of mandatory standards to the attention of the authorities. These evasions will also highlight standards which may need to be revised to bring them into line with overseas practice.
ACCREDITATION

Accreditation is the provision of an assurance to the customer that a product or service complies with certain standards or specifications. For most consumers, the main forms of assurance are the guarantees and warranties of retailers or manufacturers. Where consumers and other customers are unable to check compliance, accreditation processes are desirable.

Where testing is required, the customer may seek assurance by testing personally, by tests performed by the manufacturer or service provider, or by tests performed by an independent third party. Essentially third-party accreditation takes two forms: product certification based on conformance to design and function, and process certification which endorses a company's capabilities to consistently meet consumer requirements. In practice, internationally, accreditation of quality systems has become more important than type testing of individual products. Adoption of ISO 9000 as the Australian Standard should assist international acceptance of the process capabilities of Australian firms.

An important part of the accreditation infrastructure is a national system of laboratory accreditation. The National Association of Testing Authorities operates a Registration Scheme which enables customers and other interested parties such as government agencies to have confidence in test results produced by laboratories accredited under the scheme. This scheme is particularly important in enabling customers and others to have confidence in test results. Where assurance is obtained in this way, duplicate testing is avoided.

In accreditation as in standards, the existence of a nationally recognised peak organisation is desirable. The National Association of Testing Authorities has won a high level of recognition nationally and internationally. The Association will receive endorsement as the national laboratory accreditation body through a Memorandum of Understanding with the Government as recommended by the Foley Report.

In addition to that Association, the accreditation infrastructure includes a wide range of product and process certification arrangements undertaken by many approval bodies, including Commonwealth and State government and the Standards Association of Australia. The variety of these arrangements reflects the diversity of marketing and other circumstances which industry faces.

This is especially so for industries or products which are innovative. An essential element in marketing an innovative product is to assure the customer that the product performs as claimed. This may require the development of novel test procedures. The infrastructure, on a fee for service basis, needs to be capable of developing these new tests as required.

In a number of industry sectors, entry to export markets requires accreditation of products and/or manufacturing processes by purchasers or regulatory authorities. The information industry, the aerospace industry, and the medical and scientific equipment industries need such accreditation. The Government will be moving to further develop a Technical Help to Exporters Scheme as recommended by the Foley Committee, drawing on existing activities within Austrade and organisations such as the Standards Association of Australia and the National Association of Testing Authorities.

In some cases, programs to assist firms gain accreditation are already in place. Austrade has retained a consultant in the United States to help Australian firms apply to Underwriters Laboratories, a major US accrediting agency.

As part of the Information Industries Strategy announced previously, a vendor qualification scheme is being implemented. The scheme would help Australian component suppliers become accredited to supply world markets.
COMMONWEALTH/STATE ISSUES

Commonwealth and State governments have a responsibility to ensure that their purchasing and regulatory activities promote business efficiency and support exports. The Foley Committee noted a number of criticisms by industry of current arrangements. These included:
(a) lack of uniformity between the States and Territories in the adoption of standards in their regulatory functions, resulting in increased costs to industry;
(b) goods required to undergo multiple tests to meet mandatory standards where a single test would suffice;
(c) enforcing mandatory standards on Australian manufactured goods but not on imported goods. This places Australian made goods at a disadvantage;
(d) Australian standards which depart unnecessarily from international standards often discourage an export orientation and possibly impose non-tariff barriers on imports.

I have raised with my State counterparts the possibility of addressing these problems through a Commonwealth/State Agreement on Standards, Accreditation and Quality. This initiative, a logical extension of the approach used in the National Preference Agreement on Government Procurement, produced a collective interest and will to succeed.

It is proposed that a draft agreement relating to these issues be brought to the next meeting of the Australian Industry and Technology Council later this year. This agreement will facilitate Australia's export prospects and contribute significantly to the overall efficiency of the Australian economy.
AUSTRALIAN MANUFACTURING COUNCIL AND INDUSTRY COUNCILS

The approach which I have indicated thus far addresses overall arrangements for standards, accreditation and quality. In order to develop arrangements which meet Australia's needs, additional measures may be required in specific areas. I shall be asking the Government's principal consultative forum on industry matters, the Australian Manufacturing Council and its associated Industry Councils, for advice on those industry specific areas where further measures are needed. The Councils will be invited to identify standards which impede export prospects and to suggest priorities for the negotiation of agreements with other countries for the reciprocal acceptance of standards. They will also be invited to indicate areas where the development of new standards would boost export prospects.
CONCLUSION

The approach I have just outlined will provide improved direction and coordination of Australia's standards, accreditation and quality infrastructure. It will encourage better use of our educational and training resources in support of industry development and, in particular, in support of industry's international competitiveness.

In the areas of standards and accreditation, the underlying infrastructure is strong. The National Association of Testing Authorities' system has served as a model for the development of similar systems in other countries. Although some aspects of the present standards system have been criticised, Australia has the potential to be among the world leaders in terms of standards-setting infrastructure. The Standards Association of Australia recently led the world in developing standards for electronic funds transfer. The Memoranda of Understanding with these associations will clearly define the Government's expectations of them.

The proposed Commonwealth/State Agreement on Standards, Accreditation and Quality will provide a mechanism for eliminating inefficiencies caused by differing Government use of standards and accreditation systems.

The measures I have announced provide an effective range of initiatives through which the introduction of quality management in industry, and the provision of trained individuals and research, will be supported.

The basic point is that a total concern for quality is essential to good business management. This Government will work to fulfil its role of providing the required infrastructure in terms of education, standards and accreditation.

However, the main responsibility lies with industry itself. A greater commitment by chief executives to quality and a recognition that everyone in the work force has a vital role to play in quality improvement is necessary if Australian industry is to increase its share of domestic and export markets. The Government will do all in its power to work in partnership with industry and the unions to achieve these goals.
Finally, Mr President I would like to place on record the Government's appreciation for the important work of the Foley Committee.
