SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has just tabled and incorporated in Hansard his response to a report which is commonly called the Foley report. It is the report of a committee established by Senator Button-the Committee of Review of Standards, Accreditation and Quality Control and Assurance-whose report is dated 26 June 1987. It was tabled on 9 October last year, and this is the Government's response to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to the title of the response: `Ministerial Statement on Standards, Accreditation and Quality'. It is simply the usual ministerial response, whereas recommendation 1 of the Committee was that the Commonwealth Government, as a matter of urgency, issue a national quality strategy statement setting out both objectives and plans for action, including a statement of policies and actions arising from the report. The Committee stated in the letter to the Minister signed by the Chairman, Dr Foley:

. . . we are firmly of the view that we have been examining an issue, or set of inextricably related issues, that are at the very core of Australia's economic problems and consequently must be central to any serious attempt to solve those problems.

Because of the Committee's view of the degree of importance of these problems, it said that, as a matter of urgency, the Government should issue a national quality strategy statement. The Government has not done that. As I have said, the Minister has simply made some sort of a response to the report.

At least I can say this about the response: it has not raised expectations that the Government has solved the problem, or indeed that it has a solution which will solve the problem. In so far as it goes, the Opposition supports the Government's response. In some areas, perhaps, it does not go far enough; but at least, as I said, it has not raised expectations that the Government is about to solve our national problems on standards, accreditation and quality control. Frankly, it is a pity that the Government has not adopted that approach in other areas in which it has raised expectations far too high. I cite, for example, the steel industry and the expectations which the Government created in regard to that industry and the results of its steel plan.

The Minister's response is not a strategy statement, but it is-and this is where it is a little disappointing-a statement of intentions, which may or may not come to something. I compare the Minister's statements that the Government will seek to do this, that the Government will look at that, that the Minister will talk to one of his colleagues, that the Minister will raise particular matters with his State counterparts, that the Minister will be asking certain people about certain things-all of those statements of future intentions-with the Committee's report on the urgency of the matter. Of particular importance-I agree with the Minister's response in this respect-is the Government's recognition that the primary responsibility for quality is with industry. I welcome the fact that the Government did not take this opportunity to establish additional statutory authorities as recommended. This is perhaps the first time since it has been in office that the Australian Labor Party has not taken the opportunity to create some statutory authority as recommended by some committee that has been established.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator, that is not true. That is churlish.
—Why is it churlish? I take it that the Minister will be able to give me examples of statutory authorities that his Government has not taken the opportunity to create.
—Certainly.

—I shall be interested to hear which ones they are, because it seems that since this Government has come to office on each occasion it has set up a committee to examine a matter the result has been the establishment of another statutory authority. In some cases it has resulted in the establishment of not one statutory authority but a number of statutory authorities which in some way or other will come to monitor, control, regulate, oversee and generally interfere with the activities of the citizens and indeed with the activities of business people in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: A consistent theme of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia has been the necessity to reduce the anti-competitive burdens on industry. The Foley report, the report of the Committee of Review of Standards, Accreditation and Quality Control and Assurance, recognises the constraints imposed by the different State government requirements. I assure Senator Button that when the Liberal and National parties get into office we will certainly act to deregulate large areas of business where this Government has not yet had the courage to do the things that this Minister from time to time says that it might get around to doing. The Government has had about seven months in which to act on a number of recommendations in this report. It is seven months since this report was tabled. The Government took a long time getting around to recognising this problem prior to Senator Button creating this Committee. Though the report has now been tabled for seven months, still the Government talks about what it will do. For example, on page 9 of his reponse to the report the Minister says:
I have raised with my State counterparts the possibility of addressing these problems through a Commonwealth/State Agreement on Standards, Accreditation and Quality.
So the Minister talks only of the possibility of those matters being addressed. Later on page 9 the Minister says:

I shall be asking the Government's principal consultative forum on industry matters, the Australian Manufacturing Council and its associated Industry Councils, for advice on those industry specific areas where further measures are needed.

So, seven months after the report was presented, the Minister is saying to the Senate that at some stage in the future he will get around to asking them for further advice. The Minister goes on to say what the councils will be invited to do in a couple of areas. I say to the Minister that frankly he should have acted on this report earlier and got on with the job. On page 5 of his response the Minister says:

My Department will, in collaboration with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, seek to establish a Key Centre of Teaching and Research on quality matters in a higher education institution.
I ask the Minister whether that is another statutory authority that he proposes to establish. It may be a non-statutory government body he is talking about. I am unsure what is proposed-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think if you read the sentence, Senator, you will recognise that yourself.

—I am unsure what is proposed to be established by a `Key Centre of teaching and research'. I suspect that it is a non-statutory body the Minister will be establishing-another means whereby the Government will be able to interfere in the activities of the companies whose main responsibility this is, as the Minister acknowledges. I turn to page 6. In the second last paragraph the Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: I will be suggesting to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that consideration be given to Australia becoming a signatory to this Code.

I would have thought that the Minister could at least have got around to talking to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) about this matter by now, seven months after the report was tabled, rather than telling us in his response that he will be getting around to talking to the Minister about it at some stage in the future. As I said, I am surprised that over seven months after receiving the report the Minister has not raised this important issue with his colleague. I question whether this is truly the Government's response or merely, as I said before, the Minister's statement of intentions. I hope that the Minister will not claim that in some way or other his response is a national quality strategy statement. It certainly does not read like that to me.

The Minister defines quality simply as meeting customer expectations. However, whilst recognising that it is partly an awareness problem, the Government then proceeds to treat quality as an abstract principle for which it can establish a key centre of teaching and research on quality matters. I suggest to the Minister that in this way the Government might very well be following a response along the wrong lines because, as the Minister said in an earlier part of his report, it is the responsibility of industry. As the Minister said in his report:

Enlightened firms now aim to `build in' quality at all stages of the production cycle-from product development and production planning to marketing and after-sales service. The whole workforce strives to achieve quality, with chief executives taking final responsibility for it.

I totally agree with that. It is very much part of the Opposition's policy in relation to industry that chief executives should be developing these approaches to their productivity. As I have done on many occasions, I refer chief executives to a small volume called Up the Organization by Robert Townsend, published in 1970. I think it was reprinted last year or the year before. It is available as a paperback. It talks about the sorts of things that I believe industry chief executives should be adopting as their principles of dealing with their work force. I say to them that when one looks at the question of developing quality in their product the first thing to develop is pride within the work force, pride in the job, pride in the company employees work for. That ultimately leads to pride in the product being produced. If our chief executive officers could encourage their work force to develop that sort of pride, quality undoubtedly would improve enormously in those companies and their profitiblity would increase as a result.

As I have acknowledged, the Minister has recognised that enlightened firms now aim to build in quality at all stages of the production cycle. Quality should be built in, not by way of some whip mechanism whereby foremen and others attempt to stand over the work force to insist upon standards of work but by way of the carrot whereby workers are encouraged, as I say, to have pride in their jobs, are given interesting jobs, are allowed to exercise their minds on the job and are allowed to take initiatives, short cuts, wherever they possibly can to achieve a particular result so that they are applying their minds to their work. If they can apply their minds to their work they will come to enjoy their work and produce a better product.

Many of the firms which successfully use quality to develop competitive advantage foster good relations with employees and encourage employee participation and shareholding. I remind the Minister that a former Liberal Government Minister, Mr Ian Macphee, was very much involved in the establishment of employee participation, both at the workplace and in shareholding, which had much to do with the current movement towards employee participation. Enlightened firms practice what the Liberal Party has been advocating for many years. Finally, I turn to the last page of Senator Button's response, in which he says:

The measures I have announced provide an effective range of initiative through which the introduction of quality management in industry, and the provision of trained individuals and research, will be supported.

I very much question that the `measures' announced in this paper will provide any such thing. The Minister goes on to say that the Government `will work to fulfil its role of providing the required infrastructure in terms of education standards and accreditation'. As I have said, it is clear to me that the whole of this paper is a statement of future intentions. I am sure that the Senate will be monitoring the activities of the Government in the future to see whether or not these intentions are fulfilled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on standards, accreditation and quality is his response to the so-called Foley report by the same name. The Minister's response spells out very clearly the direction in which this Government is taking Australia. It is one of a number of papers and statements this Government has made recently that indicate the rather disastrous direction in which this Government is taking this country. I remind the Senate that the Government has embarked on a policy of deregulating industry, banking and the currency. This has thrown Australia open to the international money markets and, extensively, to international business and competition. It praises the idea of greater international competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: A moment ago Senator Lewis said that when the Liberal Party becomes the government it will extend deregulation and the application of the philosophy of greater international competitiveness. The Government has placed an unquestioned faith in what I believe is a discredited concept of the free market-the idea that the dominance of the free market will ultimately benefit the community at large, in Australia, or the world. Again, Senator Lewis in his remarks seems to be wishing to extend this discredited concept of the operation and the benefits which flow from a free market system.

It is important here to observe that this system has produced and is producing progressively a greater discrepancy between the rich and the poor both between nations and within nations. We have more poor and we have more wealth in this country now than when the Labor Government came to office in 1983. We see on a worldwide scale increasing wealth in certain countries and increasing poverty in the majority of countries. The differences are increasing as a direct result of the economic policies being followed by both this Government and a number of governments in other countries. Nonetheless, although we have this evidence before us we see the Australian Government pig-headedly persisting with attempts to bend all forces and factors in this community to serve this internationally competitive monster ever more efficiently.

I draw attention to a recently released report of the Brundtland Commission, which was an international commission set up in the early 1980s under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister of Norway, who also happened to be the President of Socialist International. In December 1987 that Commission reported to the world under the title Our Common Future and I wish to draw a comparison between what the Brundtland Commission recognises as the global problems facing us and the rather paltry response which the Government in Australia is making which is exemplified in this ministerial statement on standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is a socialist; you just said he is.
—Precisely. Let us compare and see how well this Government is performing. The Brundtland Commission says:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a time of optimism and progress in the 1960s, when there was greater hope for a braver new world, and for progressive international ideas. Colonies blessed with natural resources were becoming nations.
But it goes on:

The present decade has been marked by a retreat from social concerns. Scientists bring to our attention urgent but complex problems bearing on our very survival: a warming globe, threats to the Earth's ozone layer, deserts consuming agricultural land. We respond by demanding more details and by assigning the problems to institutions ill equipped to cope with them. Environmental degradation, first seen as mainly a problem of the rich nations and a side effect of industrial wealth, has become a survival issue for developing nations. It is part of the downward spiral of linked ecological and economic decline in which many of the poorest nations are trapped. Despite official hope expressed on all sides, no trends identifiable today-
I stress this-
no programs or policies offer any real hope of narrowing the growing gap between rich and poor nations.

It is in the context of those remarks by this international United Nations report, Our Common Future, that I think we need to look at this Government's response to our internal economic situation and its demand that Australia become more internationally competitive. For instance, on page 9 of the Minister's statement he says:
The approach . . . will encourage better use of our educational and training resources in support of industry development and, in particular, in support of industry's international competitiveness.

That is the aim of the Government and it is an aim which undoubtedly will leave both this country poorer and most other less competitive countries. In connection with education, the Minister states on page 5:
The quality ethic is an important part of the productive culture which the Government is seeking to encourage.
He later says:
The Government is keen to provide an industry focus to developments in education.
He goes on to say:

I have drawn to the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, my view that quality management should be a priority area in the education and research system, especially in the context of the Government's Key Centres of Teaching and Research program.

I ask all people currently working in universities and other tertiary institutions around this country to note that remark and to take it in the context of the Government's Green Paper on education and to look very closely at where this Government is taking this country. The Minister goes on to say:

Key Centres provide the necessary concentration of teaching resources for undergraduate training, the opportunity for postgraduate study and research, and should help to develop close links with industry and other sectors.
He goes on:

My Department, in collaboration with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, will seek to establish a Key Centre of Teaching and Research on quality matters in a higher education institution. Any such centre would be expected to contribute to the development of education on quality in universities, institutes, CAEs, TAFE colleges and at the secondary level through, for example, the development of curriculum modules.
I take honourable senators back to the line where the Minister states:

My Department, in collaboration with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, will seek to establish a Key Centre of Teaching and Research on quality matters in a higher education institution.

Let us look at what the Minister says in relation to his definition of quality. He says that quality can be defined simply as meeting customer expectations. Taken together, that means that our tertiary institutions are to be turned into places to teach our young how better to meet customer expectations, however defined.

The perceived need for a quality program is indeed an admission of failure of the market system and the inconsistency between the extolling of market virtues and the perceived need to set up an inquiry into quality and standards and the need for the Minister to comment on those seems to have escaped both the Government and the Opposition. Let us look at the way in which the Minister defines a good example of what can be achieved. I ask honourable senators to consider the Minister's definition: quality can be defined simply as meeting customer expectations. He goes on to say on page 4 of the statement:
A good example of what can be achieved is the major quality program being introduced by the Federation of Automotive Parts Manufacturers into the automotive industry.

The point I am making concerns the contrast between the definition and the example which is given. I ask the honourable senators to consider how anybody buying a spare part for a car, such as a gear for a gearbox or a piston for an engine, could assess quality as it is defined in that second example and respond in a way which would effectively interact with the way in which the market is supposed to operate. In other words, one could make a judgment about the quality of the item being purchased and placed in one's car which in some way would be reflected back on manufacturer's through the market system so that those who manufactured poor quality pistons, or some other item about which most consumers would have very little knowledge would respond with better products. Clearly, the market system simply does not operate in the way that is so glibly talked about in this place. Feedback from customers is usually far too long for the market system to respond effectively.

I return to the point made by the Brundtland Commission. What is left out of Senator Button's statement and so many other documents from the Government is the broader context and the broad environmental-and I do not use that in a narrow sense of the natural environment-and social context in which these issues need to be addressed and the narrow context in which the environment also needs to be looked at. I pick up again the definition given on page one: `Quality can be defined simply as meeting customer expectations'. Customers need to be well informed customers if we are to advance in an objective sense towards better management of our environment.

I would like to use as an example the situation in Australia whereby for many years there have been pressures from consumer groups to get an efficiency rating on electrical appliances. This would allow customers to make a judgment as to the quality of refrigerators, heaters, electric irons, toasters and so on, in terms of their use of electricity. But the industry has consistently opposed the application of these efficiency ratings. It is a fact that some work going on in Denmark has demonstrated that it is possible to build refrigerators which use as little as 10 per cent of the energy of the domestic refrigerators currently in use in Australia. They are highly efficient instruments. I do not see anything in the Minister's statement or anything else from the Government that will bring about that sort of evolution. Yet evidence shows that our human society worldwide, as well as in this country, needs to become a great deal more energy efficient. That should be a primary objective. But the definition of quality, as narrowly defined as it is in this document, leads one to have no hope that those longer term and far more important objectives will be either sought or achieved.

Last year in this place I raised the question of the use of chlorofluorocarbons in refrigerators. Of course, that is an extremely important issue. Both the Government and the Opposition have identified it as the most important environmental issue facing the world at present. Yet there is nothing in this document relating to the quality of equipment which will use chlorofluorocarbons which would lead us to believe that this emphasis will bring about any substantial changes for the better and safer use of chlorofluorocarbons.

When we make an object in a factory, in a home workshop or anywhere else, either for ourselves or for sale to others, either in this country or overseas, we do a number of things apart from simply making the object or providing the service. There is a very important element which is left out of this document-that is, the creative satisfaction which the person gets from simply making the object or providing the service. Senator Button's statement seems to look upon workers simply as units to be manipulated-admittedly manipulated rather more efficiently to make better quality products-in the interest of exports. In mentioning exports, one might reflect upon the quality of our beef recently. Many of us were very concerned for many years about the problem of pesticides appearing in many products in Australia. No action was taken on that matter until it interfered with our exports and economic considerations brought it to the earnest consideration of a government overly concerned about economic matters.

When we make something we influence the social milieu in which it is made. We influence the health of the workers and the society. In defining health in broad terms I believe that the satisfaction which workers get from making things, from the creative activity, is a very important element. We do not find anything about that in this statement, or in anything else which this Government has written. Of course, there are environmental consequences. The use of non-renewable resources leads to their depletion and the manufacturing process, in the use of any resources, leads to pollution. Again, in the emphasis on quality in the Minister's statement he makes no mentions of those factors. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it is as though all these matters are subsumed into this concentration on very narrow economic considerations.

In summary, I believe that in speaking of quality the Government has taken an extremely narrow view. It is concerned about the quality of ball bearings and motor cars but it should be concerned primarily about the quality of people. If we give our attention first to the quality of people in this country and the quality of their lives, I believe these other matters would fall into place behind them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and express some disappointment and concern about some of the comments that have been made regarding the direction that the Government is taking. For many years in Australia in the workplace, people have looked at the end product in terms of what they require in quality. They have accepted a percentage of rejects, which is a clear waste of productivity time and a clear waste of resources. What is being sought by this move, as is contained in the paper, is to have built-in quality at all stages. If the workers have some feeling for what they are doing, they will produce a quality product, and follow that product through to completion, so that there will be no rejects.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that the tripartite committee which looked at this proposal created a proposal which could work. The workers-as is the case with management-having had a say in setting out the guidelines and structure which require them to do certain things, to attain and keep certain standards of behaviour and ability, would have an obligation to abide by those guidelines. Studies show the poor quality of some Australian goods and services is a major concern to consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly because I have only just had the opportunity to read the paper entitled `Ministerial Statement on Standards, Accreditation and Quality'. I think the paper is a lot of waffle, and I think Senator Button would agree with that. I imagine that he has brought this paper in here with tongue in cheek. The Government made the discovery that quality is defined as meeting customer expectations. That is a profound discovery after all these years. It really is, as stated in the latter part of the paper, a matter for the industry, which is made up of the management, the union, the work force and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Great emphasis is laid upon the Japanese. I think we must touch upon the Japanese, because Japan is the country that has done best over the past 15 or 20 years. When Japan started its great industrial push some 25 years ago, Japan's quality was not as good as it is today. It was simply a matter of trial and error. But probably what was more important was the effort by the whole of the Japanese community to make sure that it got it right. There was a team effort across the board. Whilst I commend the reference to the Japanese, I think it is worth pointing out that, while the Government and Senator Button apparently would commend that, it was an across the board effort.
One of the areas that this Government will not touch, will not have a bar of, is industrial relations of the type that occurs in Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would they?

—There are thousands and thousands of enterprise-based unions throughout the country and the emphasis is put on the type of product that is made and the competitive nature of the Japanese. By that I mean the ability to compete with the rest of the world. I heard an interjection from Senator Burns. He wants to have a centralised system, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This has brought this country to its knees. Surely we can learn from the success of countries such as Japan, Korea and Taiwan? If Senator Burns listens, he might learn something. It works because the people who work in that atmosphere are oriented towards their own company. They sit down and discuss with management in a positive fashion and say things such as, `How can we become more productive and how can be beat the competition?', not `How can we featherbed this and have four people doing the job of one?'. The Japanese know that if they do that, they will go out of business. It might interest Senator Burns to know that on one occasion when I visited Tokyo there was a strike at Mitsubishi Heavy Industries. It was very embarrassing for the Japanese because strikes are very rare indeed in the Japanese system. I asked why the strike was on and the answer came back, `It is embarrassing. We do not have too many industrial disputations in Japan, but the reason is that we in Mitsubishi Heavy Industries have decided to cut the working week back from six days to 5 1/2. We have had a series of warnings from the men who work for us and they are now out on strike because they believe we will lose competitiveness compared to the rest of the world'. That was the reason for the disputation.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier in my speech that I thought Senator Button had brought in this paper with tongue in cheek. I do not disagree for one minute with the aim of improving quality or with the need of this country to improve its export performance and its import replacement, particularly in respect of the manufacturing industry. But before we can get to that stage we must get other things right. I think we must look at this country compared to our competing neighbours. One of the important things about quality of production is reliability of supply. Surely that is a priority. Unless we can get reliability of supply right, we will not have much of a chance. We need only to talk to some of the more successful industries in Australia, such as the one Senator Button quotes from time to time, and quite correctly-Nucleonics Pty Ltd. Why is it so successful? One of the major reasons is that it can avoid using the ports. It does not have to pay the extortionate charges that have been put on people who wish to ship goods out of Australia. It uses Qantas and other airlines and is able to compete with other countries round the world. I think it now has about 40 per cent of the world market in pacemakers. Our ports are another weakness that has to be looked at.

One of the areas in which the Japanese are leaders in the world is packaging. We can go to other parts of Asia and see goods equally as good as or better than those of Japan, but the packaging is not as good. I have never really thought that our packaging was bad, but that is just another example.

I think the most important thing is reliability of supply, because unless we can guarantee that the customer is going to receive the goods we sell on the market, there is going to be only one sale because the next time that company will go somewhere else. This is one of the major problems we have had in Australia. Another problem is the interest rates which have to be paid in Australia and which have been imposed by this Government ever since it has been in power. They place us at a tremendous disadvantage compared with other parts of the world. Another is the cost of upgrading plant, which is such that people postpone doing so. Another is the devaluation of the dollar, which is a reflection of some of the economic policies that have been in place in Australia for many years. The punitive tax scheme is another. We have one of the highest tax regimes in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, and it is getting worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has?

—We have, Senator. There are further talks going on within the Government about taxing things such as superannuation. Four or five times in the last few days we have asked in this Parliament of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) whether the Government is going to tax the income on investment of superannuation funds. He will not give us a reply. He equivocates the whole time-another tax. We talk about improving our export performance, and the next thing that happens is that this Government says, `If you go overseas and try to entice customers by providing them with entertainment'-I might say that they do that when they come here-`it is no longer a tax deduction'. That is another disincentive to marketing goods overseas and in the import replacement area. There is a whole series of reasons why we have problems with increasing our manufacturing industry's export market and improving the level of import replacement. As I have mentioned a few times, I agree with the approach taken in the paper but it is really up to industry to take action, notwithstanding what Senator Coulter said. I think he provided us with a new discovery when he said that the situation we are in really shows the failure of the market system. I would have thought that the problems we have in Australia today show the market system at work and, unless we confront that, address it, there is no way in the world that we will get the sort of recovery that I am sure people on both sides of this House interested in the future of Australia would desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-For the benefit of anybody who might be listening, this little debate is about a statement which the Government brought down on standards, accreditation and quality in Australian industry. Senator Parer seemed to think that the debate was a suitable vehicle for discussing superannuation, which I suppose he currently regards as a hot topic; the reliability of supply; and the inability of businesses to gain tax-free entertainment entitlements, for lunches and so on. That is not what the statement is about. It is about standards, quality and accreditation. After listening to his speech, nobody would have had the slightest idea that that was what the statement was about.

SPEECH.PARA: I encountered some intellectual and philosophical problems when listening to this debate. Senator Lewis says we should leave it to the companies, to the businesses, to get on with it. One of the tragedies is that governments have done that for a very long time, and nothing has happened. That is why we are in the mess we are in today with some of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not suggesting anything. It is all waffle.

—It is easy to characterise the statement as all waffle. Anybody who read the statement with an impartial mind and then listened to the honourable senator's speech about superannuation, free lunches and things of that kind would be pardoned for drawing the conclusion that his speech was all waffle and that he had not read the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that honourable senators opposite notably failed to mention some important points in the statement. First of all, for the first time in the history of this country there has been an effort to ensure co-operative arrangements between Commonwealth and State governments on this question of uniform standards. We see that effort referred to in the statement. Senator Lewis chastises us for slowness-his was a churlish speech, I thought-but we now see that effort for the first time. For the first time in the history of this country we also see an attempt in this statement to address having a uniform quality standard for Australian companies-ISO 9000. That has never been done before. That is not a matter of leaving it to the private sector; it is a matter of getting, if you like, six or seven spheres of government operating uniformly throughout Australia so that people producing an article in South Australia do not have to produce several different versions of it-one to meet the South Australian standard, one to meet the New South Wales standard and one to meet the Queensland standard-which is an example of hitherto totally inept government interference in the affairs of the private sector.

The getting of some uniformity in relation to those standards provided by various State instrumentalities and, where appropriate, by the Commonwealth Government will relieve the productive sector of the Australian economy of a considerable burden. Those two points in the statement were not mentioned by any of the speakers who purported to have read the statement. It was disappointing that such chastisers of the government system as Senator Lewis and Senator Parer should not have thought fit to mention those very important issues raised in the statement. It is not, as Senator Parer says, a matter for the industries; it is a matter requiring an appropriate relationship between governments and industries. This statement is about securing a more appropriate relationship. I do not want to follow Senator Parer at length down the track of discussing the Japanese miracle. Certainly Japan's achievement in regard to standards and quality has been outstanding, but many things have contributed to that. Probably the greatest contribution to the Japanese miracle is the fact that Japan is a country without natural resources. All its resources are very much human resources, so the Japanese economy is totally dependent on a successful productive, manufacturing and services sector. It is in that area that resources are, of course, very important for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be tough for them.

—There is a whole range of issues, cultural and others, which have affected the phenomenally good performance of Japanese industry in relation to these matters. It is no good saying that the Japanese have devoted a lot of attention to packaging and therefore we in Australia should leave standards in relation to packaging entirely to the private sector. I think that would be a counsel of doom, looking at the performance over time of the packaging industry in Australia. It is getting better now, I hope, but trying to achieve some uniformity of approach to, and quality in, standards is of tremendous importance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter chastised me from the point of view of the moral minority. He gave us a moral minority speech, but I prefer not to take any time to discuss the economic implications of that speech. Some day somebody will write a very fat book called The Economic Implications of Senator Coulter. It will take years to read, and it will be a very gloomy book indeed. He saw fit to embark on a number of points which he saw as relevant to that question. I again remind the honourable senator that this is a limited exercise on quality and the relationship between government and the private sector on quality issues. He said that the Government had a narrow view and that it was interested in having quality ball-bearings and quality motor cars but did not offer any concern for the quality and richness of people's lives. I just want to say this to the honourable senator: the quality of their motor cars is of great concern to most citizens in this community. Very often the quality of their cars and the amounts they spend on them affect the quality of their lives, so the relationships are not quite as simple as Senator Coulter would perhaps have us wish.

Senator Coulter said that this statement regarded workers as people to be manipulated in the interests of providing quality products. I have had the advantage in the last few months of having numerous discussions with people in industry, shop stewards, workers and so on about this question of quality, and quality in the industrial process is something which can lend enrichment to the lives of those who are engaged in the production of goods in this country. They recognise that much better than Senator Coulter does, if he does not mind me saying so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of priority: which one you seek first.

—What I seek first is a situation in industry where as far as possible people have some freedom of choice about the sort of work they do, because of labour market conditions; people have some opportunities, in terms of the work they do, to make inputs into the decision-making process; and people have some opportunities in respect of the work they do to follow some sort of career path in industry. In that context, people working in industry see quality as essential to the whole productive pro- cess and not something which is attended to by some quality inspector at the end of the process. If we look at the most successful manufacturing economies, we find that those sorts of views are inherent in the nature of work in societies such as Germany and Sweden, and not much detriment flows to people in the work force from those qualities being inherent.

SPEECH.PARA: In this document, we are not talking about satisfying a domestic market. A very important point, which I made earlier, is that the adoption of the ISO 9000, an international standard for quality control, is tremendously important to the future of this country. It is not just a matter of satisfying consumers here; it is a question of satisfying consumers internationally, if we are to make the right sorts of changes, which I think all of us would wish, in the performance of Australian industry and its outward orientation. I invite honourable senators to look at the recent publication from the Australian Institute of Management. It contains a very interesting block graph which is devoted to what the Institute calls high and low achievers in exports in Australian industry. The characteristics of the low achievers are that their concentration very much is on satisfying a domestic market; they are very concerned about issues such as tariffs and a whole range of negative things which they see as threatening them and bearing down on them. The characteristics of the high achieving companies in export performance are that they have a very strong commitment to management leadership in all sorts of issues-industrial relations, quality and so on. They have a very strong commitment to research and development and to bringing the work force with them, in a sense, in terms of what they are doing in the manufacturing process.

All these things are very important and have to be referred to in any statement about quality. This statement is not intended to be the be all and end all of government attitudes to standards accreditation and quality. This has to be an ongoing process. It is no good my pretending, or any government pretending, that we can wave a magic wand about these things. We cannot just run up a flag and say, `Righto, fellows, it is quality from now on. We are all changing tonight and as from 1 March we will all be like the Japanese'. With the greatest of respect, there is not much point in any Minister or government saying that. Governments have to try to set directions in these matters and try to encourage in this case as quickly as possible the introduction of the ISO 9000 standard and try to encourage the initiatives of the Total Quality Management Institute of Australia and State governments as quickly as possible to reach agreement on uniformity in these matters and so on.

If I might say so, it is in respect of those things that this Government really has had some historic successes. It was this Government which, for the first time in the history of this country, got rid of the very debilitating State purchasing preferences which were fragmenting and ruining Australian industry is some ways, making it impossible for such considerations as the agreement on standards and quality to be pursued amongst the States. It was this Government which has pursued, and just about concluded, a national offsets agreement, replacing the fragmented policies of seven different governments. It was this Government which was successful in creating a national industry extension service, which is a co-operative effort between State and Federal governments-not the duplicating, competitive system of the past, but a co-operative effort-to provide advisory services to businesses. Each of those things, in some ways, is an enormous breakthrough in the context of a very conservative Federation such as we are.

Concerning standards, quality and accreditation of standards, we will pursue the same course. As I said a minute ago, there are no magic wands. We cannot turn the culture of an industry and the whole system around overnight. We have to do it gradually. There are phenomenal examples-I should not mention specific companies-of success in seeking and attaining these results. This has been done by a number of very important companies. Far more than anything governments or politicians can say, the demonstration effect of the success of those companies, success in terms of export performance, improved recognition of quality, work force commitment and so on, will be very important in the debate on this quality issue.

In so far as we are in a political process, let me say that I hope Senator Lewis, as is appropriate in a political process, will pursue me from time to time on the basis of this statement and say, `What has the Government done about this? How far are you getting in negotiations about these things with State governments? PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to repeal the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is, clearly, to repeal the Koongarra Project Area Act of 1981. As honourable senators will be aware, the Koongarra Project Area Act was submitted to this House on 12 June 1981-the last day on which the Government then led by Mr Fraser had the number of senators needed to force any Bill it wished through the Parliament. The Koongarra Project Area Bill was brought on with total disregard for the sections of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 which provide for at least 15 sitting days notice to both Houses of Parliament, and 60 days for public comment after publication in the Commonwealth Gazette of any intention by any government to remove land from a national park. This Parliament now has the opportunity to correct that act of piracy by repealing the Koongarra Project Area Act and thereby returning the Koongarra mining project area to stage one of the Kakadu National Park.

Honourable senators will be interested and, I am sure, relieved, to hear that section 3 of the Koongarra Project Area Act has not yet been proclaimed. Section 3 is that section of the Act which actually excises the Koongarra mining project area from the national park. It is therefore most appropriate that the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981 be repealed immediately, while its repeal is a simple and straightforward one.

In the Koongarra area as it now stands, the Australian people have an invaluable treasure-an area of unique scenic, archaeological and ecological importance. The Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry Second Report 1977-known as the Fox report-opposed the exploitation of the Koongarra deposit, and suggested that the South Alligator River catchment area was the most suitable large total river catchment for inclusion in the Kakadu National Park. Any mining at Koongarra would cause irreparable damage to the South Alligator River catchment area. The Fox Commission also pointed out that the Koongarra area is:
located upstream from the extremely valuable Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary . . . the Woolwonga area is so valuable ecologically that we would oppose in principle any mining development upstream of it.

If the Government allowed any damage to the Woolwonga area, which is now incorporated in Kakadu National Park, it would be abrogating its responsibilities under the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance and Australia's agreement with Japan for the Protection of Migratory Birds in Danger of Extinction. Even the original mining company's environmental impact statement described the Koongarra area as:

containing a most diversified range of ecosystems, wildlife, wetlands and landscape formations not found elsewhere in the continent . . . the region has a number of Aboriginal sacred areas, relics and features. The ancient Aboriginal art work found in many of the caves and galleries of the rock outcrops has no equivalent in Australia.

Indeed, the archaeological value of the prehistoric sites of Kakadu National Park, of which Nourlangie Rock is one of the most important, is massive. In a report on archaeological research in Kakadu National Park, leading Australian archaeologist, Dr Rhys Jones, and Tia Negerevich wrote:

Along the base of the great cliffs . . . are rock shelters which constitute one of the world's most important storehouses of information about the prehistory and the art of hunting and gathering man. In terms of the number and age of occupied rock shelters, and the staggering profusion and antiquity of the brilliant rock art sites, the Kakadu area can be compared with some of the classic archaeological locations of the world.

. . . in Kakadu, the Aboriginal owners are the direct descendants of the people who lived in the rock shelters and who painted the art . . . The conjunction of living Aboriginal traditions, and extremely diverse and rich landscape and the wealth of archaeological sites, some with proven antiquity back to 23,000 years ago, makes the Kakadu a key zone for research into the prehistory of Australia.

The writers liken the importance of the Kakadu sites to the Dordogne cave paintings in France, with the added factor of the direct descent of the traditional owners from the inhabitants of the area over 23,000 years ago.

The unique beauty of the Koongarra area, including Nourlangie Rock, the South Alligator River catchment area and the Nourlangie Creek catchment area, would be destroyed forever if mining were allowed to take place at Koongarra. Explosions from a mine site there might cause falls or slides of segments of Nourlangie Rock itself-one of the most significant archaeological sites in Australia. There would be a significant increase of dust in the atmosphere, and that, as well as other adverse ecological effects of such a mine would cause direct degradation of the archaeological sites, as well as the indirect degradation caused by scars on the landscape from roads to the mining area, noise and air pollution, and pollution of the water table. None of this must be allowed to occur. With the repeal of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981, the area will be returned to its rightful place in Kakadu National Park. The area is of such obvious international significance that I am sure its inclusion in the World Heritage listing for Kakadu National Park Stage One would be merely a formality.

I remember reading with great interest the very strong views put forward in this place in June 1981 by Australian Labor Party (ALP) senators when the original Bill was brought on. They were horrified that such a unique area should be excised from a national park so it could be destroyed in the commercial interests of a mining company-and a Canadian-owned mining company at that. On that occasion all Labor senators joined with the Australian Democrats to vote against the Bill. I am sure, with the Prime Minister and the ALP speaking so strongly against any new mining in this area, the Government will be consistent in its attitude, and will join with us once again on this issue to replace this beautiful area in the middle of Kakadu National Park and preserve it for future generations to enjoy and to wonder at.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and I look forward to its speedy passage through both Houses.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Defence Act 1903 to provide for Parliamentary approval for overseas service by members of the Defence Force.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to place the responsibility for the decision to send Australian troops overseas with both Houses of Federal Parliament subject to exceptions covering the movement of personnel in the normal course of their peacetime activities and the need to take swift action in an emergency. In an emergency, the Governor-General may require Defence Force personnel to serve outside Australia's territorial limits, provided the Government then obtains parliamentary approval within two days.

The Bill excludes overseas service by members of the Defence Force pursuant to their temporary attachment as provided in section 116b of the Defence Act; as part of an Australian diplomatic or consular mission; on an Australian vessel or aircraft not engaged in hostilities or in operations during which hostilities are likely to occur; for the purpose of their education or training; and for purposes related to the procurement of equipment or stores.

The provision for parliamentary approval of overseas service of troops applies in other countries. In Canada, the Governor-in-Council may deploy troops anywhere, any time, subject to Parliament meeting within 10 days to approve action taken. In the Federal Republic of Germany there are limitations: there is constitutional prohibition against German forces participating in a war of aggression. Participation in a collective military action for the preservation of peace is permissible only if that force is deployed in a situation which, at that time, represents an illegal attack on the Bundesrepublik. In Japan, the 1947 Constitution of Japan, in article 9, provides:
. . . the Japanese people forever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation . . .

The Self Defence Forces are authorised to protect the peace and stability of Japan against direct and indirect aggression. Self Defence Force personnel may not be deployed outside Japan. This has been interpreted by successive governments as precluding participation in United Nations peace-keeping and observation teams.

One of the most divisive issues that has ever oppressed our history occurred between 1962 and 1971 when some 50,000 Australian servicemen from all three services were engaged in the war in Vietnam, the result of which was a communist government for the whole of Vietnam. The hostilities almost certainly resulted also in the later destruction of the free governments in neighbouring Cambodia and Laos and the incorporation of all of what was once French Indochina into the communist state. During that decade of war, 500 members of the Australian forces were killed. Of those deaths, 187 were young men who had no choice as to this tragic early end to their lives because they were conscripts sent to fight in an unjustifiable and unwinnable foreign adventure which, judged by any standard, was a disaster, and which, far from deterring the spread of communism in Asia, actually contributed significantly to it. As well as those deaths, many more young Australians were injured-nearly 3,000 of them. Of these, more than 1,000 were conscripts.

All this came about as a result of a decision taken to involve Australia in a war without the proper consultation of its people and of its Parliament. In view of this, it is worth looking at the origins of the Vietnam War. There are several versions of how Australia was inveigled into supporting the United States in that tragic and wasteful episode. For many years it was stated officially that Australia was there in answer to a call for help from the Government of South Vietnam. That story is now, of course, completely discredited. Papers released in the United States as a result of the effective freedom of information law there indicated that the United States wanted Australia and other countries involved in that war so the United States would not be seen to be acting alone. That was the motivation; that was why Australia was there.

What are the motivations of government, the pressures on it to conceal and dissimulate? A nation which cannot learn from the lessons of history has no future. We must look at the history of the Vietnam War to see what we can learn from it. Australian involvement in that war before it ended was opposed by the majority of Australians. It was passionately and actively opposed by scores of thousands. It became a deeply divisive issue in our community, and we still bear the scars of it.

If this Bill is passed, it will at least ensure a full debate on any such move in both Houses of Federal Parliament, with a subsequent vote of all our elected Federal representatives. This must, as it does in other countries, lead to a more reasoned basis for sending Defence Force personnel overseas. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Support Bill 1987 is the first in a series of Bills to reform the collection of maintenance from the parents of children. There is a desperate need for such a Bill. We on this side of the chamber acknowledge the need for that Bill and we support it, with a second reading motion amendment. We have believed for many years that change was needed in this area. The Government members, on the other side of this chamber, have consistently rejected the changes we have put forward. They have consistently turned their backs on the desperate situation that children of parents who do not live together find themselves in. We can ask ourselves why they have done this. The only credible answer that we can come up with is that there is no political kudos for this Government in accepting that since 1982 this side of the chamber has been in touch with community needs and that the Government side of the chamber is out of touch. That could not have been more perfectly demonstrated than in the by-election for the Federal seat of Adelaide held recently, with enormous swings against the Government clearly indicating that what we have believed for a long time is true-that this Government is out of touch.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, in 1988, in the autumn session of Parliament, this Government is introducing legislation which, as I understand it, it originally intended to introduce in the autumn session last year. The paper entitled Child Support-A Discussion Paper on Child Maintenance was released in October 1986. In the early part of the following year legislation was to come forward, but the legislation missed that session. It then missed the Budget session of 1987 and made it into this one, at last. The delay is typical of a government that blows its trumpet about ideas but lacks the administrative skill to implement them.

When I say that we on this side of the chamber have understood for some time the desperate plight of the children of parents who no longer live together I am not simply referring to the fact that we have understood that plight since 1986 when the Government came up with the preliminaries of this proposal. Those people who care to turn their minds and eyes back to September 1983 and look at the Hansard of that year recording discussion on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 will see that Senators Chaney and Durack have acknowledged, since 1982, and perhaps even before that, the desperate need for something to be done to reform the maintenance collection system throughout Australia. One of the sorest points in the community is that the children of separated parents are clearly not receiving adequate maintenance. The Fraser Government had intended, if it was returned to office, to address that problem. The new Labor Government, elected in March 1983, rejected those ideas. Half a decade has gone by in which Labor has consistently ignored the problems of the children of separated parents. Many thousands of couples have separated in that time without the benefit of the changes that, had we remained in office, would have been implemented.

Honourable senators on this side of the chamber know how many times and for how long Senator Durack tried to improve the situation of separating custodial parents. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber know what Labor has consistently done to his proposals. It has consistently rejected them. As I say, one of the reasons is that the Government is not politically broad-minded enough to acknowledge that when a good idea that will benefit the children of separated parents comes from the Opposition it should accept it.

A point used by the Government in favour of ignoring the problems of these children is that it was all very well for Senator Durack to have these ideas but the Government had greater plans which would be revealed later. Changes to the maintenance collection system were to be included in that legislation, that is, this legislation which has just been introduced. Even Marie Antoinette, so out of touch with the people, when told that the peasants were starving, that there was not any bread and that she was disregarding the needs of her constituents, was prepared at least to let them have cake. She at least had some positive intentions. But this Government does not even offer any cake in the meantime. It just says, `Let them wait'. At least Marie Antoinette was prepared to offer something. But not this lot. The Government says, `Let them wait until we sort out our administrative act and then perhaps we will do something about the collection of maintenance for the children of separated parents'.

I have referred in my remarks thus far to the out of touch aspect of this Government. The arrogant Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we have does not accept that he is out of touch; he does not even accept that he is arrogant. To back up that point I refer to an article in the Australian of 10 February in which Paul Kelly said:

Let's talk about style though. For instance, a number of comments have been made about you as a result of the by-election defeat. People say you're arrogant, the Government is too arrogant, there needs to be more dialogue. What is your response to this sort of thing?

That was Mr Kelly asking the Prime Minister after a devastating by-election loss whether there is a possibility that he and his Government have become arrogant and out of touch. The Prime Minister's response is as follows:

I repudiate any suggestion of arrogance. I mean, arrogance is not my nature. I have been on the public stage for a long time. I'm confident but arrogance-I am not an arrogant fellow. I think I'm right about issues.

I think the Prime Minister said it in his own words: that he does think he is right all the time and he does not think he is arrogant and he does not think his Government is out of touch. But if we turn to reports of a meeting that the Prime Minister had with some pensioners we see that when it was put to the pensioners outside Parliament House who had come on buses from various country areas of New South Wales that they were better off under the Hawke Labor Government than they were under the Fraser Government, the booed and hissed the Prime Minister. No-one likes to be booed and hissed-I accept that-but the report says:
Even Mr Hawke found it necessary to refer to their ``empty boos and hisses''. He said . . . ``If you want to deride and pour contempt on your fellow pensioners, that's your right.''

What an arrogant way to handle the concerns of pensioners who come before him. One of the pensioners, a 76-year old, Mr Fred Diamond, from the Sydney seaside suburb of Manly, said that the Prime Minister was `Bluff and incorrect'. He said:
We have lost between 25 and 30 per cent of purchasing power in the past few years.

That should indicate at least some of the concern that this Government should now have with whether it is in touch and whether it has become an arrogant government. The Child Support Bill 1987, dealing with a reform of the maintenance collection system, provides an opportunity for a discussion of families and children in general and necessarily raises the Prime Minister's promise set in the election in 1987 when he said:
So we set ourselves this first goal, by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.
Mr Mick Young, the retired member for Port Adelaide--

TALK.START.PARA: —Retired hurt member for Port Adelaide.
—The retired hurt, spit out dummy, I suppose, member for Port Adelaide, said in response to the question of whether it was possible to achieve this promise:

SPEECH.PARA: It becomes, well I think when you're saying every single child, you know, if you're going to go around and take a census on it whether every single child is going to be out of poverty, of course you're talking about an impossibility.

That is an indication again of what this Government thinks about and how much it cares about children in the community. It is prepared to make rash promises, promises that its own then Ministers agreed could not be fulfilled. The intention is laudable but to overstate the capacity to fulfil that intention is not laudable; it is quite the opposite. we on this side of the chamber all remember the 1985 announcement of Priority One: Young Australia which related to the setting up of traineeships for young Australians, who are members of families. We remember the Prime Minister saying that in the bicentennial year-that is this year-there would be 70,000 traineeships per annum. That is just another example of how Australians have been let down by the overstated promises of this Government. A viewing of the Budget Papers will show that even the Government now admits that in the bicentennial year there is not the slightest hope of getting anything like 70,000 trainees. The target is, I think, less than 15,000.

The statistics that can be produced by the Parliamentary Library and looked up by anybody in the wide variety of welfare information that is made available can tell us the numbers of single parent beneficiaries, very largely made up of separated custodial parents. Statistics, however, are very impersonal indicators. They give no indication of the depth of suffering felt by the single parent beneficiaries who are custodial parents; they are simply signposts on a highway, some sort of indication of where we are going. The Government acknowledged in 1986 that we were going the wrong way. Now, in 1988, we have the legislation to do something about that.

The complaint that I am making at the commencement of this debate is that we say it is far too long to wait; it should have been done earlier. We are pleased that the reforms are here. The reforms put forward by Senator Durack, the opportunities to improve the position of children of separated couples, should have been taken up. Members on the other side of the chamber offered no good reason why those reforms were not taken up. While those reforms might not have been part of a grand plan, they would, at least, have been proceeded with and at least some children would have been the recipients of the beneficial consequences of those reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very few.

—I hear some senators on the other side saying `very few', as though to say that very few people have separated in the last two years and very few children would have benefited from the results of Senator Durack's change. I remind those honourable senators opposite they will have their opportunity to speak and they can take it when it comes. There is a growing publicised resentment in the community in relation to the spiralling of the welfare dollar. Frequently the resentment is expressed by people who would not in principle refuse to pay welfare to anyone in need. The resentment is an expression of sheer inability to cope with rising family expenses and frustration at the level of taxation imposed by this Government. It is frustration with Labor's mismanagement, with people being worse off, that occasions people feeling that level of frustration to look around at how they can relieve their burden in some way. In other words, the frustration is vented by negative remarks towards welfare recipients. It is my belief and my hope that it is not indicative of a policy decision on behalf of those people to leave people in need without assistance; it is simply an absolute cry for help from the burden of the Government's ineptitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, there is a section of people in the community who believe and promulgate the view as widely as they can that young women have babies to get the supporting parent benefit and that they as taxpayers are somehow paying for the indulgence of young women. I invite members of the community who have that view to cast their eyes over the available statistics. They will note that only 4 per cent of supporting parents are teenagers. That should at least give them some indication about what I think about that view. The concept that a woman would have a child simply to get some welfare payment is far too simplistic and unacceptable. A further portion of people regard welfare recipients as the undeserving poor, and regrettably all of us in this chamber on both sides have met with some people who believe that. There has been a degree of selective welfare bashing. People have picked out supporting parents as the people who ought to be bashed, as the welfare group to have a go at. I point out that, unless there has been something in the nature of an immaculate conception, or many thousands thereof, there are no sole parents.

The people we call sole parents fall into two categories. A small proportion of them may be surviving parents; that is, the other parent has died. But generally there are two living parents, one forced onto welfare, battling to raise children in difficult circumstances created by this Government, and the other in 70 per cent of cases, departing the scene and failing properly to meet his or-I suppose sometimes-her maintenance obligations. Non-custodial parents are ignoring their responsibilities. Therefore, we have more supporting parent beneficiaries. This Government has failed to make parents face up to the responsibilities they have created. Ian Warden, a columnist with the Canberra Times whom I believe to be a talented wordsmith, frequently makes a point, sometimes by vitriol, sometimes in jest. He did so in the Canberra Times on 19 February. In reporting this debate he said:
But to return to the wart in question, the aforementioned debate-
that is, the debate on this Bill-

has yielded the information that seven out of every 10 Australians required to pay maintenance to keep the wolverine from the door of the children they chose to usher into the world failed to do so. Seven out of 10.

Is it worth celebrating a society which has somehow created a species of parent so estranged from feelings of shame and guilt . . . that they are able to ogle themselves in the mirror in the mornings while knowing that their blameless children are suffering . . .

He goes on to amplify the Labor Government's failure to make parents face up to the responsibility that they, as parents, have created; the Labor Government's failure to remedy the system which can be fairly described as one which encourages women to be locked into welfare; its failure to remedy a system which encourages the courts to put predominantly women on welfare; its failure to remedy a situation which has allowed parents in the past to take on extra financial commitments after separation but prior to the custody and maintenance hearings, thereby reducing their capacity to pay for the children that they created; its failure to accept that it is out of touch; and its failure to accept the positive proposals put forward by Senator Durack which could have been implemented a long time ago to save many from falling into the welfare trap.

With the passage of this Bill, in future non-custodial parents will pay their maintenance to the agency created by this legislation. In many cases it will simply be taken out of their salary and transferred. The Opposition is concerned that the burden on business in this respect ought to be kept to a minimum. Consultations that we have had with members of the business community have indicated that the consultation on this point has been inadequate. We draw to the Government's attention that concern of the business community that has been expressed to us and hope that that concern is addressed in the implementation of this Bill.

The purpose of this Bill is to assist children-not to punish parents for their relationship having failed, but to make it clear that, when a relationship does fail, we expect both parties to be responsible for the children that they have created; to make it clear that it is completely unacceptable for custodial parents to be left out in the cold, their partners giving them little or no support; and to make it clear that the community does not blame sole parents for their plight, but blames the irresponsible non-custodial parents who are ignoring their responsibilities. I repeat that figures indicate that 70 per cent of people who should be paying maintenance are paying none or not enough. The support for this Bill makes it clear that for too long when couples separate it is the custodial parent whose standard of living takes a far bigger fall than that of the non-custodial parent, who is of course usually the father. It seems odd that for so long we have tolerated a situation where the parent with responsibility for the children is worse off than the parent who is not.

It is unfortunate that this Government has taken so long to acknowledge the merits of Senator Durack's proposed amendments to the Family Law Act which, if the Government had accepted them at the time, would have improved the situation of many supporting parents and their children in that they would have been beneficiaries years earlier. I am referring here to the amendments that removed the priority given to consideration of the supporting parent's benefit and proposed to change the arrangements for people who sought to minimise the maintenance payments they made by taking on financial obligations.

In summary, the Opposition supports the Bill. It very deeply resents the fact that the Government has taken so long to get its act together. It is all very well to say, `Now we have this agency established'. As I pointed out, this is the first Bill in a series of Bills. It deals only with the agency. We have a lot further to go. But at least this Bill will mean that the children of separated parents will receive far better maintenance then they have for many years. However, we do have a concern that the couples who are not seeking to place any drain on the taxpayer and who are happy to keep their arrangements in order ought not to be covered by this particular piece of legislation. Accordingly, we wish to move a second reading amendment. We believe that, if couples separate, come to a suitable agreement and agree that they would rather handle their affairs privately, they ought to be able to do so. They ought not to lose their privacy unless they wish to claim from the taxpayer or the non-custodial parent defaults. This view is expressed in the following amendment. I move:
At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate-

(a) wishes to ensure the protection of the rights of non-custodial parents who have entered into maintenance arrangements to share in the cost of supporting their children at no extra cost to the Commonwealth, by not requiring these agreements to be registered with the Child Support Agency, except in the event that maintenance arrangements are not honoured, and
(b) condemns the fact that the welfare of Australian children has rapidly declined under the Hawke Labor Government''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak in support of the Child Support Bill 1987. In my opening comments I would like to put on the record that I welcome the Opposition's support for the Child Support Bill. It is unfortunate though that Senator Vanstone, in leading the debate for the Opposition, did not confine her remarks to the Bill that is before us. I think Senator Vanstone could be safely accused of attempting to score some cheap political points over a by-election result we recently had in Adelaide. In trying to score those points she made the point that the other side of the chamber had been in touch with the people and that this side of the chamber had lost touch with the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Vanstone and other honourable senators on the other side of the chamber that since 1982 the Opposition parties have lost about 14 out of 18 elections held in this country. Those figures may not be exact, but I know that, at the Commonwealth level, when they went to the people with their policies they lost in 1983, in 1984 and again in 1987. If they can take comfort from just one aberration, one by-election, it will probably do them good, because they need something to shake them up. They might perform the role which they are here to perform-to provide opposition to the Government. I have said in the past that one of the things a party needs when it is in government is to be put under pressure from time to time. It is a sad reflection on honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber that they have not been doing that. They have been too concerned with their internal fighting between parties and inside parties to concentrate on putting pressure on the Government.

I would now like to speak specifically on the Bill. Prior to doing so, I want to paint a broader picture into which this Bill fits quite neatly. This Bill is the result of widespread and much needed consultation throughout the community, consultation in which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his departmental staff participated. The consultation has spread beyond that; it has spread right through the system of Caucus committees that we have operating in the Parliament, with the members of Parliament themselves discussing within the community the ramifications of a Bill such as this. Needless to say, there will be sections of the community that will not be at all happy with what is being proposed in the Bill, and I think all sides of the chamber will agree that certain people will be upset. Through the series of consultations we have sought to find the best medium to introduce the initiatives we are putting forward in this legislation.
