To take the point that Senator Vanstone made, this legislation is not to be seen in isolation. A number of other complementary pieces of legislation will need to come before us to put the whole package into perspective. It is not to be seen in isolation from other Government initiatives in this area. The family allowance supplement, increased funding for education and restructuring in the area of education, employment and training programs for sole parents fit quite neatly into what we are proposing here.

The child support scheme is an integral part of a resolution passed at the Australian Labor Party's national conference in 1986, accepting the case for the adoption of a national social justice strategy. The social justice strategy had four key objectives. Those were equity, equality, access and participation. Equity encompasses the notion of fairness for all in the distribution of economic resources and political power. Equality means the equality of rights for all people. Access means access to essential services, which include housing, health and education, on a fair and equal basis. Participation means giving all Australians the opportunity to participate fully in personal development, social and community life and decision-making.

The Government had made significant advances in the achievement of the social justice objectives, especially when we consider them in the context of the previous seven destructive years of the Fraser Government. I have already said, and it is worth repeating, that this has lead to increased social security benefits, increased spending on housing and increased spending on child-care, education, employment and training. We have not got it all right. Economic difficulties have ensured that we have not been able to move at the pace we would have liked. Hardship, inequality and injustice still persist in our society. The basis of the social justice strategy is the need to attack the causes of inequality and not merely to remedy the effects. The social justice strategy is an attempt to change social structures and attitudes that institutionalise inequity in the distribution of economic and social resources.

One of the key issues the conference identified as an integral part of the implementation of its social justice strategy was that concerning all children living in poverty. The child support scheme is an essential component of the Government's strategy to alleviate the social tragedy, and a tragedy it is. During his last Federal election policy speech, Mr Hawke, the leader of the Australian Labor Party, made a promise that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty. Both he and the Australian Labor Party were maligned by sections of the Australian community for making that promise. It was said by people on the Opposition benches that we could not deliver. Here is yet another component in the delivery of that promise.

To ensure that the commitment that was made prior to the election was kept, the Caucus of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, at its first meeting following our historic election victory for a third term-and indeed it was an historic occasion not only for those of us who participated in that election but also for the Australian population as a whole-carried by an overwhelming vote the following motion:

Caucus welcomes and unites behind the Prime Minister's stated first goal of the third Hawke Labor Government announced in the campaign policy launch that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

That was the promise. It has been reaffirmed and now we have the delivery. The passage of the Child Support Bill is undoubted because of the support which we are receiving from all sides of the chamber and which we received in the other place, and it is certainly needed in our community.

Over half of the Australian children living in poverty, some 800,000-and that is not a figure we are proud of; indeed we do not accept all of the blame for the fact that there are today 800,000 children in this country living in poverty-are the children of sole parents, the majority of whom are women who for the most part have had to rely solely on social security pensions and benefits to support those children. In the last 10 years the proportion of sole parents on a pension or benefit has increased from 65 per cent to 85 per cent. The consequences of this for these families is a continuing cycle of poverty traps.

Even in those families where the non-custodial parent does not pay regular maintenance to support his or her children, and they are some 30 per cent, the maintenance orders set by the courts are generally so low-they average about $25 a week for one child or $40 a week for two children; some people are getting off with paying a lot less and obviously some are paying slightly more-that most custodial parents receiving regular maintenance still need to seek social security assistance. Of the non-custodial parents who do make regular maintenance payments, more than 70 per cent pay very little and more often than not pay nothing to support their families. This legislation will redress that problem and will put the onus for the welfare and future of their children back on those parents. Unfortunately the resources the Government has at its disposal to alleviate the tragedy of children living in poverty in sole-parent families are finite. There are limitations to the amounts governments can spend, thus the imperative need to introduce this Bill being discussed here is immediately obvious. I repeat that I welcome the support we are getting from the Opposition benches.

It is a national scandal that so many non-custodial parents are able, and have been able for so long, to escape their obligations. The consequences of their actions, while they might be living in cream, are twofold: their children have little possibility of escaping from the trap of poverty and they are tossing the burden for those children's support onto the ordinary taxpayers of this nation. From the figures I quoted earlier, this burden has obviously increased enormously over the years. The cost of supporting sole-parent families in the 1986-87 Budget was $1,886m. I repeat that figure because it is well worth repeating-$1,886m. That is money that comes from the pockets of the ordinary wage and salary earner in this country.

In the vast majority of cases the non-custodial parents are employed and hence are able to contribute to their children's support, and yet are making no attempt to accept the responsibility for the children of a relationship that they have abandoned for whatever reason. Rather, they have abrogated the responsibility of supporting their children, placing that responsibility onto the shoulders of all Australian taxpayers. In many cases the children are left in a state of perpetual poverty.

This legislation will increase substantially the numbers of sole parent families who receive regular child maintenance payments. It will assist in ensuring that court orders for child maintenance are enforced and obeyed. It will provide for more adequate levels of maintenance payments to be set in court maintenance orders after the start of the scheme by setting realistic levels of support, rather than maintenance at a maximum allowable, without affecting the custodial parent's right to a full social security benefit or pension. A survey of Department of Social Security regional office files, published in the Social Security Journal in the winter of 1987, found that levels of cash maintenance were usually set below the free area of income and were very rarely increased. The legislation will also relieve the burden on ordinary taxpayers by ensuring that non-custodial parents accept a fair share of the financial responsibility for their children.

In the first full year of the scheme's operation, 1989-90, savings to the ordinary taxpayer, to government revenue, are estimated to be $192.8m. That is $192.8m which can be diverted to other areas of the Government's social justice program-areas which can, and will, include further employment and training initiatives for sole parents.

The Opposition has made some criticisms of the Bill, and some of them have been nitpicking or have been made in an attempt to point score now that some of the States are in an election mode. The point was made in the other place, and here again by Senator Vanstone, that the scheme is compulsory. The Opposition has moved an amendment in this regard. The scheme has to be compulsory to be effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it doesn't, Senator.

—We on this side of the chamber believe it does. If we leave too many holes in the scheme, it will be exploited. The best way of ensuring that the sole parent is left in a non-confrontation position is to have such a scheme. In many cases the non-custodial parent is not making a contribution because the custodial parent is scared to make an approach. If the payments are handled by the agency, it should alleviate that potential difficulty. Experience up until now has shown that when maintenance payments have been left effectively to the discretion of the non-custodial parent, only 30 per cent of such parents have exercised the option to make such payments. Further, the amounts these parents pay have been hopelessly inadequate and bear no relationship to the cost of rearing children. We all know that that can be mightily expensive these days.

SPEECH.PARA: Some concern was expressed about the privacy provisions in the legislation. It is not the intention of this Government, nor indeed the departments that will administer this legislation, to seek out and delve into the private lives of individuals. There is provision in the Bill for the privacy of the individuals involved to be protected at all costs. I believe that the Australian society is more concerned about the welfare of the children of sole parents than it is about attaching stigmas to non-custodial parents who will be required to pay maintenance through this scheme, especially given the large number of non-custodial parents who will be required to register with the child support agency.

Marital breakdown can sometimes be a tragedy for the children involved. Whilst this Bill does not seek to stop the breakdown of marriages, it does seek to ensure that parents accept responsibility for their children. I believe the child support scheme will do this, and that it is a major initiative towards realising the Government's objective of alleviating child poverty by 1990. I put on record my congratulations to the Minister for Social Security for his hard work in guiding this legislation through a long and arduous period of consultation-consultation I alluded to when opening my remarks this afternoon-and for having the courage and determination to tackle the problem head on and place the issue of child poverty at the forefront of the Government's social policy agenda. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I support the Child Support Bill 1987, which, as previous speakers have said, is landmark legislation and the first Bill of a package designed to address the problems of children of separated couples-problems which manifest themselves in all too many cases in children living in poverty, along with their custodial parent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides for the collection of certain periodic child and spousal maintenance, which is payable under court orders and maintenance agreements. To do that the Bill sets up mechanisms such as the Child Support Register, the Child Support Registrar and a system of periodic collections. I make that point because Senator Vanstone, in concluding her remarks, said that all that this legislation is doing is establishing a child support agency. I believe it does more than that, and I think these are essential elements to be recognised because, after all, if we are to address the problems of children of separated couples who are living in poverty the essential feature is the collection of maintenance which, as we have already heard in the debate, does not happen in 70 per cent of cases. That is a rather horrific figure.

Over recent times the number of children living in single parent families has increased vastly, rising by 73 per cent in the period 1974 to 1985. The figure is now close to 500,000 children. In the mid-1970s, 9 per cent of all families were single parent families, and now the figure is 14 per cent. The proportion of sole parents dependent on support payments-on the ordinary Australian taxpayer, as Senator McKiernan said-has risen from 65 per cent to 85 per cent, and most of these families, as has been pointed out, are headed by women. The figure which concerns many people and has meant that we finally have legislation in this area is the figure that indicates that expenditure in this area has risen by some 245 per cent in the period 1974 to 1986, and of course because of the situation we do have a large number of children living in poverty. As I have said, this is largely because of the failure of the non-custodial parents to pay maintenance.

Perhaps it is worth noting that even where maintenance is paid-that is, in only 30 per cent of the cases of family breakdown-it is a low amount, and the Department of Social Security figures tell us that the amount is mostly between $10 and $30 a week. Two-thirds of all payments are less than $31 a week, and yet figures from the Institute of Family Studies show that we should be looking at an average figure of around $47 a week to keep a child. Of course, that figure varies according to the age of the child, and it should be noted that the older the child the more expensive it becomes. The situation has not been meeting the need and has forced many sole parent families into quite abysmal poverty-and it is happening to more and more of them over time. So we are happy to see at least the beginning, and a very significant beginning, of the addressing of that problem.

It is worth making some comments on the rate of marriage breakdown in that period. The number of separated wives in the period of 1974 to currently has risen from 9,000 to over 100,000. This is an enormously distressing figure. Some say that the fault all lies with changes to the Family Law Act and, most significantly, to the requirement for only one year of separation before divorce. But I do not believe that we can condemn the Family Law Act, nor that more liberal provision, for this increasing figure. The establishment of the Family Law Act, as it is now, has enabled particularly very many women to more readily get out of situations which have been emotionally, if not physically, damaging, not only for them, but also for their children.

It is important to look at the whole issue. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in response to an accusation in the second reading debate that there had been cuts in funding for marriage guidance, denied that. But there have not been the sorts of rises in funding for preventive measures which obviously are necessary to assist people in the community who are taking on the responsibility of marriage in particular, and of parenting specifically, to be able to do that with some community support and understanding of what they are taking on. Dr Warwick Hartin, Secretary of the National Marriage Guidance Council, said in an article in the Melbourne Sun last year:
This year the government will spend a miserable $5.1 million in grants to marriage counselling organisations but it will spend a massive $1.5 billion on divorce and its consequences.
He went on to say:
The Government has not learned money spent on the prevention of marriage breakdown is money saved in payments disrupted by divorce.

It is worth considering that there is a role for preventive exercises and certainly for the Marriage Guidance Council. It was rather distressing last year to have to put up a fight for the continuation of the family conciliation centre in Noble Park in Melbourne and to find that the other pilot program in New South Wales was not refunded. The Government needs to address these issues.

In our community now we are not saying to women that they must stay in unsatisfactory or, indeed, dangerous relationships. In view of that, we should recognise that this very changed nature of human relationships-one which I applaud and which the Democrats fully understand and do not condemn-means we need to assist all people, men and women and, in particular, young people while they are forming their views. Democrat policy of long standing involves support for education for parenting and education in human relationships generally. Those factors need to be taken into consideration in terms of preventing the sort of horrific poverty, distress and expenditure which we now find before us, given the rate of family breakdown. We must not ignore the fact that family breakdown brings its problems for men. This whole exercise of prevention and community support for people undertaking relationships will be of benefit not only to those women who quite visibly are disadvantaged in this whole exercise, but also to men.

It is interesting that only on Friday last, the day this Bill was due to be debated, a major article in the Australian pointed out several very interesting facts about male parenting, and, in particular, male sole parenting. It said that the incidence of children remaining with their fathers after family breakdown is increasing. According to the Institute of Family Studies, single father-headed families represent 13 per cent of all one-parent families. It is becoming more usual for the Family Court of Australia to give custody of children to their male parents. The question is asked in this article by Berwyn Lewis:
Will the increase in single fathers mean extended shopping hours, more child-minding facilities and will paternity leave become the rule rather than the exception?

I certainly commend this article to members of the Senate because it gives a clear picture of some of the changes in attitudes that exist because of the increased incidence of male parenting in sole-parent families. The particular point is made that the average Australian father is said to spend 30 minutes a day with his children-so these are quite exceptional fathers. I will go on to detail some of these facts. While female parents are those who, in the breakdown of a relationship, most commonly are recognised to have suffered, because it is clear that their economic situation suffers severely, we must not lose sight of the other research which shows that in a family breakdown, whether or not the male parent becomes a custodial parent, there is an enormous amount of emotional distress for men. We must not ignore that fact in this kind of debate.

Anything that can be done to enable relationships to survive is worth doing and anything that can be done to assist and provide community support is worth doing, not just for women, but also for men. However, we cannot escape the fact that the majority of affected children that we are talking about are living in single-parent families with their mothers and, as I have said, the economic effect on women is quite severe. As I understand it, the following figures are from the Institute of Family Studies. They are quite clear. After divorce, men who are living alone are, on average, $72 a week better off than women in that situation. Men who subsequently have custody of a child are $60 a week better off, even though they have custody. Men who have repartnered and have no further children in the new partnership are $149 a week better off. Of course there are reasons for this. We must not forget the inherent disadvantages that still exist in our community for women who need or want to be in the paid work force. If any women need to be in the paid work force, sole supporting parents who are women are the ones.

Let us make no mistake: most people on pensions or benefits of any kind, the young unemployed included, want very much to work to earn their own living and have their independence. Let us also make no mistake: the only real way out of poverty, in spite of what we might do here in this Parliament, for people who are on pensions and benefits, is for them to enter or re-enter the paid work force. But when women do that, if they do get off benefits they are still disadvantaged. Women are still clustered in low-paying jobs and, on average, still do not receive anywhere near the male average wage. The last figures I saw were in the high 60 per cents. There is still the impediment, particularly for women about whom we are speaking specifically today, of a lack of child-care facilities. This Government makes great moment of its goals and achievements in child-care. I think child-care is the biggest issue that we face in terms of equity, participation and access, particularly for women but also for men. Let us bear in mind the increasing proportion of male sole parents. Child-care must be flexible, it must be available and it must be affordable. Inflexibility and unavailability are also problems for women when it comes to attempting to enter or re-enter the paid work force by training or retraining.

Since the demise of the class B widow's pension and the reduction last year in the availability of sole parent's benefit beyond the dependent child reaching the age of 16, I have had a flood of letters and phone calls from women who are finding it virtually impossible to get the sort of retraining that they need. They cannot get Austudy unless they study full time. Many of these women need to study part time. The training programs which are available and funded and for which income support is available while they are being undertaken are very restricted. They are short courses. For women in particular-one woman phoned my office about this last week-they are very stereotyped in their application. This particular woman, who wanted to become a social worker, needed to study part time because she had young children. She wanted to assist people like herself in the future. She was not able to get Austudy because she could only study part time and the only options through the Commonwealth Employment Service for her were computer work and typing. The Government has got a long way to go on that. We heard in the mini-Budget period last year, when those other benefits were removed, that money would be spent and that there would be new programs. We are hearing now that there will be savings from this legislation and that when those savings are made we will get the programs. These women cannot wait. They need those programs now.

I have not mentioned the isolated women. If a woman lives in a country town that is only 25 or 30 kilometres away from the nearest technical and further education college, she has enough problems. But if she lives in a country town that is 120 kilometres away or further, she has really got problems. The greatest motivation for this legislation-I will give the Government some credit for this; certainly it is our greatest motivation in supporting this legislation-is breaking the cycle of poverty in which these women and their children find themselves. Another motivation for this legislation is to lay emphasis on the responsibility which all parents have, not just those who have the custody of the children after there is a breakdown of a relationship. I think we all agree that that is a responsible approach and that it is something that we should be doing.

I am disturbed at the increased community hostility which is being directed towards sole parents. As Senator Vanstone pointed out, the myth that teenagers are having babies to get on the gravy train of social welfare is killed, if not by the fact that only 4 per cent of sole parent beneficiaries are teenagers, then certainly when one looks at the figures, sees the abysmal amount of money and knows that these people are living in poverty. I think it is very important that all of us, whichever side of the chamber we are on, do everything we can to break down this rather distressing attitude which appears to be building up.

There is a third motivation; that is, to save money. I notice that the Minister, in his response in the second reading debate in the other place, was annoyed-I think he used that word himself-at the accusation that this was a money saving exercise. I am interested that the accusation was actually made in any case because I would have thought that the people in opposition down there seemed very interested in money saving. However, I am glad it was made, and it did annoy the Minister. We are told that the estimated savings will be $7.6m for the first partial year; $120m in 1987-88; and $192m in the two subsequent years to 1990. That is a lot of money. Certainly they are significant savings, but those savings must not be made at the cost of children who are still living in poverty.

The major flaw of this package is that there is to be no maintenance guarantee. That is an essential factor. The Government has been very heavily lobbied by the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) and by people from the Welfare Rights Unit. I am not sure whether the Institute of Family Studies actually lobbies, but there have been quite disturbed comments by people, including Tricia Harper from the Institute of Family Studies. An excellent article by Marianne Latham last Wednesday on the `Accent' page of the Age, of which Rosemary West is the excellent editor, said of this legislation:

Some of these savings should go to some form of guaranteed child maintenance payment for those the scheme won't assist. These included women who do not know the location of their ex-partner and those whose partner is dead or on a very low income.

The article points out that a maintenance guarantee was part of the initial proposal for a better scheme for maintenance payments which came from the Institute of Family Studies. As I have said, Tricia Harper has commented: `It's a major flaw that the Government hasn't included a maintenance guarantee'. We share those concerns, as do ACOSS, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and others. I note that in the article the Minister said that the Government would be looking at the recommendations for a maintenance guarantee next year. He warns:
There is not unlimited money to go around; it will become a budgetary matter. Currently our priority for single parents is education and training.

I have made my comments on education and training for single parents. Putting those programs in place is lagging very badly behind. Meanwhile the labour market oriented legislation which is removing benefits is going through this Parliament. I think the Government needs to worry a great deal about that. It is very distressing to hear from these women who need retraining, who want retraining and who must have it if they are not going to continue to live in poverty. They are just simply not getting it at the levels it is needed.

At this point it is important that I give credit for the changes which have been made before this legislation came into the Parliament and subsequent to the original announcements. The reduction of benefit under the income test from 60c to 50c in the dollar was an anomaly which I think the Government was very wise to remove. There has been a deferral of the starting date for the savings clause. I think that is good. The income test on housing has had a limit of 25 per cent put on it. I commend the work of ACOSS, and Julian Disney in particular; his consultations on this matter were strongly supported by the Australian Democrats.

We have before us a Bill which, as I say, is deficient in that there is no maintenance guarantee but in very little else. There are, though, some other concerns with the legislation in a range of areas. One is the requirement of the custodial parent to take maintenance action to gather and provide information about the non-custodial parent. That is a major concern, since so many people who are moving out of a relationship are doing so because of fear for their personal safety. We are still concerned about that. In that process, bearing in mind that these custodial parents are very often people who are on very low incomes and who are therefore going to require some legal aid in taking these actions, I think I need to raise here the issue of legal aid funding, particularly through community legal services whose resources are enormously stretched at the moment. I plead with the Government to recognise that, if custodial parents pursue this action, it should look to ensure that there are no hitches simply because legal aid and legal assistance, particularly through the community legal services, are available to these people. Very often they will need someone to act for them, especially when they have particular problems in pursuing their former partner or providing information about that person.

There are some issues to come in the subsequent legislation relating to income testing, about which we shall have specific things to say at that time; but there are major concerns that, while currently sole parents on benefits have an entitlement to earn $40 per week plus $12 per week per extra child before there is any impact, under the new system the figures are much lower. I recognise that it is a different system, but we shall be pressing for higher figures and, of course, for indexation of those figures. The imputation of in-kind maintenance is a fairly sensitive area. We believe that a phase-in period is needed; but, as I said, we welcome the 25 per cent threshold that is put on that.

I shall also address some of the concerns that have been put to the Australian Democrats, as well as to other parties, about the effect of the collection scheme on business. Of course we need automatic collection. That issue has been addressed. The honourable member for Gippsland in the other House, Mr McGauran, asked why we were lumping together all non-custodial parents as irresponsible defaulters. It is true that they are not all irresponsible defaulters-just the vast majority of them. That is the reason, as has been pointed out-because the previous system has not had any compulsory aspects to it, it has failed. It is clear, and it is clear from overseas evidence as well, that a national register is terribly important in this matter.

We need, too, a system without stigma. That is important. I do not think that what we are trying to do here is to label `responsible' versus `irresponsible' parents, because to do that would drive people into the woodwork or underground and we would have the same problems as we have had before. I certainly support Marie Meggitt, a single mothers representative in the consultation, when she said that automatic collection promotes a community view that this is an accepted part of ordinary everyday life. I remind the Senate that one of our goals here is to promote the view that people should have a responsibility for their children whether or not they are custodial parents. As Marie Meggitt said, one pays for one's children, just as one pays one's taxes. She said:
What has a man got to hide? Why should he be ashamed of his offspring?
That is a very pertinent remark.

Concerns have been expressed by business. Many of those concerns are not legitimate. I point to remarks made in an interview with the honourable member for Bradfield, Mr David Connolly. I refer again to the article in the Age last week, in which he is objecting to the fact that `everybody must pay'. He says:
But there are cases where the boss gets his secretary pregnant. Are you achieving anything by making that a great public exercise? It's even more complicated in cases of incest.

If that is promoted as an argument against automatic payment, I could scarcely think of an argument which would be more deserving of condemnation. There is no circumstance in which one should be ashamed of one's child. I just cannot think of any less rational argument than that. In fact, it is not the case that the actual collection is automatic, because there is an opt out procedure; it is simply the registration of the commitment which is compulsory. For that reason, we shall not be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment.

As I have said, unless the registration is there for everyone, in the sort of circumstance which would exist if the Opposition's proposal were accepted we would still have the case in which, if there were a default, the custodial parent would have to go through exactly the procedure that she currently does, and that is to search the jurisdictions all over Australia to find that in which the order was made. In some cases that might have occurred many years ago, and the jurisdiction may now be very far distant from where she and her children are living. It may be very distressing, or even dangerous, to return to that jurisdiction. She may need someone to act for her, and that would be expensive. So the automatic registration is very important.

It is important, however, that the provisions of the legislation and subsequent provisions of privacy legislation, which the Australian Democrats consider to be of enormous priority in this Parliament, ensure that the information is subject only to the Agency as it is established under this legislation.

The other area, from complaints that we have had from businesses, with which I have considerable sympathy is that of those very small businesses which are still using tax stamps. There are discretionary clauses in the Bill. I urge the Government to fully inform and assist these very small businesses, particularly through the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, using some innovate ways of informing people-indeed, even individual letters to individual businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not just extraordinary how long it takes the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to pick up the Opposition's policies? Tonight we are dealing with the Child Support Bill, a Bill that makes, according to the speech of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh):

SPEECH.PARA: the legal right of children to be supported by both their parents a real right.

The Bill sets up a maintenance collection agency for children of broken families-the Child Support Agency. Its aim is to enforce the payment of maintenance from non-custodial parents. Two steps are needed before that stage is reached. The first step was to remove from the Family Law Act the requirement that when considering maintenance judges should take into account eligibility for the social security supporting parent's benefit. This the Government did just a few months ago. In 1983 Senator Durack first proposed his amendments to this Senate, suggesting that the Family Law Act be changed so as to stop judges being able to take into consideration eligibility for social security benefit. And what did this Senate do? The Labor senators and the Democrats voted against it. As I say, a couple of months ago they put through identical legislation.

In 1985 Senator Durack again tried to bring the Government to its senses. He introduced a private member's Bill proposing exactly the same amendment as that which had been defeated. And what did this Government do? It voted against it, and so did the Democrats. A couple of months ago they brought up identical legislation. What excuse has the Government got? What excuse have the Democrats got? They are certainly slow learners.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are quite consistent. They always support the Labor Party. There is nothing inconsistent in that.

—Well, as far as the Democrats go. In January 1983, while we were still in government, we recognised the need for a collection agency and foreshadowed such an agency. The present Government, then in opposition, was completely opposed to it. We cited all the problems that have been mentioned here tonight, all the problems that are now acknowledged by the Government. We said that it was imperative and that-to quote from the Government's second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The only way to ensure that children receive the support to which they are entitled is by a collection system that does not depend on voluntary payment.

We said in 1983 that that was imperative. We pointed out very clearly that it was the legal right of children to be supported by both their parents. We said that it was the responsibility of both parents to bring up their children, not the responsibility of the taxpayers. We pointed out that 70 per cent of children of separated parents did not receive cash maintenance payments on a regular basis. We said that more than half of the estimated numbers of children living in poverty were from sole-parent families. We said all those things. Indeed, we said that the child maintenance obligation must be given priority over all other commitments of the non-custodial parent. We said that it was imperative that the father pay maintenance before he spent money on luxuries that he considered he should have. We explained all of those things. We pleaded with the Government to alleviate child poverty in this area. The Government refused to take that first step, and it refused to take that second step. By its refusal it allowed more than 400,000 children, according to the Minister's figures, to remain in poverty from 1983.

Suddenly the penny dropped. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) needed an election gimmick. Consequently, we have before us the legislation that we advocated should be introduced in 1983. We all remember in July last year-I am sure that you would remember it, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I am sure you were appalled by it-the Prime Minister said that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990. I am sure you were appalled because I know that you would know it was an impossible thing for a Prime Minister to promise. Yet tonight Senator McKiernan said that that promise had just now been restated by the Minister. Senator McKiernan did not read the Minister's second reading speech, because not one word of it is along those lines. What the Minister said was that no child need live in poverty by 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a change of one word!

—Just a change of one word but a whole host of difference. Tonight Senator McKiernan said that that promise had been restated by the Minister. He had better be very careful because he is going just the same way as John Brown has gone in the other place. John Brown has come out telling the truth and the Prime Minister has jumped on him like a sack of potatoes. I do not know how Senator Walsh, who presented the second reading speech in this place, proposes to fulfil either or both of those promises.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the Government believes that this legislation will cover 40 per cent of those 70 per cent of sole parents who do not receive maintenance payments. What about the other 30 per cent? It means that 30 per cent of those sole parents who are not receiving maintenance payments at present will be in no different position from the position they are in today. And the Prime Minister says that no child will be living in poverty by 1990! An additional 200,000 children have been placed in poverty since this Government came to office according to what is contained in two reports that have recently been presented. It is any wonder, considering that families are not among this Government's priorities?

Let us examine what the Government has done. It has introduced divorce by post. What will that do for families? If that does not encourage the break-up of families, I do not know what will. Under legislation that was introduced recently and that we in this place have debated only in part, magistrates will be able to deal with divorces. Under the present system judges who deal with non-contested divorces must ensure that correct and adequate arrangements are made for children. This Government, with its priorities geared towards introducing anything that saves money, has said that it will allow magistrates to deal with those matters. There is no requirement for magistrates to have been judges or even legal practitioners.

The Government has abolished the payment of the family allowance for children aged 16 years and over. That is the sort of commitment that this Government has to the family. It has means tested the family allowances, resulting in more families being on skid row. This Government has gone down in history as the only government since 1941, when the Liberal Menzies Government introduced child endowment, to tear down the concept, which recognises the added financial burden on families of raising children, that all families should receive some tax relief in order to assist them with that additional financial burden. The Government has refused to increase the family allowance. It has refused to increase the dependent spouse rebate. When the Liberal and National parties came to power in 1975 the dependent spouse rebate was $400 a year. In 1976-77 we increased it to $500; in 1977-78 we increased it to $555; in 1978-79 we increased it to $597; and in 1981 we increased it to $800. In 1981-82 it was increased to $830. We said that that $830 rebate should apply only to a dependent spouse without children; the rebate for a dependent spouse with children was increased to $1,030. That was a deliberate effort to assist families with children.

What has this Government done in the four years it has been in office? This Government has not given an additional cent to dependent spouses with children. That is the sort of priority that I have been talking about. Do not tell me that the Hawke Government has any feeling for families or gives them any priority at all. The family assistance package has been introduced only because of Mr Hawke's statement in his election speech that no child will be living in poverty by the year 1990. The Government pretends a lot. With a great flourish it commissioned Bettina Cass to review family allowances. Bettina Cass presented a report in which she said that the family allowance should not be means tested. She asked, `Why do governments support families with children?'. Her answer to that question was:

Firstly, governments assist all families with their expenditure on children's needs, in recognition of the increased costs which they must meet. Secondly, governments provide additional assistance to low income families whose circumstances make it very hard for them to be in the workforce or whose workforce earnings are low.
When dealing with horizontal equity, which means a fair share for all families, the report says:
This principal recognises that at any level of family income people with children incur greater costs and have greater needs than do people without children at the same level of income.
She went on to say:
All families have experienced a decline in their disposable incomes relative to individuals and couples without children.
She also said:

As noted previously, income-testing or taxing family allowance payments would involve redistribution of resources between families. This would not address the problem of maintaining the disposable incomes of all families with children as a form of tax equity.
In conclusion she said:

In summary, when formulating future directions for reform of family income support programs in Australia we need to address the fundamental objective of redistributing income to all families with children so as to improve and maintain their position in the tax/transfer systems. As a community we need to reassess the value which we place on children and focus again on the concept of the shared parental/community obligation to recognise the increased costs which parents bear.
She stressed that the family allowance must not be means tested. But what happened? The Government means tested it.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was pointing out that this Government has a very poor record in its priorities when it says that it is concerned with the family. I pointed out that the Government has introduced divorce by post, lowered the hearing of the divorce proceedings from the Family Court by allowing magistrates to deal with divorce cases and removed the family allowances for 16-year-olds and upwards and means tested it, even though it commissioned a report by Bettina Cass who recommended that the family allowance should not be means tested. With a great flourish the Government pretends that families are its priority.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the statement of the Prime Minister that by 1990 there would not be a child in poverty the Government introduced the family assistance package. We all remember it well. Mr Hawke, in his election speech, told the Australian people cynically that there would not be a child in poverty by 1990. The family assistance package created dreadful anomalies, dreadful poverty traps. I quote from my last speech on this subject. I said:

We have a new poverty trap. Let us take the case of a single income family with two children where the wage earner, the father, earns $330 a week and, with a little overtime-say 7 1/2 hours-earns an extra $90, which brings him up to $420 a week. By working an extra 7 1/2 hours a week, what will he get? . . . if he is in private rental accommodation he will get the princely sum of $8.59.

That is what he gets from the family assistance package. I pointed out then that this Government has done nothing to give incentive to families, nothing to allow that father to work a little overtime even though he is on a low income. That is one of the cynical approaches the Government has taken when it says it believes that families have a high priority.

What is in the latest Bill the Government has brought before us? As I said, this Bill sets up a collection agency which will be called the Child Support Agency. It establishes the Child Support Register, which is a record of the detail of maintenance liabilities. The registrar in charge of these records will be the Commissioner of Taxation. The Child Support Agency will be administered within the Australian Taxation Office. The Minister's second reading speech states:
. . . all child maintenance liabilities that are payable on a periodic basis under a court order or a registered maintenance agreement are registrable on the Child Support Register.

This will not be retrospective. It will apply only to those who have separated after the Bill's introduction and only to those supporting parents who are in receipt of a pension, allowance or benefit. It applies to another category of people but they-I will come to this later-will be able to get some sort of opting out system.

A matter that worries me-I will refer to this more in the committee stage-is the proposal concerning a person receiving maintenance. The opting out situation can apply. The majority of cases by far will involve an automatic deduction from salaries and wages. The Government says, and the Australian Democrats certainly agreed, that it rejects the suggestion that automatic withholding be imposed only when default in payment occurs. The Government maintains that a stigma is attached to automatic withholding if it is imposed only when people default and that this would detract from the success of the scheme. I do not believe that it is proper to stop an arrangement that has been successfully orchestrated between a former husband and wife, if the father regularly visits his children, takes pleasure in payment for their maintenance and likes to have the children understand that he is still supporting them. He should be allowed to undertake this. But this Government will not allow that to occur, except in very special circumstances. I will explain what those special circumstances are. New section 23 (3) of the Bill states:
. . . the payee-
that is usually the father-

is not required to furnish the form to the Registrar if the payee, within that period of 14 days, elects, by furnishing a duly completed approved form to the Registrar, not to have the registrable maintenance liable enforced under this Act.

That is, the payee cannot do that if he is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit. So only if the person receiving the pension is not in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit is a special dispensation allowed for the payee to be able to opt out of the system. If, as the Government says, a stigma is attached to automatic withholding why is it allowing this special opting out clause? I do not understand what the Government is talking about. If it is good enough for someone whose ex-wife is not on the income tested pension, why is not good enough for someone whose ex-wife is? To me it is a lot of rubbish. The Government is taking away from the father the opportunity of visiting his child regularly and being able to stress that he is still vitally interested in the child's maintenance and is clearly maintaining the child under the separated circumstances.

The Bill contains very strict secrecy clauses which are supposed to entail both Commonwealth officers and employers. I would be very interested to know how the Government intends every employer, who has an employee paying maintenance, in casual conversation not to say to some friend, `So and so is separated from his wife and is paying her x number of dollars'. This is an infringement of people's privacy. I believe that unless there is default people should be able to arrange their circumstances as they choose.

The self-employed will be required to pay maintenance directly to the Agency. If they fail to do so there will be a penalty. This Bill has been extended to spousal maintenance where orders or agreements have been lodged for collection with a State collection agency. This is necessary as the new Child Support Agency takes over from the State collection agencies. In clause 67 of the Bill penalties are referred to. This Bill will make a considerable burden for the employer. It will require more paperwork. It will certainly cost the businessman a certain amount because he will have to take out maintenance payments from the wages of his employees and pay them over to the Registrar. The Bill says that there will be a fine of $20 if such payments are not paid by a certain date.

It is extremely difficult for every employer in the country, particularly the thousands and thousands of small businessmen, to become aware quickly of legislation that passes this Parliament. I would be interested if the Minister later could explain to me how he will be able to overcome this problem and make sure that all employers are aware of their liability. I am not sure how the Government intends to cope with the problem of fining employers $20 if they do not come up with the payment to the Registrar in time. It is a draconian provision.

As I said, this Bill is a farce as the Government is saying that it is really concerned about child-care. It has been accused of putting forward the Bill as a money making exercise only. If the Government's priorities were different I would not make such an accusation, but the Government has an extremely bad history with its priorities for families. I believe the $192.8m to be made by the Government by 1989-90 is a great incentive for the Government to introduce this legislation.

I agree that a collection agency is absolutely essential, as was the first step that was undertaken a couple of months ago. However, this legislation is far too late. This Government should have taken both those steps in 1983 when the Opposition first brought them to the Government's attention. The Government is well behind the eight ball. It has now allowed an extra 200,000 children to move into poverty during its term of office. According to the Minister's own figures it has allowed 400,000 children of sole parents to remain in poverty since 1983 without the benefit of this legislation. I believe it is disgraceful for the Government to treat the people of Australia in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is debating the Child Support Bill of 1987, a Bill for an Act to make provision for the collection of certain periodic maintenance payments and for related purposes. The principal objects of the Bill are that children receive from their parents the financial support that parents are liable to provide and that periodic amounts payable by non-custodial parents towards the maintenance of their children are paid on a regular and timely basis. Further, it is the intention of the Parliament that this Bill shall be construed and administered to the greatest extent consistent with the attainment of its objects to limit interferences with the privacy of persons. I have quoted that set of objectives for two reasons: firstly, to put the debate into its context, and also to give some indication of what an extremely lucid and well-written Bill we have before us. It is one of the easiest Bills to read that I have ever been given. I find it all very straightforward and I also find that there is no excuse for those people in the Opposition who insist on misconstruing what is in the Bill and the intentions of the Government in relation to this Bill and its other initiatives, particularly as regards those families on low incomes with dependent children.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very easy for Senator Walters, for example, to roll out her familiar barrow of dependent spouse rebate, completely ignoring that this is not of any real, direct assistance to those families on low incomes with children and ignoring what we have been able to do as part of a well-constructed plan of direct assistance carefully targeting those families on the lowest incomes. The Federal Government will be paying the family allowance supplement to around 100,000 families by early March. This is a half-way mark of the estimated population in the relevant income range. The Department of Social Security has approved 80,000 applications and 22,000 claims are waiting to be processed. The average payment to low income working families is in the range of $40 to $60 a week, a very substantial contribution to the disposable incomes of low income families. The typical recipient is aged 25 to 35 with a very young family. There are now more than 200,000 children in working families on the family allowance supplement. I repeat: these families are now receiving on average between $40 and $60 per week in non-taxable payments as a supplement to the family allowance.

Our other initiatives include working through the notorious poverty traps that have blighted our system for years and our child support scheme, which itself is one of a series of measures to ensure that families with dependent children which are in distress currently, as has been pointed out time and time again, because of their low incomes have that distress alleviated by whatever measures we can implement.

There has been a great deal of emphasis during this debate both here in the Senate and in the House of Representatives on the length of time it has taken to produce this legislation. Also, some rather misleading statements have been made about a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Durack on two occasions, I believe. Just to set the record straight, I point out that this is not a modern problem; in fact Australia's history is rich in accounts of non-custodial parents avoiding their family responsibilities. In view of the fact that this has been the state of affairs for a great many years-decades, even generations-it is hardly surprising that it has taken us several years to get the system that we want into place, to get the procedures sorted out and all the very many complexities thought through carefully to the point where we feel now able to introduce this legislation and to see the system working within the next few months.

I would like to refer to a paper given by Dr Meredith Edwards to the National Law Council Conference in 1986. Dr Meredith Edwards, I might add, is probably the Australian expert on the subject that is under discussion tonight, the collection of maintenance and the payment to custodial parents. To paraphrase a little the introduction to this paper on the Family Law Council proposal, Dr Edwards says that the issue of maintenance reform was given particular attention by the Family Law Council following the release of the report on a maintenance agency for Australia produced in 1984 by the Attorney-General's Department. That report came out of the joint parliamentary review of the Family Law Act. Dr Edwards said that at that time, while the Family Law Council generally endorsed the concept of a maintenance collection agency, it did have some reservations about the narrow terms of reference on which that report was based. As it transpired, the very thorough and comprehensive report by the Attorney-General's Department was not acted upon-for a number of very good reasons, I might add. Meanwhile, it was known to the Family Law Council that the Commonwealth Government was still considering the issue and had before it many options, including a scheme similar to the New Zealand liable parent contributions scheme. The adoption of a maintenance scheme similar to that operating in New Zealand was, according to the Family Law Council, too narrow a solution and fraught with dangers, particularly the possibility that all maintenance collected would go directly into government revenue. On the basis of the work of the sub-committee that was set up by the Family Law Council, a specific reform proposal was submitted to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in December 1985. Work was being done behind the scenes on this extremely complicated problem at about the same time as the Government announced that it would set up a sub-committee of Ministers to examine maintenance issues and options.

As has been pointed out earlier in this debate, in the last session we dealt with the necessary amendments to the Family Law Act. I remind honourable senators that those amendments picked up the points that were made in Senator Durack's private member's Bill of 1983 and of, I think, 1985. Those points worked very well as far as they went, but they provided for no structure whatsoever. The only way of dealing with recalcitrant non-custodial parents was to gaol them. As I said it was a good start at approaching the problem in a legislative sense but it was only a start and we have built upon what was done on that occasion.

The problem of non-custodial parents avoiding their contributions to their children's upkeep and support is not a new problem. Of course, in earlier times sole parents had very few choices available to them. In many cases, if they did not have a supportive family or friends they were forced to part with their children. The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was able to work through some of the history of this particular problem in our 1985 report, Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care. Of course, the solution until very recently was that children went into institutions. In this report it was observed that the institutional care population has decreased markedly since the peak was reached in 1968. In 1968 the number of children in institutional care totalled nearly 28,000 and comprised 0.72 per cent of all Australian children. This compares with 0.15 per cent of children in institutional care in 1984. That is a very marked change. During the last decade or so the number of children in this type of care has fallen by 65 per cent. The decrease is most marked during the early 1970s, when the Commonwealth Government introduced the supporting mother's benefit and took other initiatives in the child care field. There was a similar reduction in the number of children under guardianship in foster care. The reduction between 1972 and 1982 was about 30 per cent-from 8,500 to just on 6,000.

I recently read a book that I can highly recommend to anybody with an interest in social change. It is My Place by Sally Morgan and it is still on the best seller lists after months. Sally recounts how her mother grew up in-not to put too fine a point on it-an orphanage in Western Australia. It was not a bad orphanage by the standards of the time. It was a pretty run-of-the-mill one, I would have thought, but the mother of that tiny child had to leave her at the orphanage and was able to see her, when she was lucky, one day a week. The people for whom she worked-a wealthy Western Australian family-were pleased to employ the mother but they were not prepared to tolerate the child in the house. That was the state of affairs facing very many supporting parents, the majority of whom were women, in those days.

When one considers for how long non-custodial parents have been avoiding their responsibilities, it is surely not too remarkable that it has taken three or four years for us to produce what we believe will be a very effective and workable scheme that will, one hopes, resolve the problems in Australia. To finish that point, honourable senators may be interested to know that when the responsible Minister-the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe-was in the United States of America recently consulting with authorities who have been working on similar schemes, they expressed their surprise and their congratulations that he had been able, in such a short period, to work up the scheme and to see that it could operate in time. I understand that in Wisconsin he was told that efforts had been made for 10 years to introduce such a scheme.

This is a major social initiative. We are setting up new structures and a completely new approach. There are bound to be people in the community who do not like it, but I am afraid they have been given their chance. This is what we feel should be done. Even worse than poverty for many custodial parents has been the dreadful uncertainty of their incomes, and the feeling they have developed-and it is not surprising-that it is better to be in receipt of a pension or benefit because that equals security. They simply have not had the security of knowing that the non-custodial parent was going to pay the maintenance when and if he or she-mostly he-felt like it.

The question that was raised in relation to the second reading motion amendment that has been put before us-Senator Walters mentioned it-is one that we find a little puzzling because the amendment actually refers to people who have come to an agreement. Those who are to be covered under the child maintenance legislation are those who, as Senator Walters correctly said earlier in the debate, are receiving some sort of pension or benefit, those who have been having their maintenance collected by existing State authorities, and those who have court orders from the date that the legislation is enacted. It does not apply to people who have come to an arrangement. The amendment mentions maintenance arrangements. Where there are consent arrangements the child support scheme does not really want to know about it. At the point where it is felt by the custodial parent that there is no doubt that the payments will be made and there is every confidence that they will turn up on time, that custodial parent can then apply to the Child Support Registrar to have any order suspended. There is also provision in the Bill for a review of that in case that happy state of affairs does not continue.

I am not particularly impressed by the plea that is made about employers and how difficult it is going to be for them, how this might transgress people's privacy and how it will be a great burden for everybody involved. Employers are accustomed to dealing with garnishee orders. In addition, the majority of employers are well organised and arrange for deductions from wages for a number of different reasons. They deduct union dues, insurance and health insurance payments. They deduct amounts for social clubs and all sorts of things. One would have thought that for a cause such as this they would be delighted in many cases actually to take part in what I have described as a major social initiative. I think many workers will actually welcome having this money deducted from their wages. Those who are sincere, those with decent intentions, will be quite grateful to have the money handled in this way. Let us face it, a debt which is the subject of a court order-and this is the same with any other debt-has no less status surely because it is of a domestic nature. It is a little like the argument that violence that occurs within the home is somehow different or of a lesser order or of less concern to society than violence that occurs on the street. Surely a debt which occurs between people who are closely associated, and certainly a debt which is going towards the payment of maintenance for children of a marriage, should be of no less status than any other debt that is handled in that manner. Regardless of where it occurs, this system will deal with debts in that very effective fashion.

I am tempted to tell the House one of my favourite maintenance stories, and I will. Mr Justice Fogarty, who is chairing the Child Support Consultative Group which is studying the next stage for this particular structure, has a reputation for giving very innovative decisions. The one I like best is the one that related to a non-custodial parent who was pleading before His Honour that he had no extra resources and that his only sport, his only recreation, was parachuting. His Honour was moved to say, `That is all right, you can go on parachuting; we will have your parachutes.'.

The Taxation Office is going to be the obvious and most efficient venue for the setting up of our office. The Child Support Registrar will be the Commissioner of Taxation, and the national child registry, the Child Support Agency, will be within the Tax Office. It is in by far the best position to trace defaulters. It would be in a much better position if it had a universal file tax number, and perhaps we will have that one day. The national register that we are planning for births, deaths and marriages would also be a great deal of assistance to this process. In any case, we will have a national registry which will take much of the confusion, the expense and the distress out of the proceedings regarding custodial and non-custodial parents who are living in different States, who receive orders from different States and who at the time may have a great deal of difficulty in sorting out the orders or even finding out where their orders have been made.

Senator Walters mentioned that we would be dealing with spousal maintenance as well as child maintenance. This may surprise some people in view of the fact that very much part of the philosophy behind the Family Law Act was that spousal maintenance would be a rare occurrence, for a number of reasons, many of which go to the question of the spouse who does not have much in the way of resources being encouraged to develop skills and talents and to become independent. The Act, however, does recognise that the spouse who is over 45 years of age and on a pension or benefit, or is currently receiving spousal maintenance, can be included in our scheme. As I said, this is rare but I understand there has been some increase in the last two years in the cases where spousal maintenance is being approved by the court, particularly where the spouse is over 50 and has had a long period of being out of work and does not have any immediately marketable skills. I understand that spousal maintenance is being awarded to younger women for periods of perhaps three or four years to allow them to retrain and to become independent and support their families.

We are no doubt going to have some problems. The proportion of non-custodial parents who cannot pay maintenance by reason of their unemployment, sickness or any other incapacity is assessed at about 18 per cent. It may also be likely that a fairly high proportion may not be located easily. I understand that if one goes to northern mining towns with a camera one is not particularly popular in bars late in the evening. A journalist friend of mine who produced a camera was suddenly faced with a completely empty bar, so that might be a fertile field for some solid investigation. One-third of the pensioner beneficiaries who are on a supporting parent's benefit or pension are on it for less than 12 months, and two-thirds of that cohort are on a pension or benefit for less than three years. So we can see that we will be dealing with a shifting population. Another problem is that quite a substantial number of those custodial parents are assumed not to have court orders, but we will be doing whatever we can to help them to get those orders. Eighty-four per cent of these pensioners or beneficiaries are on full pensions or benefits, which gives an indication of the very limited access that the majority of them have to any income outside their social security pensions and benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maintenance paid by non-custodial parents on average is 13 per cent of their take home pay, and the higher the income of the non-custodial parent, the lower the proportion. Three-quarters of female sole parents are worse off by a median amount of $78 a week, while three-quarters of men are better off by a similar amount. Rather than going any further into that, I will rely on the table to speak for itself. In 80 per cent of the cases the mother has responsibility for the children. However, as has been mentioned here this evening, there are now more cases in which custody is being awarded to the father.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the criticisms of this Bill is that we are not including at this stage a guaranteed payment which would assist those women, principally those custodial parents, who for some reason or other-low income would be one of the main reasons and failure to locate the non-custodial parent could possibly be more common than that-will not be helped by this Bill. I am amongst the people on this side of the House who have a very strong commitment to seeing some sort of guaranteed payment introduced within a reasonably short time. I think that any- body with a commitment to any sort of social justice, equity and access-all those things-must see that as one of the next steps that we must take. As Senator Powell said in her very perceptive contribution to this debate, breaking the cycle of poverty is the crucial thing to do. We must provide training opportunities and the moral and material support that is required to enable supporting mothers particularly to acquire the skills and confidence to enter the work force, and to get out of the cycle of poverty and make it possible for their children to grow up other than in that environment and amongst that expectation of poverty.

Maybe not all the problems have been sorted out but we have spent a lot of time and a lot of energy working through what we saw as the difficulties of this exercise. I am pleased to have been part of that process, as I know many of my colleagues are. I believe the congratulations of the Senate should go to Minister Howe for his commitment to this legislation, and our congratulations go also to those senior people on his staff and in his Department who have spent a lot of their lives over the last two or three years working very hard on this scheme. I believe that this social advance is long overdue. I am delighted that we are now in a position, as the Opposition might never have been, to make the difficult decisions and to include this particular Bill amongst our legislative initiatives.

We hear now mourning noises from those people who will now have to pay, who can no longer choose whether or not to support the children of their associations. Surely over the years those people have been given every opportunity in the world to demonstrate whether or not they were going to be responsible. Time and time again in this debate we have heard that 70 per cent of non-custodial parents default in their maintenance payments. I do not see how we could anticipate in the future some amazing change in Australian nature that would mean that any less than those 70 per cent would pay maintenance without being compelled to do so. This Bill will break through the barrier that has kept so many women and children in poverty for far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Child Support Bill and to support the amendment moved by the Opposition. This Bill establishes a new system of maintenance collection by enabling the collection of maintenance orders set by the courts via tax mechanisms and by setting up a Child Support Agency. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has stated that more than half the child maintenance orders set by the courts are not complied with, and in most parts of Australia there is no effective collection system and separated parents just do not pay. It has been said that many custodial parents do not bother to obtain an order in the first place because orders are often impossible to enforce. Also, going to court is a very costly business. Just about every time anyone goes to court it costs $1,000 or something like that. The result of all this is that more than 70 per cent of parents no longer living with their children do not pay regular child support.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982-83, when the present Opposition was in government, Senator Durack was working to bring in legislation to ensure the payment of maintenance. When Labor came to power it decided not to proceed with it at that time. Finally this legislation has been brought in. It has certainly been a long, drawn out process.

The Opposition's amendment is an important one, as it aims to ensure the protection of the rights of non-custodial parents who have entered into maintenance arrangements to share in the cost of supporting their children at no extra cost to the Commonwealth by not requiring these agreements to be registered with the Child Support Agency except in the event of maintenance arrangements not being honoured. Certainly parents, whether married or unmarried, have obligations in terms of their children. The reality is that it is the duty of parents to provide support for their children. There is no way on moral or economic grounds that parents should be able to walk away from their responsibilities and leave it to the Australian taxpayer. However, we have to realise that 30 per cent of non-custodial parents do pay regular maintenance although, as I said before, it is regrettable that 70 per cent do not. These people who pay should be trusted to adhere to their responsibilities without the compulsion of legislation such as we are debating this evening.

It is important when parents do the right thing by themselves, their children and the taxpayer that they not have a bureaucrat interfering in their private affairs, that they not be required to have their employer know all about their private affairs and that they have a right to come to a private arrangement. I believe that is what the Opposition's amendment is all about. It is recognised that there is a need to ensure that people make maintenance payments. If the payments are not made, if one former partner does not agree to a private arrangement or if there is a claim on the social security system, the agency certainly should be involved. But if there are none of those things, if the partners agree, if the maintenance is being paid and if there is no claim on the social security system, why should the Government's bureaucracy get involved in their private affairs?

It is regrettable that there is so much child poverty and marriage breakdown in our community. We should all be concerned about that. I think we would all accept that there is a role for government in trying to prevent the failure of a marriage having harmful consequences by protecting both children and spouses from destitution-and, indeed, in facilitating easy separation in hopeless cases. The perverse outcome of our system is that the fragmented family instantly receives far more in government support than the family which stays together. To take an average example, a family with two children receives about $12.75 a week in family allowance. If that family breaks up, the supporting parent will receive at least $158.15 a week. I sometimes do wonder whether the Government is doing enough for premarriage counselling which perhaps could help provide a solution to marriage breakdowns. Regrettably this Government has drastically reduced the funding available for premarriage counselling. As a matter of fact, a mere $5m or so a year is allocated to supporting Australia's extremely effective counselling and marriage guidance organisation.

It is important that the non-custodial parent make maintenance payments. If a child is brought into the world it is the parents' responsibility to make sure it is looked after, whether the parents are married or unmarried. We must remember that children are a community resource and are entitled to community support, both financial and otherwise, to ensure their optimal development. Children do have a right to expect support of all kinds from both parents. The Government's pre-eminent responsibility should be to assist parents to provide adequate support for their children, thereby minimising the need for substitute care for children which is undertaken at financial cost to the community and at social cost to the child and the community.

The sad part of this whole subject is that the figures tell us that there are 800,000 children in poverty, and 400,000 of those are the responsibility of single parents. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has told us more than once-we hear it often-that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! Do you support that?

—I certainly believe that to be a very worthwhile objective, but we are not seeing too much happening about it at the present time. I just want to tell Senator McKiernan that the Government has said that, under the family assistance package, a married couple with two small children and on a single income of $330 a week is eligible to receive a family allowance supplement and rental assistance if they live in privately rented accommodation. But what the Government does is take $40.39 per week from them in tax and give them back a family allowance supplement of $35 a week, plus rental assistance. Should the wage earner work 7 1/2 hours overtime and earn an extra $90 a week, the family will be only $8.59 per week better off after the loss of the family allowance supplement and reduction in rental assistance. Who would want to work an extra 7 1/2 hours for $8.59 per week? People would rather sit back and be assured of the government handout. Those are some of the problems that confront the Government in trying to do away with poverty. We all need to think about that.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that many of the 400,000 children who are suffering a degree of poverty are suffering purely and simply because their parents decided not to stay married or decided not to bother getting married at all and then parted company. Last year there was in one of the papers an article which said that Minister Howe was saying that girls having babies to claim benefits was a myth; but the article pointed out that Australia has 7,400 teenage single parents.
