That is a cause for concern. There are 6,300 unmarried teenagers and 1,100 separated de facto teenagers receiving the supporting parent's benefit. The article refers to a study which says:

. . . while failing to find any clear evidence that teenagers decided to get pregnant to receive the benefit availability of the benefit might help teenagers decide to keep their babies rather than have them adopted.
If motherhood is the most appealing option to some teenage girls, then a broader range of educational and employment programs may be needed for them . . .

That is the conclusion of the study. We all know of cases where marriages have broken up. Each partner thinks that he or she is the right. The courts have to look very closely at, and above all must decide, who is best able to support the children, because the children should be the ones we are worried about in this Bill. The reality is that these days many pressures are put on people in receipt of lower incomes because they do not have enough money. We must try to make sure that no further poverty is imposed. Most importantly, we have to do all that we can, as legislators, to make sure that the traditional marriage structure is held together, which, of course, is really the best solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Child Support Bill which is before us tonight. It is one part of three significant pieces of legislation, the others being the Family Law Amendment Act and the soon to be introduced Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Bill. Together with this piece of legislation they form a package dealing with changes in maintenance payments. As any reading of the House of Representatives debate would show, we are hearing in the Senate a debate in which both sides are in considerable, if not complete, agreement, apart from one very curious amendment that seems to miss the substance of the legislation. I do not quite understand how that amendment has come in. By way of justifying a slight difference in emphasis or position, Opposition senators have spoken somewhat to the amendment and somewhat to the nature of marriage, the state of parenting, insufficient marriage education and so on, which perhaps are all related to, but certainly slightly wide of, the substance of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it was Senator Bjelke-Petersen who said in her speech that maintenance legislation had been introduced by Senator Durack, both as a member of a government and, since, as a member of the Opposition. She seemed to suggest that it was a bit curious that the Government did not support those proposals but went ahead with its own. Any examination of what the Government is doing would explain why. The Government's legislation tonight, as I said earlier, is part of a package of three pieces of legislation that clearly indicate the comprehensiveness of the proposals in this area by the Government. There was no way that a simple change of maintenance payments under the Family Court system would address the question with anything like the same sufficiency as the Government legislation has done. It is important to appreciate that this legislation is part of those three pieces of legislation which make a very different and much more comprehensive attack on child poverty as a consequence of insufficient maintenance payments.

It is important to recognise that this piece of legislation is one part of the continuing Government program on behalf of the people of Australia, particularly those in poverty. It is very much in line with the Government's ambition to see no children in this country in poverty by 1990. It, first of all, recognises that there are children in poverty, and that it certainly has done. Secondly, it has also been able to target where most of that poverty occurs. The largest part of child poverty occurs where there are sole-parent families and, in particular, sole-parent families dependent entirely on welfare payments and denied their just maintenance contribution from a non-custodial parent. The figures are clear. They have been cited by any number of people. Over half the 800,000 Australian children living in poverty are in sole-parent families. There are now more than 250,000 sole-parent families, with 450,000 children, who are forced to rely on pensions or benefits from the social security system. In other words, the social security system by itself is not sufficient to address comprehensively the alleviation of poverty in those families. While it clearly guarantees that no child starves and that children have roofs over their heads, it does not in any way alleviate the poverty consequent on the failure of the non-custodial parent to make a right and proper contribution for the children.

As I was saying earlier, this program recognises that poverty occurs and that we should address that poverty. This legislation is part of a number of programs of the Government to try to address that. Senator Knowles has asked how we are planning to do it. I am happy to answer. One of the great achievements of this Government that somehow seems to be easily ignored or overlooked is the creation of one million jobs since coming to office in 1983. (Quorum formed)

I was saying that this child support legislation is part of the Government's program to attack the question of poverty in this country. One of its achievements in addressing that problem has been the creation of one million jobs through the creation of an economic climate in which that could be fostered and achieved. Those jobs mean that an income coming into the family is the very best way to address the question of poverty. We have seen other legislation-whether it is the equal employment legislation, the affirmative action legislation or our child care legislation, which is not so much legislation, but programs-which contributes to the opportunity for women to take their place in the work force and to be able to participate in education and training. It is a clear understanding and recognition that the best way out of poverty is having a regular income from employment. I do not quite understand why Opposition senators would feel aggrieved enough on my mentioning those points to feel that they should interrupt this debate.

The other comments that I have heard argued against some of the other achievements of Government-for instance, the comments made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen that somehow the family allowance supplement is not really of benefit to families in poverty-I think are very curious. Those families in poverty on that low income were paying their tax before the family allowance supplement. They now receive the family allowance supplement as a tax free addition to that income. Judging from the number of families around Australia who have learned of that program that is to their benefit and have taken it up to this point, I would have thought that they would be very appreciative of any dollar contribution to their family income and to the benefits that that will provide for their children. I find it quite curious that the Opposition would argue that this Government is not concerned to alleviate poverty and that it is not concerned for the welfare of the very people we claim to represent and whom, in fact, we clearly do represent.

The other point that needs to be mentioned here is that apart from the questions of social justice-I believe that they are undeniable-that is, of having poverty alleviated, there is also the hard economic good sense it makes to take people out of poverty. Poverty is very expensive for any country. We cannot argue any longer that keeping people in poverty is an economic gain for the country. It is an economic outlay; it is a drain. It is precisely for hard, economic reasons, let alone the questions of social justice, that this Government is very concerned to see the alleviation of poverty and, in particular, the alleviation of poverty for children. Our children are-here I do agree with Senator Bjelke-Petersen-our richest asset. If those children grow up in poverty, unaware of ideas, educational opportunities, books and the possible things that they can try to achieve and are denied opportunities of education and training, they will be the poorer. They will be the poorer as adults and they will, therefore, clearly be a contribution to a poorer society. It is precisely because poverty is a drain that the Government is very concerned to address that question of the alleviation of child poverty. The welfare of our children adds very much to the richness, recovery and economic well-being of our future.

Lest I forget later on in this speech, I would like to take the opportunity now to congratulate those people who have been involved in the comprehensive preparation of this legislation and the three pieces of legislation going, as I said earlier, to a package to address the question of maintenance in a comprehensive way. I think the whole social security review, headed by Dr Bettina Cass, the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, and in particular the people on his staff who have been so involved in all of this, needs to be commended. It has been a very long and tough task to arrive at the proposals outlined in this legislation which I think do address the question so comprehensively, as I said before. They go to the changes under family law that mean that in the future no decision about maintenance can call into account the likelihood of a pension or social security payments. Maintenance must be set disregarding social security benefits. That is a very critical change. I think that the courts will welcome the clear outlining of that as a requirement of the courts in addressing the question of maintenance.

Under this legislation we have the establishment under the Australian Taxation Office of the Child Support Agency. Attached to that are the benefits that go to the privacy of tax matters that will continue to be provided in all the matters pertaining to the child support agency. As well, there are clauses in the legislation that go to guaranteeing that privacy requirement be extended to employers, particularly those who are involved in providing maintenance payments in employee's wages or salaries. It is very clear that people should not fear an invasion of their privacy under this legislation. They will be assisted to address their rights of maintenance payments properly under this legislation, but they can be assured of the strict privacy guarantees.

Why go this way? It seems to me to be fairly obvious. I do not understand the comments made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen that people ought not be required to pay maintenance. If they seem to be people of goodwill and they want to enter into an agreement between themselves and prefer to stay that way and not be required to participate under this legislation and if we were starting out on this path it might be a reasonable way of proceeding. But what we do have to face is the hard evidence that over the last 10 to 20 years or so, more than 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay regular maintenance. It has been tested and it has been found wanting. People, even under an injunction from the court, have not been keeping up their maintenance payments. Clearly, the legislation acknowledges a piece of history; that is, that more than 70 per cent of non-custodial parents despite court orders, have failed in their maintenance payments. I do not believe, in the face of that evidence, that we can continue to be cavalier or to disregard the requirement of that maintenance to be paid.

It is not a punitive piece of legislation, it is not a piece of legislation that says that people shall be punished; it is a piece of legislation that goes to what I would have thought was one of the Opposition's considerable claims-that is, the importance and rights of families to have a responsibility for their children. In many other debates Opposition members object to the Government's legislation on the grounds that we somehow seem to be denying parents the rights to and responsibilities for their children. We do not in any legislation; we certainly do not here. But what we have to admit is that many non-custodial parents in times past have not maintained their contribution. They have defaulted on their contribution to their children.

We strongly endorse in this legislation the rights of parents to the primary responsibility for and care of their children. The Government is not subsuming the rights to care for children; it is prepared to say that it wants to endorse that primacy, that responsibility of parents to care for their children. It is and it always will be a backup support. In this legislation the Government is guaranteeing the importance of that concern-the primacy of parents to have not only regard for but also responsibility for their children.

The other important emphasis in this legislation is that it has separated the importance of maintenance payment away from custody and access. They are separate questions. Maintenance cannot be seen as a payment by which one buys access of custody to children. In separating it in that way, much of the heat and unhappiness consequent on marriage break-up and separation from children will be removed from the debate. That is a separate debate. It can be undertaken in other places. But the rights of children to the maintenance payments from their non-custodial parents are approved and supported in this legislation as part of a principal concern of government that parents have that primary concern and responsibility for their children. That is why I am sure that in many of the speeches from the Opposition there is no dispute with the heart of this legislation.

Certainly, as I said earlier, any reading of the House of Representatives debate on this legislation, from both sides, will show that there seems to be some dispute about how we agree-a curious notion-but I believe that it goes to the understanding that nobody in the Opposition is seriously about opposing this legislation. And neither should they be, because this is a thoughtful piece of legislation. It has addressed very comprehensively how people shall come on to the Child Support Register and how the essential decisions will still be made by family courts. The Family Court amendment has made clear which children will be under the jurisdiction of that Court. Some of those children who were previously not able to be dealt with in the Family Court now will be, and as well the other changes will expedite non-contested cases which can be dealt with more speedily in a magistrate's court. All of those things contribute very much to settling the problem quickly consequent on a marriage break-up and allow for the Family Court to make proper orders in this way but with some clearer guidelines about to whom those orders shall apply and how they shall be made.

I am sure that the Family Court will welcome the clarification that, for example, it cannot, as I said earlier, take social security payments in to account when making decisions about maintenance. It also will shortly be able to address better what is an appropriate amount of maintenance. Any evidence will show that the going rate of maintenance settlement in the Family Court is about $25 per week for the first child, or $40 per week for two children. Anybody who has the care of children and the responsibility for their upbringing, in this place let alone anywhere in Australia, will say that that is a very small amount of money with which to try to meet the cost of rearing a child. So the courts will, I think, be welcoming of the changes and the clarification on this matter.

Under the proposals of this piece of legislation, the Commissioner of Taxation will assume the role of Child Support Registrar and families will be able to register with that Agency for the regular payment of maintenance. As I have said, it will take much of the heat out of the problems of maintenance payment in the past. It will also guarantee a more regular and reliable contribution to the family income of the custodial parent, and that is a matter of importance in itself. Maintenance can be paid sometimes erratically or intermittently, and that in itself is very disruptive for the ongoing decisions that the custodial parent has to take on behalf of the children of that family. The importance of a regular payment is probably equal to the importance of an appropriate amount of payment. Both of those things will be dealt with under the new provisions of this piece of legislation.

I think that the clear spelling out-Senator Giles alluded to this-and the clarity of this piece of legislation, addressing these issues as it does, in a way that is very accessible to understanding, needs to be commented on. It is important for people to know precisely what is the emphasis and what are the proposals under this piece of legislation. Fortunately, as spelt out by Senator Giles, the Bill does that very well indeed, and consequent on the proposed changes the Government would expect to see some small savings, in the first year of about $7m and in a full year a proposed $190m or thereabouts. Those savings consequent on the adequate and proper collection of maintenance will also be then available for the Government to better target its other policies, in particular, the further targeting of those children who still need further assistance to contribute to the alleviation of their poverty. As I say, poverty cannot be understood only in terms of dollars. It also has to be understood in terms of children growing up in a family with adequate educational opportunities, training opportunities and so on. The savings under this legislation can be targeted to contribute in this way.

One other point that I wanted to make earlier is that another point of change under this Government has been the considerable improvement and change in the education allowances under the heading of Austudy that have been so encouraging of children to stay at school to continue developing their education, taking up those fuller opportunities so as to better proceed to tertiary training of whatever sort they choose and, therefore, a much higher likelihood of employment. That is another very significant area in the alleviation of poverty, and it contributes very significantly; it matches and joins very nicely with the proposals under this legislation.

The families who will be taken into the registry after this legislation is enacted include all of those who will be in receipt of a pension and all of those who choose to be registered with the Agency. But the legislation certainly allows that, where people come to an agreement and the custodial parent will not be in receipt of a pension, they do not have to register with the Agency-though the opportunity is there, down the line, if there is a default on maintenance payments for the Agency to pick up that collection if the agreement fails. There is the option for parents, on the occasion of separation, if the custodial parent will not be in receipt of a pension, not necessarily to register.

That point needs to be made. I cannot understand why the Opposition's amendment is not covered by that. Despite hearing the debate put by the Opposition, I still do not understand exactly why it is moving the amendment and what exactly it goes to. Perhaps in the course of the debate still to come somebody on the Opposition side can make clearer to me what the Opposition is proposing under its amendment and why, despite the arguments from this side and the hard evidence of what we have done, it would condemn the Government for a rapid decline in the welfare of Australian children. It seems to be quite curious in the face of this piece of legislation, which deliberately and directly has the opposite effect.

Just to make it clear, the new collection system will cover the child maintenance payments for parents who separate after the scheme is introduced, for parents who have not lived together when the child is born after the scheme is introduced, for parents receiving income tested pensions, benefits and allowances other than family allowances, regardless of their separation date, and parents using State maintenance collection agencies or whose maintenance orders or agreements are lodged with State agencies when the new Child Support Agency takes over the collection functions of those State agencies. I think that will pick up a considerable number of parents currently in receipt of maintenance or in receipt of insufficient maintenance. The Agency will pick up all of those and, of course, it will take on those other categories of people I have just spelt out.

I mentioned earlier the importance of the legislation dealing with the rights to privacy. The legislation specifically addresses the individual's right to privacy. It also has clauses that address the right of individuals not to be discriminated against by, for example, an employer, because of their maintenance obligations. Most importantly of all, it makes sure that the health and safety of children of custodial parents will not be threatened as a result of the operation of the scheme. I have certainly heard some discussion from the Opposition that the requirement of employers to collect the maintenance payment will be, first, a problem and, secondly, a prospective invasion of privacy. Senator Giles, in her speech a little earlier, spelt out very clearly how employers are currently engaged in the collection of a number of contributions from their employees. This will be but one more. Employers will be very well aware of the privacy requirements under this legislation and the penalties provided for should those requirements be breached. I do not believe that employers will want to breach them, not so much because of the proposed penalties but I believe because they will support the privacy requirements of the legislation.

Discussing the detail of the legislation could keep us here for quite some time. Senator Coates, who is sitting in front of me, and I are two of the senators on this side of the chamber who have been through many of the debates, discussions and negotiations about how this legislation would come out in its final form. We know how long that task has taken and the sorts of details that have been picked up in the Bill. We are well aware of its detail. I do not believe I should take up the time of the Senate in discussing that detail. I believe this is a significant piece of legislation. It will provide great benefits to those families who would expect not to receive maintenance payments, with the current climate being that maintenance payments are defaulted on by 70 per cent of parents. Parents who separate in the future will have the comfort of knowing that maintenance payments will be made regularly and that such payments will be provided for them under the arrangements set out in this legislation in a way that will free those parents of the worry of making such payments and of the problem of contesting such payments or having to go to court time and again because of continuing defaulting. That will be a thing of the past for all those parents eligible to come under the terms of this legislation.

The legislation will also allow the custodial parent to plan on behalf of his or her children in a more satisfactory way, knowing what his or her regular income is likely to be and being able to take that into account. I think that will provide the custodial parent with considerable harmony. It will relieve that parent of the disease and unhappiness that goes with the chronic worry of where the money is coming from. In all sorts of ways it is a splendid piece of legislation. It is very much part of the Government's package designed to alleviate poverty for children. I find specious indeed the Opposition's objections to that claim by the Government. There is really no substance to its cynical rejection of that claim by the Government. The Government is on target. It is addressing poverty in this country in any number of ways. This legislation is very much part of that process. The Opposition's arguments are curious, particularly as the sentiment expressed by all of those who have spoken on this legislation is in support of the substance of the legislation. Though we can take note of the edges of the Opposition's arguments, they do not go to the substance of this legislation. I am very pleased to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Child Support Bill 1987 which is complementary to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 which placed responsibility on parents to maintain their children as a priority at a level not lower than the needs of other children and above all other needs. It was interesting to listen to the remarks of Senator Crowley and a number of other government speakers this evening. However, I think Senator Crowley has topped them all in her total and unequivocal abuse of parliamentary privilege by the way in which she has misrepresented the Opposition's argument and the way in which she camouflaged the Government's inadequacies in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of public record that back in 1983-January 1983 to be precise-the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, foreshadowed the proposal to establish a collection agency. Senator Crowley has chosen to leave the chamber. This Government chose to ignore that proposal because it did not see the benefit of such legislation. My colleague Senator Durack foreshadowed amendments to the legislation in 1983 and moved those amendments when this Government took office. The Government, in cahoots with the Australian Democrats, defeated the amendments that Senator Durack moved to the Family Law Act.

In 1985 Senator Durack, via the avenue of a private member's Bill, tried again to have maintenance payments set by the judges without due consideration, before that determination was made, of any social welfare payments that could be obtained by a supporting parent. Of course, once again the Government and the Australian Democrats saw fit not to support Senator Durack's Bill. Today we have before us what Senator Crowley has described as a thoughtful piece of legislation. I suppose `thoughtful' is about the right word to use; it has taken the Government four years to think of it, even though it was not the originator of the idea in the first instance.

On behalf of my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I must state that what Senator Crowley said about Senator Bjelke-Petersen-that she considered that maintenance was not important to the children of a custodial parent-is absolutely and utterly wrong. That is not what Senator Bjelke-Petersen said. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is very much in favour of ensuring that people support their children. Throughout this debate we have heard an absolutely amazing set of words from Government speakers, that they do not understand the amendments moved by the Opposition. I suggest, with all due respect, that they first read it. They might then understand it. Paragraph (b) in particular of the Opposition's amendment seeks to condemn the fact that the welfare of Australian children has rapidly declined under the Hawke Labor Government. I shall give the Senate some facts to support that contention in a moment.

I come back to the fact that the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 was a very important piece of legislation, if belated. What it did was exclude any consideration of the availability of pensions and benefits before the level of maintenance was determined. That is exactly what the Opposition has been advocating for such a long time. Yet it took until the end of 1987 for this Government to wake up. The great tragedy of all this is that more than 800,000 children are living in poverty and half of those children are in single parent families. I believe it is almost sinful for this Government to say not once, not twice, but repeatedly that it will eradicate child poverty by 1990. Even Mick Young did not believe that. During the election campaign he said that that would be impossible to achieve. Tonight Senator Crowley repeated the disposable promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he would eradicate child poverty by 1990. When asked by way of interjection to demonstrate how the Government would achieve that goal, Senator Crowley chose to ignore the interjection. She did so because she could not answer it, and she knows full well that because of the way in which the Government is proceeding there is no answer to it.

This whole exercise becomes especially cynical when the Government says simultaneously that one key element in achieving the abolition of child poverty is the introduction of flexible and effective programs to assist the sole parents to get and keep jobs. Senator Crowley went on at length about this aspect tonight. But the Government needs to wake up to itself and the militant trade unions and create a more flexible working environment in which supporting parents can in fact look after their children and also work. If the Government will not get tough on the unions and allow employees and employers to come to suitable agreements, how can it possibly hope to deliver this wild dream that it keeps repeating? Not so long ago the employers and the employees at a clothing factory in Victoria decided they would start work half an hour early, take only half an hour instead of an hour for lunch and finish work an hour earlier in the afternoon. The employees in that factory were predominantly women. That arrangement enabled them to pick up their children from school and look after them. What happened? The unions, with their typical militant thuggery, threatened to close down the operation if the employees did not return to the original working hours. Where is the flexibility, about which this Government is talking, that is meant to get people back into the work force where they can earn a respectable living? Children deserve to be looked after by their parents under all circumstances. They should not be treated as an item to be thrown away when the fun wears off.

A more realistic and just approach to the question of maintenance is essential, both to reduce the taxation demands on the intact families of Australia and to instil the basic moral principle that parents, to the best of their ability, have an overriding responsibility to their children, whom they must not be allowed to divorce. This Government must shoulder a fair slice of responsibility for the incidence of marriage breakdowns and, therefore, child poverty. This is where we come to paragraph (b) of our amendment which poor Senator Crowley could not read or understand. It appears that this Government's national priority is to make it easier financially for people to go to the Family Court to dissolve a marriage rather than encourage them to seek marriage guidance. The funding discrepancies between the two are nothing short of outrageous.

I am most concerned about one element of the Child Support Bill 1987. Whilst the measures are all prospective in terms of putting people onto the Register for maintenance collection, why is there a need to breed a sense of injustice by not allowing those who abide by their obligations regularly and privately to continue to do so? I recognise that there is a massive problem with non-payment in many cases. That must be prevented. We must all work to prevent it. But why must we deem all to be guilty before trial? Thirty per cent of separated parents continue to care for their children. They should be given the option of continuing to do so without bureaucratic intervention.

I return to the element of poverty eradication to which I referred earlier. This Government claims that it wants more flexible opportunities for sole parents to earn income. With so many people having to go on supporting parent's benefit, why will this Government not look at the realistic opportunities many people, largely women, have to go out and earn a living? At the moment we have dreadful statistics for the supporting parent's benefit. In 1982, under the previous Government, there were 124,000 recipients of supporting parents' benefits, with 216,000 dependants, costing revenue $606m. In 1986, the figure had risen to 176,000, with 308,000 dependants, costing us $1,234m. Those are rises of 42 per cent in recipient numbers, 43 per cent in the number of dependants and 104 per cent in cost-and this Government has the audacity to say that it has done a good job. Even Senator Coates, who is due to follow me, I am sure cannot justify the Government's attitude in saying that these figures represent a good job since 1983 when it came to office. They are disgraceful figures, from which the Government cannot run away.

It is significant that from 1982 to 1986 the percentage of separated wives on supporting parents' benefits rose from 54 per cent to 61 per cent. That, too, is evidence of the declining effectiveness of maintenance payments under this Government. I remind the Senate and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Government refused to accept solutions to this problem as far back as the early 1980s. It is significant also that since 1982 a greater proportion of sole parents have become reliant on welfare for basic support. Between 1982 and 1985 the proportion of female sole parents dependent on welfare rose from 82 per cent to 90 per cent. These are the people who, the Government maintains, it is trying to get back into work force. According to those statistics, it is not doing a very good job. The figures continue to rise for those who are still reliant on welfare. The proportion of male sole parents so dependent also rose, from 20 per cent to 39 per cent-almost double. In total, the percentage rose from 73 per cent to 83 per cent.

Lack of child-care for those most in need-sole parents-has a bearing on the increasing proportion of them who are outside the work force. In 1983 this Government promised 20,000 child-care places. As of 30 June 1987 only 5,700 had been created. I believe that this is due basically to the misdirection of funding for public child-care centres where there are wastefully high staffing numbers and where one-third of children who receive direct and indirect subsidies of $81 a week are not in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the period of the promise? What was the three-year period?
—The Government promised, before the 1983 election, to deliver 20,000 child-care places. As at the end of the last financial year, 1987, it had delivered 5,700.
—You get your figures right.
—They are right, as of today.
—They are Budget figures.

—They are from Senator Coates's own Budget Papers. He should go back to his own Budget Papers and check them. If he has come up with some magical figures in the way he seems to come up with them all the time, I suggest that he check his own Budget Papers. Let us look at the public child-care centres which the Government is so wilfully going ahead and wasting public money on. If the 39,000 community care places were shifted to the private sector, 20,000 new child-care placed would be created. The Government would have saved $70m because private care involves an average cost of $60 per week per child compared with $113 for public child-care.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some classic examples of waste. In South Australia a public child-care centre for 40 children was built for the massive figure of $323,000. A private child-care centre nearby cost $64,000. What is the Government doing spending $323,000 of the taxpayers' money on a child-care centre when it could be privately built for $64,00?

TALK.START.PARA: —What age group did the private ones take?

—I am talking about the child-care bracket in the maintenance area of $81 a week. In Queensland one public child-care centre has a staff of 23 for 65 children, a 1:3 ratio, when the regulations require a ratio of only 1:8. It is a bit like Senator Reynolds providing jobs for the boys and girls. It is what this Government is doing all along the line-spending taxpayers' money and not having any regard to the real output of what the taxpayers' dollar is producing.

SPEECH.PARA: When we condemn the fact that the welfare of Australian children has declined under this Government we must also consider juvenile crime. Australian Institute of Criminology statistics show a rise of 51 per cent from 1981-82 to 1984-85, the last available year, in incidents, of serious assault by juveniles. The incidence of rape is up by 47 per cent; robbery is up by 37 per cent; fraud is up by 33 per cent; breaking, entering and stealing is up by 8 per cent; and motor vehicle offences are up by 4 per cent.

The most distressing aspect is that the Labor mainland State governments, in conjunction with the Federal Government-and it is of major concern in New South Wales and Western Australia-have done nothing about law and order. They have presided over a massive increase in the problem of law and order. Juveniles are showing the worst crime increases among the whole community. I suppose one could be extra cynical and say that juveniles are really graduating to more serious crime because when we look at breaking and entering and car theft we see that 50 per cent in total are committed by juveniles. How can the Federal Government and the mainland State Labor governments be of the opinion that they have provided a better country for Australians to live in? We must make sure that people can live comfortably in our society.

Surely it is even more important that custodial parents spend as much time with their children as possible to provide the love, care and supervision that is necessary. Therefore, I come back to the flexible work agreements which are so important and which can permit normal working hours and working days but provide earlier knock off time for people to get home to supervise their children. Those businesses associated with that should not be subject to union thuggery as they are currently experiencing it.

Another aspect of cost explosion is the child delinquency about which I spoke in conjunction with juvenile crime. Much of this could be overcome by parental supervision and family stability. Custodial parent obligations would be greatly enhanced by the two-pronged approach of ensuring that the maintenance payments of custodial parents are honoured and providing a working environment where custodial parents can have the opportunity of getting a regular income and making sure of the security of their children. We have seen a situation develop in Australia in which payment of maintenance virtually became optional or maintenance was set at ridiculously low levels. This was started by the atrocious Whitlam Government in the early 1970s and then reintroduced by this Government in 1983.

Family allowances have remained unchanged under this Government. If this Government were really dinkum about supporting families in the community it would increase family allowances by over 50 per cent to return them to their original value of 1976. The post-1987 Australian Labor Party Government scheme to assist families with the new family package, in conjunction with marginal tax rates, of course creates another problem: it creates poverty traps for many Australian families. A family with three children and earning $360 a week needs to earn an extra $120 a week to gain a net $9 a week. Such is the nature of the poverty trap this Government has saddled Australian families with. A family allowance worth $386 in 1976 is now worth $273 in real terms. Only the 27 per cent of families below the poverty line will be truly assisted under any of this package.

Continued stress on intact families on modest incomes is the continuing underlying factor as to how this Government fails the great majority of Australian children whose welfare cannot be separated from that of the family. Yet at the same time this Government says it is going to eradicate child poverty by 1990. What it is in fact doing is enhancing child poverty by creating these poverty traps, not just for children of single parents but for many other children in intact families.

We as Australians must all aim at making people responsible for their own actions and themselves and direct them away from the Government should pay mentality, give them the incentive to get out there and get a job and give them the incentive to make sure they are maintaining their responsibilities to their family. We must get them away from the attitude that the Government should pay: the Government will pay for this, the Government will pay for that. They must recognise sooner or later that governments do not have money of their own; governments have only taxpayers' money. If we ram that home often enough we may get back to a position of personal accountability by individuals. Parents must realise that their children are not animals that they can just send to the pound but are their direct responsibility and not that of the taxpayer.

Another important aspect of this Bill is spouse maintenance. Many women, not only children, are living under great poverty after marriage breakdown and a degree of maintenance should be provided for women, particularly those looking after children. Once again it comes back to policies of governments to ensure that there is a true option for people to get out there and get a job that allows them to earn a substantial living for both themselves and their children and at the same time to provide them with the option to look after their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by laying to rest this accusation which various Opposition speakers have used and which Senator Knowles repeated that the Government has been slow in its action in this area. It has been frustrating in this period not to have been able to achieve this package of legislation earlier than this but Senator Knowles and all her colleagues ought to be reasonable and acknowledge the very complex nature of this whole issue and the way in which it had to be dealt with in a thorough way which tried to deal with all the issues involved. It involved consultation with the public and with those affected. Yes, it has taken several years to get to this stage but I can assure people that if the Opposition had been in government this package would have been nowhere near this point, if the Opposition had been left in charge to develop such a scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles and others point to the fact that in 1983 Senator Durack brought up a Bill to amendment the Family Law Act to require that social security entitlement be ignored for the purpose of calculating maintenance. That is true and at that time--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you reject it then?

—Because the Government was in the process of developing a package of measures. This is the problem. Senator Knowles suggested that her side had the solutions in the early 1980s. Senator Chaney, in a discussion about this general area, may have foreshadowed a maintenance collection agency as an option but it was never the policy of the previous Government, it was never the policy of those who are now the Opposition. Their only policy was to alter the Family Law Act in that one simple way and to throw people into gaol. Certainly, the next time around that Senator Durack introduced that same Bill, during the proceedings on the Bill he withdrew the reference to gaoling people as the only method for providing for maintenance to be paid. I acknowledge that. He left it just as a simple amendment to the Family Law Act that would ensure that social security entitlement was ignored for maintenance calculation purposes. As has been correctly stated from the other side, we opposed the Bill at the time because we did not want that change to be made in isolation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill that we are dealing with is the second Bill of a package of three Bills that are part of a planned program that is complex, and that ought to be acknowledged by the Opposition. There was the change to the Family Law Act at the end of last year. This Child Support Bill sets up the Child Support Agency and before long we will have the relevant social security amendments as the third Bill in this package. The second stage of this scheme, about which there is community consultation at present, is the development of a formula which can be a guide to how maintenance is collected. That is not part of the scheme at this stage. This scheme involves the family law changes which have already been passed, this child support measure and the social security changes. It is part of a planned package which has involved public consultation and a thorough review. It is due to the efforts of those who have worked so thoroughly on this matter-particularly Dr Meredith Edwards and those others in the various departments who have worked on it-that we have developed it to this state, which would not have happened had the Opposition been in charge.

I turn to the amendment that the Opposition has moved to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. The Opposition has suggested that those on the Government side who have spoken do not understand what it is driving at in its opposition. The fact is that we understand only too well that it is driving at. The Opposition is suggesting that there are these rights of non-custodial parents who have entered into maintenance arrangements so that when they are willing to pay the maintenance that has been ordered by the court there should be no registration of the agreement with the Child Support Agency. The Opposition misunderstands the whole scheme in that registration of all such orders from the Family Court will be automatic-that is, the Family Courts around the country will provide to the Child Support Agency, set up as part of the Australian Taxation Office, the details--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what is being objected to in the case of those particular people.

—The Opposition says that those agreements should not even be registered. That is what its amendment states. The fact is that there will be that automatic registration but no action will be taken on those registered agreements unless one of the parties involved is a client of the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs or unless the custodial parent seeks to have that agreement enforced. The point is that enforcement must be a decision of the custodial parent. The Opposition is saying that even if the custodial parent wants the agreement enforced, if the non-custodial parent does not want it enforced he or she can say, `No, I do not want it enforced'. The point is that--
—We are not saying that at all.

—That is exactly what the amendment states. It reads, `Wishes to ensure the protection of the rights of non-custodial parents'. The point is that if there is not an amicable agreement, there will obviously be a need for enforcement by the Agency. If there is not agreement about whether it should be enforced, the agreement is hardly an amicable one. Let me make it clear: where both of the parties are happy for their private arrangement to continue, there will be no need for the Child Support Agency to become involved and it will need to become involved only if there is a default and the custodial parent takes action to ask for enforcement. But it still needs to be the choice of the custodial parent to have the collection made by the Agency, even if the non-custodial parent agrees. Even in relatively amicable arrangements there is at least one good reason for that-that is, the at arm's length nature of the payment of the maintenance. It ought to be readily understandable that the custodial parent should be able to say, `I don't want to receive this payment directly but I want it to be done through the Child Support Agency and the Department of Social Security and to receive it in that manner'. I think that that adequately answers that part of the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the amendment purports to condemn the Government for the fact that the welfare of Australian children has rapidly declined under this Government. The Opposition has an absolute cheek to suggest such an amendment at a time when the family allowance supplement (FAS) is in the process of being delivered to tens of thousands of Australian families. Payments to pensioners and beneficiaries over the period of this Government will have increased from $10 per child to $22 or to $28 per week per child, depending on the age of the child. There are so many more people in the work force on relatively low incomes who are now eligible for the family allowance supplement, including those who were eligible for the previous family income supplement. They now receive an increased amount. There are many more who, because of the sliding scale arrangements of the income test for the family allowance supplement, will now qualify for it as well. I hope that more and more people will apply for the FAS payment if they have even the slightest thought that they might be entitled to it. The more people who apply, the greater the success of the scheme in ensuring that those who are eligible obtain it. Those with a relatively large number of children can receive quite a high income-higher than average weekly earnings if there are five or six children-and still qualify for at least some family allowance supplement. So with those few words I dismiss that part of the Opposition's amendment.

The whole question of the collection of maintenance for children after the breakdown of a marriage or a relationship has always been a problem. Anything that has been tried in the past to enforce payment has not succeeded. As a result, as everyone acknowledges, the Government has had to take up a large part of the financial responsibility for the children of divorced and separated parents. As has been acknowledged on both sides, the majority of non-custodial parents have reneged completely on their responsibilities towards their children, even in cases where quite inadequate amounts of maintenance have been either awarded or agreed to. This has contributed to the unacceptably high numbers of children living in poverty in Australia, which this Government is tackling.

Senator Knowles referred to the promise of the Government that no child need live in poverty by 1990 as a disposable promise. If in 1990 that promise has not been implemented let her then say that it was a disposable promise. But we will wait until then because that was a key part of the Government's election policy which we are determined to stick to, to ensure that the family allowance supplement does not remain at its present level but is adjusted to take into account changes in the consumer price index, and to ensure that no children need to live in poverty by 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one of you will answer how you will do it.

—Senator Knowles seems to have a real fixation about this matter. I acknowledge that it was a central promise of the election campaign, which has been implemented for this year and which will continue to be implemented over the next few years to 1990, to ensure that no children need to live in poverty in relation to the amount that is available to them through the family allowance supplement, having regard to the poverty line, as is generally acknowledged.
—Tell us how. You cannot do it.

—Just wait until the Budget, and the Budget after that. The establishment of the Child Support Agency, which will be within the Taxation Office, will contribute to relieving the burden of poverty which has been placed on so many children. It will also ensure that the flow of funds which should have occurred up until now, and which has in so many cases not occurred, will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some opposition to this Bill by interest groups in the community, but perhaps not as much as one might have expected. The bipartisan support generally for the Bill is, I think, a factor in achieving its successful passage. I think it can be asserted that, despite the Opposition's amendment in which it has complained about one aspect of the proposed rules for the use of the Child Support Agency, it generally supports the proposal that there be such an agency, which is in some ways surprising in view of its general attitude to government becoming involved in things.

At least on this occasion it has acknowledged the necessity for government to become involved, to have an agency in the Australian Taxation Office responsible for collecting maintenance from those concerned and passing it on through the Department of Social Security to the custodial parents for the benefit of the children involved.

It is important to stress that the Bill is not about pursuing, for punishment or degradation, non-custodial parents. It is not about setting up custodial parents in some position of advantage compared with their former spouses. It is about giving the children involved the right to adequate financial support. This will be fully achieved only when the courts award more reasonable maintenance payments. In the meantime, even with the sorts of awards that are presently made, it will certainly help those who have had difficulty up until now in getting their maintenance. It will ensure that the primary consideration of both parents is the proper financial support of the children of their marriage or relationship in accordance with the ability of each to pay.

I think this Bill, and this whole legislative package, sets the pace in trying to solve the problem of maintenance collection which is encountered throughout the world. I think we will find that Australia, because of these measures, will improve its reputation. The whole strength of this package is in the linking of the activities of the Family Court of Australia with those of the Department of Social Security through the necessary powers of the Taxation Office.

One of the criticisms that are made concerns the automatic deduction of maintenance payments from the salary or wages of non-custodial parents and the fact that this might involve some stigma. I hope that this whole scheme will avoid the attachment of stigma to the collection of maintenance because of its automatic nature, because it will become just part of the general scheme of things. In the same way as people have their pay as you earn taxation deductions made from their wages, so will some employees have their payments to the Child Support Agency deducted.

I think that is another answer to the Opposition's amendment. If we were to follow the proposal in its amendment that only those who already had defaulted would have to participate in the scheme, that would make the Child Support Agency a punitive body. It would mean that those who had their collections done that way had already defaulted. I do not think we want that to be the situation. I think we want it to be a neutral arrangement whereby there is no particular stigma or labelling involved in having maintenance orders collected in this way. That is a further argument which I should have mentioned before against the Opposition's second reading amendment.

The establishment of a new and separate income test, which is part of the overall scheme, has been criticised, but it is a genuine commitment to improving living standards and ensuring that any earnings that a custodial parent has are treated separately from the question of maintenance. The proposal has been criticised as being too tough, and there is some legitimacy in that criticism. But it is important that the whole question of work force participation be part of the scheme, and a separate maintenance income test free area is a requirement that we really cannot get away from, and in fact it will be of benefit to some of those involved.

We have to acknowledge that there are those cases where the collection of maintenance is impossible, where there is no identifiable non-custodial parent or where that person just cannot be found. Such people will not be as well off relative to those in cases where the maintenance order can be enforced. I do not think anyone would suggest that we should therefore abandon the scheme or not implement this part of it just because of that. It would be better, as has been suggested, if there was a maintenance payment or its equivalent available to all of those in this situation. At least the scheme as proposed will go a long way towards improving the situation for custodial parents and the children involved and will ensure that there is a reasonable method of administering the scheme, providing for those who want to use it and for those who are involved in the social security system an arm's length method by which maintenance orders are paid from the non-custodial parent to the custodial parent.

I support the Bill and congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for getting to this stage with our package of measures. Again I reject the Opposition's criticism of the time taken. I would have been nice to have had all three Bills passed before Christmas. That was not possible. At least this is being done at this stage of the year and a very welcome scheme is being implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight debating the Child Support Bill and, as has been said several times, this Bill is receiving the support of the Opposition. However, we have a two-part amendment in relation to the legislation, and Senator Coates obviously has some difficulty in understanding the import of our amendments. I think that rather tends to demonstrate the difference between the Opposition's approach to government and the Government's approach to government. It is a pretty basic difference, and that is that we believe that, unless citizens absolutely have to have government intervention in their lives, we should try to keep it out wherever possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of maintenance payments between parents for the sake of their children, if there is an amicable agreement working we can see absolutely no reason why government should be involved. We believe it is only if that agreement does not work or starts to break down that there should be any reason for government and employers to be involved. So there is a quite clear distinction in the way we approach the matter of how people in this country want to lead their lives and whether they should be forced to lead their lives in a certain way. We do not believe in compulsion and the compulsory involvement of government unless it is necessary.

The second part of our amendment condemns the fact that the welfare of Australian children has rapidly declined under the Hawke Labor Government. Any parent in Australia could tell the Government that that is the fact. I do not think that Senator Coates is doing the Government much of a service by trying to pretend otherwise. There cannot be a family outside this chamber who believes that they are better off now than they were when the Hawke Labor Government came to power in 1983. If Senator Coates thinks otherwise, he had better go back to his electorate of Tasmania. I find that families down there have quite a different view of his Government.

Nevertheless, the Opposition welcomes this legislation. It is interesting to note in passing the very high proportion of female senators who have spoken in this debate. I think there are 13 speakers on the list, and nine are female. That may say something about the sensitivity of this issue, particularly for women. So many women in our society have been disadvantaged by ending up the custodial parent with no money. Perhaps many of us in the chamber can feel, `There but for the grace of God go I'. We are also saddened so often to see families that need the help of both parents but are getting it from only one and the state. We have heard constantly in this debate the disgraceful figure indicating that currently 70 per cent of maintenance orders in this country are not being complied with. It is a figure that all of us should hang our heads in shame over.

This legislation, as was the previous legislation that Senator Coates referred to earlier and that his Party rejected when we tried to introduce it some years ago, is really an admission that the Whitlam Government's provisions in the Family Law Act relating to the need for judges to take into account social security benefits in deciding on maintenance were a form of social engineering which has proved to be a total failure. As a result of this social engineering, many families in this country have come to grief. I am glad to say that at last, and not before time, those mistakes are being wound back. The Institute of Family Studies estimates that 400,000 children living in poverty are supported by sole parents; that is, half the children in poverty in Australia are being supported by sole parents.

Between 1976 and 1983 there were 430,773 children in Australia who had lived through a divorce; 30 years ago, the figure was 8,235. We simply have to take more action to tackle the problem of family breakdown at its source. This legislation tackles a symptom, and thank goodness it does, but I do not think this Government is doing enough to help deal with the source of the problem-family breakdown. It is not widely understood that 80 per cent of sole-parent families are in that position because of separation, divorce or the death of a spouse. I think most people outside this chamber would be astonished to know that that is what sole-parent families really are. I think many people have a quite different view. Sole-parent families now make up 14.4 per cent of all families in Australia; in 1974 the figure was only 9.2 per cent.

It is quite clear to all of us that we should have measures which keep families together, but this Government seems to be going in the opposite direction. Dr Warwick Hartin, of the National Marriage Guidance Council, says that this year the Government will spend $5.1m in grants to marriage counselling organisations but $5.1 billion on divorce and its consequences-$5.1 billion on sweeping up the mess and only $5.1m on trying to prevent the mess happening.

The tax system still disadvantages families with children. It is clear that this is so; every study ever done can demonstrate it. The Government knows it; it has had advice to that effect, but it will not take effective action. The Government believes that by slapping money at people in a welfare manner it can fix the problem of child poverty. Throwing the money around with the family allowance supplement is not the way. An honourable, dignified way to handle the problem is to assist those working families to support themselves by reducing the level of taxation on them. Let them keep what they earn. Raise the threshold. There are many other ways. We have suggested a number of ways. I will not tonight go through them all again, but the Government has had this advice over and over again. It fails to take action. It likes to give people a handout mentality.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense!

—It does. The Government believes in a welfare state, clothed in whatever name Senator Coates wants to call it. The Government wants people to get hooked on its milch cow. Look at the action the Government took over the tertiary allowance and how that affected supporting parents. The Government took action to prevent supporting parents on maintenance from continuing their studies. They could not continue their studies, because they were not eligible for assistance unless they were on the supporting parent's benefit. A woman may have been getting maintenance from her husband and striving to improve her qualifications so that she could be self-sufficient, but this Government did not lift a finger to help her. It said, `You just muddle along'. Day after day Senator Ryan told this chamber what good things she was doing for women in this country, but the ones who wanted to be self-reliant she left floundering because they could not afford last year the $250 per subject, if they were trying to do one subject a year perhaps because they had small children in the home. That charge is now $263. The Government just sits by and lets that happen.
—And so did the Opposition.

—We did not introduce that legislation, and the honourable senators know that. So we have some misgivings about the legislation. We believe there are very real problems that the Government has to face with self-employed parents who wilfully avoid paying maintenance. I believe it will be extremely difficult to pin down self-employed people. Obviously pay as you earn taxpayers will be picked up fairly easily, but I do not think the problem of self-employed parents will be as easily resolved. I am concerned that we will be another year down the track before we get the formula. I recognise that this is the hard part and the Government has put it at the end. I sympathise with it. That is the real Solomon job-trying to work out whose rights will be paramount. Would it be the rights of the first family or those of the second family? Which spouse will have the better standard of living? Remembering back to my time in practice in the law before the Family Law Act was introduced, we had some real difficulties in establishing paternity. I can see those coming back with a vengeance now and we do not look as though we will be any better equipped to deal with that problem now than we were then. As Senator Panizza said to me before, a father with a stockwhip was perhaps one of the ways of establishing paternity in the past, but I do not know whether fathers these days keep stockwhips. It is a very difficult problem which has to be faced down the track. We will have a lot of difficulty with mothers who will not name the father of their child or cannot name the father of their child, or with fathers who deny paternity. I do not know how that will be dealt with. I have already mentioned the problem we see with parents who have an agreement which they see no reason for the Government to be involved in, and I think they are also entitled to their privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that does worry me about the legislation is the very real penalties that will be imposed upon employers. There is a $5,000 fine if payments are not paid over to the maintenance collection agency in the proper time, and a very short time it is too. I think of the small business people who so often do their books at night after having worked all day. These are not the sort of people who can afford to employ bookkeepers and accountants to do their pay records for them and simply add one more item to the pay sheet or the computer. These are people who have to sit up at night to do the pay records and keep the books up to date, waiting for the tax man to inspect them or pop in to have a friendly chat. They are already overburdened with government regulations. This Government, particularly, does not seem to have much concern for those sorts of people. If one is in very big business perhaps the Hawke Government is interested, but small business seems to have been forgotten long ago. That is widely recognised outside. This will be one more pressure on small business.

I was very interested to see the Government's commitment to children and poverty already being watered down. On 23 June last year, during the election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, `By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty'. On 1 July he said, `There will be no watering down of the pledge that was made'. Senator Walsh, in his second reading speech, said, `by 1990, no Australian child need live in poverty'. I might be a very suspicious female but I wonder at the slight difference between the Prime Minister's adamant insistence that no child would be living in poverty and Senator Walsh's speech which said that no child need live in poverty. Is that an option, an opt out clause, for the Government-that it will not be its fault if children are living in poverty-when it does not achieve what is claiming? That was a very stupid election commitment by the Prime Minister that he has no hope of keeping-and nobody outside really believes that he will keep.

It is the same sort of election comment that we hear from Dr Blewett who recently, with an eye to the New South Wales election, said that 19,000 child-care places have been approved out of the 20,000 that were promised back in 1983. But Senator Knowles tonight gave us some very detailed facts on this matter. The situation is that, as at 30 June last year, only 5,758 places had been created. Dr Blewett has some pretty fast footwork or some very creative accounting if he has achieved 19,000 places since 30 June last year. How many of those are bricks and mortar-in place-and how many are just approvals or pieces of paper he is shuffling over his desk? I have my doubts about that election claim, too. I think it has a lot to do with the New South Wales election. We will be lucky if a formula is worked out. With the time that is needed to put it into law, we will be lucky if it has much impact by 1990.

One of the problems that we will be facing, as I said earlier, is: what are we going to do about the quality of life for the second family and the first? I do not believe that a second family's income should be preserved at the expense of the first. These days are the days of contraceptives. No-one is forced to have children that cannot be supported. If people cannot support a second family without disadvantage to the first, they should not have the second family. We are adults and we have opportunities to avoid having new responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second family might already exist.

—Presumably that family has a father. Let the responsibility fall where it is due. Senator Coates should not use that as an argument for not supporting the first family. I find that quite unacceptable. I am very pleased to think that this legislation will bring a measure of dignity to supporting parents who, quite unfairly in many ways, have been the subject of a lot of criticism in the community.
—On your side primarily.

—Not at all. People right around this country think that supporting mothers are milking the system. As I tried to point our earlier, the figures show quite clearly that over 80 per cent of sole-parent families are in that position because of separation, divorce or death of a spouse. That is quite contrary to what a lot of people believe. When we have a system working through the maintenance collection agency, that will go some way towards giving supporting mothers, struggling in poverty as they are now, some sort of dignity in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that these people be encouraged to get out of the welfare cycle and find a means of supporting themselves. When proper maintenance is provided to children by fathers, mothers will feel able to get out and give themselves more of a leg up. But the Government does not give them a leg up by penalising them for trying to improve their qualifications. These mothers are really struggling against the system. We seem to have become a country in which people are always talking about their rights. All of us have rights. Everyone will wander round at some stage with a placard talking about rights. We seem to have given up any idea that we have responsibilities. That is a very old-fashioned idea these days. One is looked on as if one has come out of the ark if one talks about responsibilities. I would like to think that this legislation, at last, is doing just a little towards getting responsibilities back on the agenda, instead of putting rights as priorities. Parents have responsibilities; children have the rights-but they have not been getting them until now. I am glad to think that this legislation is focusing attention back on making people fulfil their responsibilities. What a dreadful thing it is that we need legislation to make people support their own children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Child Support Bill 1987 and the amendment the Opposition has moved. The Bill has already been well explained by previous speakers, so I will not go into it, but it is designed to enforce the collection of maintenance orders from non-custodial parents This Bill arose, no doubt, from the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last year that `By 1990, there will be no child living in poverty'. However noble his intentions were at the time, many parents at large did not envisage the course of play that the Prime Minister meant. He did not point out that employers were going to take the brunt of collecting the money that he had promised to supporting parents. If the Prime Minister had done so, the Government would have lost as many votes on this issue as it gained.

SPEECH.PARA: Our side of politics welcomes the Bill. It is a means of forcing onto some parents the responsibility they took on, or should have known they were taking on, when they entered into the institution of marriage and commenced a family. Statistics have shown that there have been an increasing number of parents who leave marriage or a de facto relationship and walk away, leaving the Government to pick up the responsibilities. The time has come to put an end to this and to return to a stricter method of collection of maintenance as existed in the past, though not one by which people are removed to Her Majesty's nearest prison. The Bill is a mechanism to inform people of their responsibilities in bringing children into the world. Mothers and fathers alike no longer will be able to pass the responsibility on to the community.

However, my main concern this evening is for the free collectors of the scheme, the employers. Once again, the Government has seen fit to add another responsibility to the ever increasing responsibilities of the gratis collectors of revenue. We already have the pay as you earn collection system, with its inherent penalties. Other free collection services provided by the employers are: Medicare payments; sales tax; the fringe benefits tax-here the employers have the privilege of picking up the tab as well-and prescribed payments, with their own penalties. The Australian Taxation Office sends reminders to employers even if they do not have to send in payments for that month. Another collection service is the voluntary deductions requested by employees, which the employer is obliged to collect, such as union fees and hospital dues. In this case, under clause 47 (1), there is provision for a penalty of up to $5,000, 12 months imprisonment, or both, for failure to furnish particulars in the approved form within the first seven days of the following month.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Smith Family: Proposed Building-Reimbursement of Medical Bills-Foreign Investment in Australian Farms

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do not adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to refer to two matters tonight that I hope the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) will take up. The first matter relates to the building that the Smith Family wishes to go ahead with at Woden. The Smith Family and the club next door have come to an arrangement about the block of land and the construction. SPEECH.PARA: The delay seems to be that a portion of the block of land needs to be valued so that the Minister can determine whether or not there is any betterment tax payable in relation to it. I am told that the Australian Taxation Office, which is the appropriate authority, has, in fact, valued the block of land and has advised the Australian Capital Territory Administration businesses leases section that it has valued it and what the value would be.
