I ask the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to look into this section of his Department with a view to expediting medical bills, not just for one constituent but for all of them because for those who are attempting to live on about $235 a fortnight, to be out of pocket $20 or $30 on medical bills is, indeed, a great hardship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to address myself to the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) annual report. I particularly wish to refer to the purchase of rural properties by foreign investors. The report shows that in the last financial year the amount spent by foreign purchasers of Australian farms rose by more than $100m-from $44m to $143m. In land area Australia lost to foreign ownership 512,000 hectares in 1986-87. Added to the 1985-86 figure, the total new foreign ownership for the past two years has been 3,650,000 hectares. While I do accept that these figures may have many different and debatable interpretations, it is clear that they do show an increasing ownership by foreigners of our rural properties.

SPEECH.PARA: However, over and above this, the most disturbing aspect of these figures is that they do not give a clear picture of the actual foreign ownership of Australian farms and, even more so, the potential of foreign ownership of Australian farms. This is because the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has directed the FIRB to review the purchase of only those properties costing over $3m. As a consequence, the FIRB has no record of the number of types of farms purchased or the names of the purchasers of farms under the value of $3m. Considering that the vast majority of farms in Australia today are valued under $3m and they are mostly family farms by nature, I see this as a serious flaw in the ability to shape or plan economic policy in Australia, particularly in relation to the family farm. However, what we do know from the Australian Bureau of Statistics is that over the past three years, 4,000 to 5,000 farm units have disappeared from the Australian landscape.

While this Government carries out its micro- and macro-economic policies that are distinctly anti-family farm, I believe that freeing up of foreign ownership rules is another serious blow to the survival of the economic and social unit of the family farm. I do not believe that more regulation by the FIRB is the real answer. I believe the answer lies in this Government's will to tackle in the upcoming May economic statement the real problems of family farmers, the dual problems of taxation and tariffs and the improvement of family farm access to cheaper finances-namely, reduced interest rates.

I really do not think that the Government is giving Australians a fair go to hang onto their properties. Let us not forget that these properties truly do symbolise ownership of Australian natural resources. This link between ownership and work is probably the most powerful stimulus to personal enterprise. The family farm is an efficient, economic unit, as it must be in these economic times. With the daunting economic challenges ahead of us, it must be part of our future economic strategy and not be handed over-unleashed-to foreigners, worst of all, unrecorded. It has got to a stage where this Government really has to decide to what extent it will allow our farms to be sold off to foreigners or corporatised. It must give Australians an answer in the forthcoming economic May statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we have heard from Senator Reid, who raised the issue of unfortunate delays in regard to the paperwork that has to be completed for the building of the Smith Family to proceed. Obviously the Smith Family does a tremendous service for the community and we would all like to see it have its home at Woden as soon as possible. I will certainly undertake to refer the honourable senator's concerns about this delay to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson).

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator also raised the question of reimbursement of medical expenses and, again, the question of delay. I do not know whether Senator Reid will find this to be any consolation, but I sometimes am under the impression that delays occur only when one is distant from Canberra. So I guess, in a sense, I am reassured that delays affect the people of the Australian Capital Territory as well. But on a serious note, I do not accept that the constituent to whom Senator Reid referred is obviously being considerably disadvantaged by delays of up to 10 weeks. I will certainly refer the honourable senator's and the constituent's concern to the Minister.

I was interested in Senator McGauran's speech this evening. I wonder whether he has ever taken up the question of a register of foreign ownership with some of his colleagues in Queensland. I am sure that Senator Jones will agree with me when I say that we have been trying for many years to get Senator McGauran's National Party colleagues in Queensland to agree to establish a register of foreign ownership in that State. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the historical basis for the title ``the Honourable'' being applied to Ministers.
(2) What is the reason for the practice continuing.
(3) What would have to be done by an individual Minister or by the Government to avoid the title in any specific case or generally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Records held by my department indicate that the earliest use of the title ``the Honourable'' in Australia was in October 1856 following the grant of a Constitution to New South Wales when the title was accorded to the President of the Legislative Council and the Speaker of the Assembly. While there was no direct reference to use of the title for members of the Executive Council, they were generally so styled from the inception of responsible government in the Australian colonies. In November 1900, the Secretary of State for the Colonies advised that the use of the title was extended by Queen Victoria to members of the Federal Executive Council. As all Ministers are Executive Councillors they consequently receive the title ``Honourable''.
(2) The reasons for continuing the practice of styling Ministers ``The Honourable'' are based on tradition and continuing acceptance.

(3) As the honourable senator would know, there is no legislation conferring upon Ministers a right to the title ``Honourable'' and there is no legislative requirement to use the title. TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1204), Senator Walters asked Senator Ryan, as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of Dr Henry Giaretto's highly successful self help treatment of more than 6,000 sexually abused children and their families at the Californian Institute for the Community as an Extended Family? Will the Minister consider inviting Dr Giaretto to visit Australia so that he can give first-hand help to the Institute's treatment centres here in Australia? If so, when will this take place?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Treatment programs for sexually abused children and their families are primarily the responsibility of State Governments as a result of State legislative provisions in the areas of child health and welfare.

While the problem of child abuse is of great concern to the Commonwealth Government and this portfolio, the Commonwealth has sought to avoid duplication of State statutory responsibilities in this area.
The focus of the Children's Services Program and its enabling legislation, the Child Care Act 1972, is on the provision of child day care services.

The Commonwealth/State cost-shared Family Support Program is not directly involved with child abuse. It contributes indirectly to the prevention of child abuse through services funded, which are expected to be oriented to the prevention of family breakdown and to the enhancement of the role of the family.
For the reasons outlined, it is not appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to invite Dr Giaretto to Australia.
